I know they're not perfect - Jamie is TOO wonderful and obviously written by a woman - but that's ok in my book because I get great pleasure from him.  By the way, gals, listen to songs like "Broadsword & the Beast" and "Dun Ringill" (and many others) sung by Ian Anderson of Jethro Tull - that voice IS Jamie's voice to me. So - I don't know what I'm gonna do when Jamie dies at that kirk yard, aye?  And why aren't there more Jamies out there anyway?  Diana - keep up the GREAT WORK - I am psyched to see so many people love your work as much as we do!

It started out well enough, but the convoluted plot lines that added little to the arc of the story made it too long and silly.  I liked Claire less and less as the book went on.  It's hard to stick with a long novel in which the main character is annoying. The level of violence and rape in what is supposedly the main romantic relationship in the book also turned me off to this book.  I grew tired of the story with no point and the unappealing characters and didn't finish.

I JUST KEEP READING DIANA'S BOOKS OVER AND OVER AGAIN!  EVERYTIME YOU READ THEM YOU FIND SOMETHING NEW. EVERYONE SHOULD READ DIANA'S WORK AT LEAST ONCE. THEY'LL NEVER BE ABLE TO STOP!  TRUELY AWSOME READING !

Well....Let me start off by saying I cannot BELIEVE there are actually 1 star reviews of this book!! If you're "offended" by the darker content in this story I definitely recommend maybe reading the Harry Potter series instead.  That being said I absolutely fell IN LOVE with Jamie Fraser!! I started teasing my boyfriend to start speaking to me with a scottish accent :) I could not put the book down and am a 3rd of the way into the 3rd book. I am an avid reader. I typically read from 4 to 6 books a month...This series has become one of my favorites. It has everything anyone could want in a story. Those of you out there who are a tad skeptical about the "Historical Romance" genre of this book....DON'T BE. I admit that I was a bit turned off by that myself. I've never read a book like this before. A woman that came into my bar told me it was the best book she has ever read (thank you by the way...) and when the download was free for kindle I decided to give it a whirl.  I am so, so, SO glad I did. I understand why DG has such a huge fan base! I have been telling everyone I know to read this book!

This might possibly be the worst book that I have read in my pretty long life.  It's hard to believe that somebody is going to make a TV series out of this garbage, but these premium channels are so desperate to find the next "Game of Thrones" that they'll try anything that has any connection to fantasy tied in with an historical period.  But this book is incompetently written "mommy-porn", with elements of sadism and masochism, so sick mommy-porn.  I decided I'd had enough when the "hunk-of-the-book" spanked our heroine when she "got out of line"; and it was pretty clear that the author of this, um, piece of material was entirely on his side.  How shallow and petulant of her to object to being spanked by her husband!  Of course, he had been spanked a good deal in his life as well, and quite a bit worse actually -- enough abuse, in fact, to give the Marquis de Sade a pretty good charge.  Which leads me to the books strong streak of homophobia...  Oh well, never mind.  Folks, this is really awful stuff.  If the action doesn't put you off, the writing will.

I just finished reading all the online reviews of this book and really enjoyed everyone's opinions. It was like participating in a gigantic book discussion. I am an avid reader, and long time member of a book discussion  group. I have read thousands of books in my life but I can honestly say  this one is in my top five favorites. The only other characters as  memorable to me are Catherine and Heathcliff. DG is such a gifted writer. I  too consumed all of her books in record time to the dismay of my husband  and children (although my husband appreciated it in the long run). They are  so addictive. I just bought the companion book and cannot wait to read it  also (although it will make me read them all over again). I too, have been  to Scotland several times in my life and can attest to DG's skill in  describing that beautiful country. I can't wait for the next book, but  being a mother, I also don't want to pressure DG to neglect her family too  much just to rush out the next one to appease her many fans. However long  we have to wait, it will be worth the wait I am sure!

I have read the whole series twice and purchased several copies to give to friends.  I tell everyone that the first book is priced lower to get you addicted like drugs...once you read it you would pay any price to remain on the journey with Jamie and Claire.  I had never read a time travel novel before this series and the clerk in the store had to convince me to buy it...but when I found myself sneaking downstairs late at night just to read another chapter I knew I was in trouble.  Jamie is everything I love in a man - he is strong, funny, smart, honest and loyal with a very high tolerance for mental and physical pain (as Claire, among others, puts him through both more than once!).  I could feel for Claire and her struggle to resist Jamie's pull so she could ultimately return to the life she once knew but you bet I was cheering for Jamie every step of the way.  I absolutely love and highly recommend this book - enjoy!

I really did like the character Jamie, but I had problems with Claire.  She seemed to get over the time travel ordeal pretty quickly, which kind of lost me.  She also seemed to lack vulnerability and softness which made her seem harsh and negative.  I just remembered her yelling at Jamie a lot.  And the tone changed too quickly for me towards the end.  I suppose it was because there was romance thrown in this novel, so I really didn't expect any thing as heavy as the torture scenes.  That just made me confused and I wasn't sure what I was reading anymore.  Some parts seemed to drag, and I had a hard time following some of the descriptions, such as the names for the weapons and garments.  It was interesting to look them up as I read though, so I learned some things.  Despite some funny dialogues and interesting endeavors, I just found myself skimming through a lot of it.  I don't think I'll be picking up the sequels.

Shame on me for not reading the full description of this book before downloading it to my kindle.  I read the premise, and being a fan of historical fiction, sci-fi and fantasy I thought the time travel element sounded interesting. Had I have taken the time to read Amazon’s Editorial Review I might have had second thoughts, because the text included in that review was a sampling of basically the whole book. While the author did a wonderful job placing the reader in the time period, the amount of sex and innuendo in this book was more than I cared to read. What could have been a great story was really only mediocre.  I can’t help but think its popularity is due more to the fact that it’s more of a lustful fantasy than anything else.  Had this book been less a sexually charged romance and more a historical fiction/time travel story I would have given it more stars.

I read Outlander several years ago when it first came out.  I was captivated from the beginning and truly agreed with my friend that it was, indeed, the best book I had ever read.  Just recently, in anticipation of  the next book, I decided to go back and re-read that long novel...and  again, I didn't skip a page.  It was even better the second time.  Whatever  you do, give yourself some time and make room for this book on your list of  "must reads".  It'll be worth it!  And if you can't talk your  husband into reading it...just read him parts from the historical battles  and in a few days you'll find him asking you about Jamie & Claire.  This is definitely not a romance, so if you're looking for an intelligent  alternative to those "soupy" love stories - get started with  Outlander and read ALL Diana Gabaldon's books!

You know, I really liked this book. The characters are interesting, the plot kept me reading, the descriptions and scenery make me want to travel and experience the Scottish Highlands. However, there was a huge plot development that I wasn't prepared for: the sexually violent abuse further along in the book. Something did need to happen at that plot point. It works in one way towards the completion of Ms. Gabaldon's plot layout. However, I only think it fair to advise readers with such sensitivities that there is disturbing sexual abuse/violence in OUTLANDER. To know is to choose with truth.

Well, I must admit I've read Outlander at least a dozen times and have met Ms. Gabaldon twice...so I obviously love Claire and Jamie. These books are not, I repeat NOT typical romances. If you want something cute, tame, and sexy, read Nora Roberts. If you want lots of spice and supernatural, read Laurell K. Hamilton. If you want something that defies description, is beautiful, disturbing, and hauntingly original, read Outlander. I understand how some people are disturbed by the violence, but if you handled the movie Braveheart OK you should be able to take this. The relationship between Jamie and Claire is the main thread of all the books, but if I had to place this novel anywhere it would be Historical Fantasy (not that there is such a thing!), NOT Romance. Gabaldon's writing style is intelligent and refreshing, her characters are breathing and tangible, and the story is breathtaking, especially considering it was a)written somewhat secretly, largely online while the author was taking care of three children, just to see if she could do it and b)without Gabaldon ever going to Scotland. I've done my share of research on the 18th Century Highlands (and if I read another review that says this book takes place in the Middle Ages I'll scream) and her portrayal is amazingly well-thought-out. In response to other reviews, Claire had a nomadic childhood and was a war nurse in WWII. She admits she barely knows Frank after eight years of marriage. I think that justifies her easy adjustment to the primitive conditions and her seeming (to some few people) callousness towards Frank. Anyway, I believe this novel is a masterpiece. And I've read A LOT of books.

I must say at first I wasn't sure I would enjoy this book.  I guess you could say I'm a fussy reader and am not a big fan of "traditional" romance novels.  I DO like fantasy-type books where the worlds of modern times are combined with the person suddenly finding themselves in another time or place, along the likes of Charles De Lint (who I love!).  During the first few pages, I thought, "Well, I don't know", but as soon as she fell through the stones (within the next few pages) I was hooked.  It combined so many different aspects and was amazingly detailed.  It follows the adventure of Claire, a 1940's post-war nurse who falls through the stones (like Stone Henge).  There she meets up with Jamie Fraser and thus the adventure and romance begins.  The author gets so detailed with their feelings for each other and Claire's thoughts all the way it was amazing.  And they had SO many adventures, most of them life-threatening.  The details of life in the 1700's in Scotland were so detailed and accurate it was astounding.  I actually found myself speaking some Gaellic/Scottish slang on accident here and there (ye 'ken?)  I was so engrossed.  Add in a little sex and it was an incredible book I could not put down.  I have just ordered the next in the series, "Dragonfly in Amber" and eagerly await the package on my doorstep.  Needless to say, with the fact that there are so many books in the series (5) and with the length of each this will be keeping me happy for awhile.  Please keep writing more, Ms. Gabaldon (but Claire and Jamie, not the kids!) and make sure to pick this up and read it.  You won't be sorry!

I read the first four books in the series back in 1998.  I reviewed them then but couldn't find those reviews so I decided to write a new collective supportive review.  I have never read anything that captivated me as much  as the story of Claire and Jamie. The historical accuracy and detail put  the reading into a category of it's own.  Add the romance and the character  detail of each person in the series and you have a story that becomes part  of your whole being.  I think my life was changed.  Sounds rather silly but  it is true.  I found myself so interested in the history of these events  that I began researching and haven't let up since. I am truly hooked. Even  though the story is fiction...the writing is so superb...you want to  believe it is true. I anxiously await the next book.

This is the best book I have ever read. You will devour it and run out to get the next book in the series, and the next, and the next...I understand that the saga continues in a double trilogy (6 books in all). According to The Outlander Companion, Diana Gabaldon set out to write this book for practice, but what a book it turned out to be! I lost myself in the pages, picturing myself along with Claire and Jamie in old Scotland. It is packed with adventure, aingst, romance, history, herbology, medicine, and sensual scenes. This is not just another romance novel. It has such depth, humor, and plot twists, you will be captivated. The language and descriptions are fantastic. If you want to escape into another world, dash through the ancient stone circle with Claire and find passion.

As an avid reader of romance novels (over 500), I have to say that Outlander is by far the best novel I have ever read.  In many of the books I have read, the authors do not reach the same level of detail as Diana Gabaldon does.  I am always in constant search of a "great read" and found it in the Outlander series.  I have read all four books in the series several times now and each time it's like reading a new book.  The storyline is captivating and believable and the characters are very real.  I love that the book contains romance, mystery, politics, sex, danger, and adventure.  I've cried, laughed, been horrified and amazed by the characters and their actions.  I highly recommend the Outlander Series to everyone!  I am eagerly anticipating the next book!!!

Like many others, I was initially absorbed by this book. Sure, the time-travel theme is hokey and hackneyed, but I love history and am particularly fascinated by Scotland. I was able to overlook the heroine's all-too-easy adjustment to 18th-century life (poor Frank!), and even the "forced" marriage to James Fraser and "forced" consummation thereof--what a perfect excuse for adultery without responsibility!However, like many others, I was shocked and appalled at Fraser's vicious beating of the heroine. Though this may be one of the more historically authentic parts of the story, it seemed totally out of character for the hero as Gabaldon had developed him thus far. To make matters worse, he confesses that the beating aroused him sexually. Danger, Claire Randall! And her reaction is even more troubling. She is initially more peeved than outraged and "forgives" him all too easily, even professing to understand why he "had" to beat her. Pernicious attitudes, indeed. And there is more--much, much more--brutal violence intertwined with sexual arousal before this book wheezes to a close...

What the heck did I just read? This book was so boring. All of the "exciting" plot in the description, well that's as much plot as there is in the books too. The rest is multi-page descriptions of the rippling in the water created by trout. Are you here for character development? Out of luck. The protagonist starts out kind of ballsy and becomes shrill and one-note. Is she curious about how she travelled in time? Not really. Is she having any interesting dilemmas adjusting to the new environment? Not really. The romantic interest meanwhile starts out as the most annoying puppy dog of a character ever committed to page. He might as well not have a brain or tongue because his only use seems to be taking beatings for other people. And the only thing said about him is that he's handsome. Well it's a book, so that doesn't help me much. He then somehow turns into a dude completely willing to beat and rape the wife he's supposed to be madly in love with. And that my friend brings me to the last point. How is this relationship romantic? Girlfriend has an adoring, handsome British SPY husband at home. I don't care about the cheating like some reviewers, Jamie's hot and her husband won't be born for 200 years. But girl, pull it together, you do not fall in love with the 23 year old virgin meathead who beats you with a belt. Don't do it. Run away. Run, Claire, run. But then her inner monologue is so tediously boring that maybe they're meant for each other.

A bookstore employee suggested Outlander to me.  3&1/2 weeks later I had finished all four books and purchased the Companion. (I do work full-time and have two children under the age of four!)  I visit the Diana  Gabaldon Home Page for previews of the next two books.  My friends and I  discuss the characters and history so well developed in these novels.  Reading this series is an EXPERIENCE, not just a casual passtime! If for  some reason you don't like this book, please give it to someone else to  enjoy!  Gabaldon is a terrific writer, so these books are much MORE than  romance.  They are stories of the times in which these characters  live...adventure, history and many, many questions.  Lots of genuine  surprises, too!  Bon voyage!

I purchased this because I had heard about the popularity of the series and wanted to see what it was about.  I did not realize I was purchasing a "bodice-ripper"  (have never read one before but there was plenty of ripping in this book).  The historical background led me to look up some of it on the Web as I had forgotten, or never knew, what was going on in Scotland in the 18th century.  Although I got caught up in the story, almost against my better judgment, it was dismaying to look down at my Kindle and see that I still had "9 hours" or whatever left to read.  Unlike my reaction to books I love, I wanted this one to end.  Not believable time transport and too much pandering to idealized romanticism for my taste.

I bought the Kindle version after watching the first episode on Starz, which was great. I had to know what happened next. The problem with this book is whenever the storyline starts to falter, the author falls back on graphic descriptions of sex or torture or the two combined. I guess some people must enjoy reading this kind of stuff, but I'll be darned if I know why. I'd rather use my imagination and stick with the motives behind the characters' actions and the drama within the story. The time travel is an interesting element. If you like romantic fiction, it's worth reading, I guess. Frankly, I could do without the homoerotic masochism (or any masochism for that matter)  and probably won't bother with  the sequels.

I admit to being somewhat of a literary snob.  My shelves are lined with the likes of Philip Roth, Joyce Carol Oates, and Ian McEwan.  I generally avoid historical fiction, and I've never enjoyed romance or fantasy.  So why do I love Outlander so much?  I'm not exactly sure, but the book's combination of memorable characters, intelligent dialog, non-stop action, non-sappy romance, and historical detail is like a drug.  A very pleasant, very addicting drug.  Gabaldon's writing is always elegant, never fussy, and moves along at a quick pace.  After about 50 pages of this novel, I was absolutely hooked for the entire book, and that's saying a lot considering it's over 800 pages long (depending on which format you read).

Don't be sucked in by the gorgeous production values, breath taking locations and brilliant casting of the television series. I found this book to be unreadable. I've never been a fan of Romance novels- now I know why. Ugh. Stick with the show.

Well, I was in a down after reading 2 wonderful books from a French-Canadian autor (Marie Laberge, books:Gabrielle and Adélaïde). So, I went to the library and asked to have something to read, as good as Marie Laberge. So, they suggested me Outlander and all the others books from Diana Gabaldon. I started Outlander. It took me about 150 pages to enter inside the story and been totally addicted about Jamie and Claire. And about Scotland. After one mount, I read all the 4 books and I cant wait reading the 5th one. Diana Gabaldon is an autor with a lot of wisdom. I learned a lot inside her books. I especially liked the melting pot of romance, historical, magical side, erotism, clues, and the fact that we travel all around the world with that unique couple. And well, that Jamie is the man. I was a little bit sceptic when I got that suggestion. I looked at the book and was thinking that it was a kind of "Danielle Steel" story. But NO! So, if you have some doubts when you will see the book, dont keep those doubts. You will live a very, very special experience with Jamie and Claire. Enjoy your reading all.

The title for this review is not meant to be a pun but the book became so pornographic with ridiculous, laughable, over the top sexual encounters every few pages that it became tedious. The violence was over done and repetitive. You  begin to think Jaime is a masochist. I liked the premise of the book and it had possibilities. I would have liked more historical references to everyday life, more believable characters, and 200 pages of violence and sex edited out. Then you would have had a good read. I ended up plodding through the entire book but will not read any sequels. Ridiculous!

No, Outlander by Diana Gabaldon is not strictly a romance book; but it  should be the standard by which romantic fiction is written.  No more-ho  hum, I know where this is going reading.  I was not prepared to have things  in the plot not go as I expected and it took me a little while to trust the  author and her vision for this book.  That's exciting reading.  Full of  history, fantasy, humor, violence, romance; whatever your tastes-this book  was a great read.  Be sure not to miss Dragonfly In Amber, Voyager and  Drums Of Autumn; the rest of the books so far in this series.

I was really enjoying this book and falling in love with Jamie until about halfway in. He holds Claire down and beats her with a belt "within an inch of her life". He told her he enjoyed beating her. He laughed at her. She forgives him?! Then he attempts to rape her. She stands up to him and he stops. She consents to sex with him but midway tells him to stop because it's hurting her. He refuses at which point it becomes rape. I haven't read another word of it since. I googled up feminist reviews of the book and apparently it gets worse. Their constant fighting isn't "passion", it's domestic violence and spousal abuse. If the author can be historically inaccurate regarding witch trials, and even write that the Loch Ness monster is a dinosaur that really existed (Claire has a moment with it!), then she can reimagine a man in that era who doesn't enjoy beating and raping his wife. Read the Earth's Children series instead for a historical romance with consensual sex and no violence between lovers (book 2 onwards). Better sex scenes in EC too.

I love the book Outlander and did not know that this was the same book.  I wish it would have been stated somewhere in the offer so that I could have saved myself some money.  It is rather annoying.  I was hoping to find another book by Ms. Gabaldon in the same genre of the Outlander series and by the cover I thought this was one.  However, I am still on the lookout for yet another book in the Outlander series as there were some things not yet explained and a few loose ends so I remain ever hopeful that we haven't seen the last of Jamie and Claire Fraser.

The story of Claire and Jamie--and yes, even Frank--is a triumph of writing by a highly educated author.  Gabaldon writes with an easy directness, yet occasionally uses words that send even me--a teacher of history and English and an avid lifelong reader--scurrying for a dictionary.  I love that she can surprise and inform me, while totally capturing me in the story.  The characterization is sublime; even supporting characters are interesting, and I find myself caught up in emotions--love, frustration, fear, hope--felt by the people in the story.  The setting of Outlander evokes mid-1700s Scotland with awesome and continually interesting scope.  The reader sees Claire's life there, and it is never boring.  This is a book that could have gone on much longer than its considerable length...and, thankfully, did, in subsequent books.  Each book in the series can stand on its own, but, obviously, the thrill is to tie everything together.  It's beautiful, intelligent and totally enthralling writing, and I, for one, wish it could go on forever.

Outlander and the other three published books in this series (Dragonfly in Amber, Voyager and Drums of Autumn) are simply the BEST books I've ever read! They have it all; wonderful characters (both good and bad),  intriguing plot lines, breathless romance and in depth history. I couldn't  put any of them down when I read them in Nov/Dec 1998 and now I'm making my  way through the unabridged recordings. I am anxiously awaiting Book 5 of  the series. I highly recommend this series to anyone who wants a fabulous  read! You won't be disappointed.

I bought this book when it first came out in hardcover in 1991.  I still have that first edition, autographed by the author.  I also have two lending copies in paperback, and am about to buy the Kindle version, just so I can have it with me all the time.  I also have the UK version, titled CROSS-STITCH.  If you haven't read this book, I envy you being able to read it for the first time!  Jamie and Claire will make you laugh and cry.  This is a great romance and a great adventure.  And you'll learn some Scottish history while you're at it.

Reading the Outlander book before listening to the tape was my mistake.  I  loved the book...couldn't put it down.  The best thing about the audio  version was hearing the words with the lovely scotish accent.  There was so  much left out of the audio that was so wonderful in the book that I found  myself waiting to hear stories, family arguments, love scenes, and  characters that were left out all together.  If there is ever an unabridged  version I would recommend it 100%, but spend your money on the book not the  abridged tape.

Diana sure can put you right in the picture, her writing is so intricate and entwining.  Every word has some connection or meaning that needs to be paid attention to in the next book (or even the next chapter for that  matter).  I could see every step that Jamie and Clair took, every place  that they were in and the poeple they met!  I simply love Diana's writing.  I will probably never get to Scotland in person, but thanks to this  series, I have been there and saw it trough the eyes of Jamie and Clair!
Silliest thing I ever tried to read. Made it halfway through, couldn't take it anymore.

Bodice ripper and transparently obvious throughout. The heroine is shallow and sex appears to be the main reason to read each chapter as there is nothing else going on.  Each place she runs to the characters all seem like cardboard cutouts or backdrops for her to get predictably in a mess then dramatically rescued so she can have wanton sex again with cardboard Scottish laird outlaw lover boy. If it were possible to give a minus 5 ⭐ rating I would pick that. A waste of reading time.

Seriously lame. Someone from the modern world is 1. not affected by the viruses/diseases of that time 2. doesn't yearn for hot water and plumbing 3. doesn't succumb to hideous diseases. HONESTLY I kept thinking they will now make a plan for her to get back to her world. True love can never duplicate hygiene and hot water.  The beginning is awesome and now its just simply a silly love story. Also the guy he must have really bad teeth...I dont know. just not practical

There is no book that comes to mind as a favorite I have read than the Outlander and its three continuances, Dragonfly in Amber, The Voyager, and The Drums of Autumn. Diana Gabaldon weaves such a story so rich in details of Historical Scotland that you are literally there with Claire Randall and Jamie Fraser. I feel like I have spent part of my life with them after reading these books written by a woman who can tell a tale like no other. A fantastic read from beginning to end, and you will wish it would never end....Diana Gabaldon truly brings these characters to life. I found myself laughing outloud in some points in these books and crying sadly for Claire and Jamie in others. I have read and re read the Outlander to the point that the pages are falling out of the book. The Outlander is one to add to your library collection of books!

I have read tons of books, romances in general and Scottish romances in paticular, and no book/author can compete with this one. This story is the most amazing story I have ever read. Until I picked up a Gabaldon, I tended to read Garwood, McNaught, Moning, Cole... and the list goes on and on and on. Once you get into it, you won't sleep, you won't eat, you will just read and read. The first couple hundred pages are good, the last 5 or 600 pages and amazing.

This is one of the best romance novels I have ever read.  Nothing I have read since quite measures up. If you like non-cheesy romances and historical fiction, then you will love this book. The characters are so well delveloped and the historical accounts taught me quite a bit about scottish history.  I fell in love with Jamie just as Claire did.  I finished the last in the series this summer and still miss him.  Diana Gabaldon is truly a talented writer!

I won't go into the plot of this book, but I will say I loved it!  I started reading this book while on holiday and I just couldn't put it down.  It is not your typical action/adventure, sci-fi, or romance story.  It is difficult to put it into a category.  For those who are skeptical about the time travel aspect, don't be.  It is very well written and so easy to get lost in.  I will warn that it is graphic in places.  All in all a fantastic read!

Be prepared for detailed violence, sodomy,  and cruelty.  I read romance novels because they don't contain these things.  Yes, this is a well written romance novel.  I enjoy the characters and the history, but it can be exhausting to get through all of the struggles these characters go through.  I'm surprised that there weren't specific warnings about this book.  Movies would have warnings about what's contained in them, and books don't have that, so if you have a tougher stomach than I do, and you like these people going through nightmare, after cruelty, after nightmare, then, okay, you'll like this book and the sequels.  I have to take a break from them, and not read every page in some sections, but there is something compelling in these characters that isn't in the regular romance novel.

I have loved Diana Gabaldon books. I have read them all over and over. I would say above all books I have ever read her books I love the best. Often times I find when I am bored or driving in the car my mind takes me back to a scene in one of her books. I am an avid reader and have bookshelves upon bookshelves of books. but this book along with the others in the series are my very favorite. Read them you will not regret it!!!

I must admit that it took me a little while to get interested in this book. Not being much of a romance or history enthusiast. However, once engrossed in this book I was unable to put it down. A truly amazing story with just the right mix of romance, suspense and yes, sex and violence or violent sex for that matter. The characters captured my heart and I found myself thinking about them even after I finished the book and VERY few books have that effect on me.(and I read ALOT of books) I thought the characters are beautifully developed and you can't help getting caught up in the story. I couldn't wait to get my hands on Dragonfly in Amber (the next book in the series)which again is starting out a little slow but I have faith that it will not disappoint. As for some of the other reviews complaining that the book was filled with abhorrent violence and rape, yes it is graphic but it was recommended to me by my 70+ year old grandmother. All I can say to them is loosen up a little! I have never understood why someone would suffer through a book they don't enjoy only to complain about it afterwards. Put it down and walk away. Outlander was my first Diana Gabaldon read and I must say I was impressed!

I will make this simple buy the book and start reading I swear you will not want to put it down. I have my mother in law to thank for introducing me to the series. I am in love with the books and now have convinced my very macho husband to read them. The Author is very convincing and I swear it is like you are there with them through it all. I can't wait for the next one.

Get the audio version if you have any drive time at all.  I read and listen to books; this series is excellent if not the best I have heard on audio.  I can't say enough about Davina Porter's reading of this series.  Each of the characters are alive and distinct.  It is really a performance. You will not be able to get Jamie and Claire out of your head.

This book is my caliber of which all other books are judged. It has everything--excellent writing, historical accuracy, humor..I could go on. The main reason to read it is this--A damn good book! And I love these characters. Do yourself a favor, pick up this book and you wont be able to put it down! And the other books in the series are just as great.
This is the first book in a fabulous series of incredible books.  I want to start over and read them all again as soon as I get the last one which is not out yet.

I tend to be skeptical of romance novels, but this one was recommended to me by several different people so I decided to check it out.  It was worth it!  I was a little wary of the plot at first too thinking that the time-travel aspect of it was rather cliché but I absolutely fell in love with all of the characters so much so that the plot didn't seem as important.  I have since read all 5 books in the series because I would follow these characters anywhere.  Plus, Gabaldon writes beautifully with a rich sense of humor.  I'd definitely recommend this book to anyone, romance and non-romance readers alike.

boring foreign Scottish rhetoric thruout excitng only intermittently.it is a lo ve story with graphic insight. I get it that they love each other, but where is the rest be of the story that gets very little play. boring pages and pages of description like a travelogue Hard to get thru this book. The tv adaption is not much better  SC

Because I am not a fan of true romances, the sex scenes turned me off with their detail. I loved the transfer from one time in history to another though, and the love story too; just too much detail for mew to continue reading the series. Maybe better for the younger set or for those without enough love in their life maybe?

It is entertaining enough to read the whole book but the author relies too much on sex for content.  The characters are always in some crazy situation but always get out of it and there are too many situations where the author uses sexual violence for drama.  I don't think I would read any other books Gabaldon has written.

The premise is fun, and the main characters memorable. Overall, however, the novel tends to drag on and on. I found myself wishing for tighter writing, and ended up eventually skimming through some sections while trying to find the next genuine plot or character development. This book could benefit from a better editor.

I love historical romance and this is the best I've ever read. You'll want to travel to Scotland after reading this book, I guarantee it. The story of Jaimie, the Scottish highlander of the 1700s, and Claire, the nurse who accidently travels back in time from the 1940s, is unforgetable. One of my favorite books ever.

Does everyone think this book is that good?? I heard raves from a coworker and raves from two relatives. Then it got made into a TV series. I don't watch TV, but the fact that it was converted into a TV series finally pushed me over the edge and I just finished the first book. I am highly unlikely to read any more in the series. Claire frustrates me. She apparently had this great marriage before she went through the standing stones, but doesn't even TRY to go back to her time when she obviously has the chance. Doesn't try? Weird. She seems very content with the filthy 18th century and rarely even bathes, herself. She seems enamored with a stinky Scot. Does she like filthy-smelling people? Why not try to introduce some modest improvements in personal hygiene? As for the stinky Scot, he's just not my kind of guy. The number of times and ways he gets himself beaten up is impossible. The only way he could survive all that is in a kid's video game, but somehow Gabaldon always resurrects him from near death. And, sure, all 1940s nurses knew how to set fingerbones, right? Easy peasy. I enjoy steamy sex scenes, but the ones in this book were lurid without being particularly exciting for me. For example, I didn't particularly enjoy or appreciate the intimate descriptions of pregnancy by Jamie's sister. And was there a point in the long description? I didn't quite see the relationship to the plot. I read through to the end because the concept of having a modern person travel back to another time period was intriguing, and I wanted to see what would happen next. But so LITTLE actually happened in this book (other than a sort of episodic traipsing through 18h century Scotland) that I won't be reading any of the other books in the series. It was OK. But I was tired of it before it was over. And when Claire got pregnant at the end, I just rolled my eyes. Please.

The Gabaldon series is by far the best I have ever read.  I was completely enthralled and found it impossible to put down.  I picked up Dragonfly In Amber first at a discount department store thinking it would be pretty much like most other romance novels(I read at least one a week).  Boy was I wrong!!! I got a third of the way thru when I relized there was a prequel. I then put it down (which was very difficult) untill I found Outlander and was fortunate enough to find all three other books at the same time.  Not only have I thoroughly and completely enjoyed the series as just a damn good read, I am also amazed at how it was written . It's almost as if each book is written from a different perspective, thus adding to the intrigue of the story.  Also, no "insignificant, minute" detail can be ignored because it surprizingly show up and connect to a very significant event later in that book or a following book and completely blow you away at the cleverness of this writer.  Yes, as with every other female who has become aquainted with Jamie Frazer, I am nursing a mad crush.  Who wouldn't be?  This is perfect, non-perfect character I have ever met in liturature. I am fortunate because I am married to "Jamie-like" man.  Not in looks but in character. And I'm really getting a bit peved at everyone targetting Claire as being selfish.  Get off her case.  The woman had just lived thru a war.  Not to mention that her upbringing was not exactly middle class suburbia.  There was no need to "develope" her character any further.  If you just read between the lines it's all there. You've got a lot of fans sitting on pins and needles. Thank You for such a wonderful gift and talen. GBroussard END
whoever is trying to sell these books on cd for 225.00 is out of there mind.  the list price is less than 75.00.  someone is trying to rip people off.

There was a time when I wouldn't have been caught dead in the Romance aisle at my local bookstore. I have to admit to being somewhat of a book snob - reading strictly "literary" fiction and looking down my nose at people who read what I would call "fluff". No more. I picked up Outlander grudgingly after hearing everyone in my reading group continually rave about it. These are intelligent women whose opinions I truly value. Am I ever glad I listened to them. I can't remember the last time I had such fun reading a book! Since finishing, I have made 3 more trips back to the Romance aisle (with my head held high) to buy the next three books in the series. Even if you don't think Outlander sounds like your "type" of book, give it try. You might be pleasantly surprised - I was.

I thought there was something wrong with me and my inability to actually FINISH this novel.  I'd pick it up every once in awhile, read a few chapters and then unceremoniously dump it back into the pile of unread 'stuff' I have laying about.  After coming here and reading other one star reviews, I now know I am not crazy.  This novel is bland tripe.  Claire and Jamie are the most uninteresting and idiotic characters.  The story drags and there doesn't seem to be any point.  Claire has no redemming qualities--I could never 'get into' her persona.  I now feel ok with letting this book fade away into my distant memory.  I no longer feel bad about aborting.  Abandon ship!
Interesting to read and watch simultaneously.

I'm an avid reader and love books with a strong female lead.  A friend of mine recommended this book and it was on my amazon recommendations so I went ahead and bought it.  It was OK but I will not read it again.  Super boring.  I couldn't wait until it was over.

Couldn't put this book down?  I couldn't force myself to finish it!  Both the hero and heroine in this novel are thoroughly deplorable characters and  if the author wants to indulge her own personal masochistic and rape  fantasies, that's her business, but physical abuse and sexual assault are  not behaviors I look for in a fictional hero.  The heroine, too, lets the  reader down in her total lack of understanding of the terms commitment and  fidelity (cheating on her husband in quick order when a younger, sexier man  comes along).  Any woman with a shred of self-respect and dignity should be  appalled that a modern woman could write a story approving of a man beating  his wife, as though that were acceptable behavior and that we, as readers,  should be pining that such a man isn't in our own lives! It was a truly  sickening experience.  It isn't enough that the sex scenes are so very  graphic that the book is inapproprite for teenage readers, but the equating  of abusive behavior with manliness is truly alarming. I know it's not a  message I would want my daughter to be hearing.  In this day and age, all I  can say is shame on everyone involved--the writer, editor, publisher,...

I don't understand how people can view this book as anything more than a trashy romance novel. And not even a good one. You can't help but laugh when you read things like, "Ride ye I will." I am not a prude. I've read my share of trashy novels. But as far as I could tell, the only thing these two people have in common is sex. There is nothing about this that qualifies this as "fantasy" other than the one time traveling episode. The heroine is not particularly engaging or sympathetic. The hero is basically a savage warrior but with the sensitivity of a 21st century male. And to top it all off, I found it kind of homophobic. Why are the two gay characters in the book portrayed as rapists pushing themselves on unwilling men? The author has no ear for the Scottish dialect ... and it's irritating. Hated this book.

There is nothing wrong with romance novels, if that's what you like.  But be warned, guys:  this book would fit right in with those pulp paperbacks featuring covers with muscular half-naked men saving sexy damsels in distress.  The author clearly has a taste for sexual violence, and perhaps even a fetish for rape.  The heroine suffers attempted rape no fewer than three times, and is rescued each time by the hunky Scott.  Yea!  Also, she gets her clothes ripped off by an angry mob.  Don't worry, the hunky Scott saves her again.  Hmm.  But what bothers me the most is the wasted opportunities for our intrepid time traveler. Thrown back in time 200 years, does the heroine bother to revolutionize medicine? Nope. Invent the steam engine?  Nope. Build repeating rifles?  Nope. She spends 99% of her time wandering about the Scottish countryside having sex with her squeeze and avoiding rape, barely.  How many attempted rapes does it take before she realizes it's dangerous out there?  Don't ask.  She is way too busy talking about Love.  Love, love, love.  Not that there is anything wrong with that.  Sigh. I should have gotten a clue when she spent two pages describing the buttons on her wedding gown.

When I see woman cooing over the Vampires in the newest Twilight book, I absolutely want to tell them that Twilight is childs play.  Diana will make you believe that time travel exists, and a love so strong that it knows no time barrier.

After the vicious beating of Claire by the "hero" Jamie, I could not pick up this book again. Good thing I stopped reading -- the reviews here suggest it only gets worse.  Like other readers, I was willing to overlook the silly premise and less-than-stellar writing for a good historical love story.  Unfortunately, endless descriptions of torture and sexual violence do not a love story make. Yuck -- after you finish this book, you'll need to find some real literature to get this awful story out of your head.

I was immediately pulled in to the story as an adventure, mystery, fantasy. But somewhere in the middle it turned into a harlequin romance bodice ripper. Too bad. Wish there was a bit more story and a lot less touchy feely.

Be prepared to read the entire series, if you love romance.  Diana Gabaldon breathes life into Jamie and Claire and you can't leave them on the shelf.  Jump in, the water is fine.  Join millions of other women from around the world who follow the love and adventures of two special characters. This is the first book of the series and it shouldn't be missed.

Glad I didn't pay full price for this book! After all the rave five star reviews I thought it would be great. It could have been if the main characters were likeable people. Jaime started out as someone loveable and sweet,then he shows a sickening side with a pension for abuse. He describes how his father beat him mercilessly for small offenses he committed as a young boy like it's a fond memory. When Claire asks if he would do that to a child of theirs he assures her he would. Claire does not come off as someone loveable either. She's mostly just all business and a cold and clinical nurse who relies on her training to see her through all the situations they find themselves in. Every once in awhile she breaks down and sobs, guess that's meant to show she has emotions. For a love story this couple fall flat, I felt nothing but sex existed between them. Then there's the uncalled for and vile descriptive rape of Jaime. Why? It added nothing to the story line other than another instance of Claire showing up somewhere and making a perilous situation for Jaime even worst. She did this at several different points in the story. Half this book could have been left out. I can only imagine most five star reviews are for the endless sex scenes in this book.

Could I give 10 stars!?!? LOL I work at a library and happened to come across this book on day at work, and so I immediatly come on here to read some reviews and I asked around amongst my coworkers. Most of the reviews were pretty good so I delved in, and was instantly hooked. I absolutly adore this book, it completed consumed me for the few days it took me to get through, I was reading at redlights and coming to work dead tired cause I could not put this book down the night before! Ms. Gaboldon is a fabulous writer, and I could close my eyes and see the Scottish Highlands and almost smell how the air would smell there. The exchanges between Jamie and Claire are in turns hilarious, fun, tender, passionate, and brutal. I laughed and cried and was overjoyed. I found myself wishing I could touch a stone and be transported back in time to what must be a beautiful country, and a sexy, compassionate, wonderful Jamie Fraser! It's a wonderful mix of romance, fantasy, history, mystery, and it's definatly now one of my favorite books of all time, reccommended to anyone, no matter what genre you usually read. I'm a few chapter into the sequal, Dragonfly in Amber, and cannot wait to see what happens to Jamie and Claire!

I just finished reading this book for the second time (about four years in-between) and I found myself swooning just as easily the second time as I did the first. I was amazed how much I had forgotten, even though I had been hanging every word the first time. I kept saying to myself, wow, I don't remember that had happened. If you have read this series, give it a few years and read it all over again. I work in a bookstore so I recommend it to as many ladies as I possibly can, and I am overjoyed when I see familiar faces return to purchase the next book. I have never read anything like this in my life. The books are so incredibly romantic, that I truly believe the love between Claire and Jamie surpasses that of Romeo and Juliet. Shakespeare has nothing on Gabaldon. The characters are real, as if you have known them all your life, the scenery so perfectly described you can smell, hear and see everything. The stories are non stop action packed, with the most romantic and sometimes raunchy sex scenes you'll ever read. I can't recommend this series enough. I believe every woman out there should read the Outlander series. They won't disappoint, not even fifty years from now after I read them another dozen times.

I mean it.  Changed my life.  I've always loved reading, since I was a little girl, but this book made me look at books in a whole new way.  And not just this book alone -- the whole Outlander series.  Yes, some books within the series are better than others, but overall it is an amazing tour-de-force that Ms. Gabaldon has given us.  She is truly a gifted storyteller.  And can I just say, an OUTSTANDING researcher???  These novels, although technically fantasy because of the time travel element, are really more historical fiction than anything else.  She shows us Scotland in the 1940s, as well as the 1740s and then (throughout the series), we are shown England, France, crossing the ocean on a ship, the Caribbean, the colonies, North Carolina, etc., etc., etc!  So, not only did she have to thoroughly research her initial destination of Scotland (and all the history of wars, clans, traditions, etc.), but she had to do that same amount of research for ALL those locations I listed.  The woman is amazing.  How does she even find time to do all that??  I would (obviously) highly recommend this entire series to anyone who likes anything.  This series has things that will appeal to EVERYONE.
The characters are rich and carefully crafted. The author creates solid history for her primary characters and remains faithful to their development.  I am completely enchanted with Claire and Jamie!

I was pretty horrified to find out this book was being made into a movie. I first read this book only because I have long been interested in Scottish history and Scottish historical novels. Big mistake. This book is sick and I honestly wonder about the kind of people who enjoyed reading it and are giving it 5 stars. Um, hello? There is S&M; in the book, plenty of rape, along with over-the-top violence, and the main character of the novel, Jamie, beats his wife. Although I realize this part was somewhat true to the time period, Jamie is portrayed as the romantic hero by the author. Um, I don't think so. My question for those of you who enjoyed this book: WHY? Seriously, what do you see it this book? Its fairly disgusting. For those who haven't read it yet, don't bother. After this book, I never again wanted to read anything by Diana Gabaldon. S&M; is just not my thing.

Based on the rave reviews, I expected more than your standard bodice-ripper fare. I was disappointed. Characters and story were just OK; wild sex every 15 pages became laughable. Barely managed to finish it and rather regret wasting my time with it. Will certainly be able to resist reading any more by this  author.

This is one of my most favorite books of all time.  I think this is about my fourth reading and each time I pick up additional details I missed on a prior reading. I don't have Starz on my cable TV and wanted to be able to share the story with my fellow workers who do and are raving about the series.  Claire Randall and her husband Frank are on a second honeymoon, in Scotland, after World War II when they were serving in different areas.  Claire  is interested in plants used for healing and journeys out one day to revisit a spot where she saw some interesting plants.  She goes to the top of the hill, gets too close to a stone formation and is thrown back about 200 years in history.  She gets rescued by a group of Scots, ends up marrying one of them and has many adventures.  I have read and re-read all of the books in the series and I never get tired of any one them.  I'm most anxious to continue reading the series and see what happens after the most recent installment "Written In My Own Heart's Blood".  Once you start the Outlander series, you're hooked.  Can't wait for the TV series to come out in DVD.

I was persuaded by the glowing reviews, but what a disappointment. Poor character development, boring story, this couple only passes from one action oriented and unbelievable situation to the next with a bit of sex and violence thrown in to juice things up. Do not waste your time if you like literary fiction, I struggled to finish. Like a B-movie.

**spoiler alert** This book has left me swimming in conflicted feelings. I really didn't like the book when I first started it and was cursing the entire historical fiction genre for boring me to death yet again! Then something magical happened and I was swooning over Jamie and loved the book so much I literally held it dearly in an embrace. The characters came alive and I was walking in Claire's shoes and experiencing the the Highlands of Scotland in medieval times (it was glorious.) Claire will remain one of my all time favorite heroines from here on out, but unfortunately I can only give this book 4 stars. After devouring several hundred pages things started to slow again and I found myself skimming for the good stuff (tender moments with my dear Jamie.) Then something horrible happened. Gabaldon took my brave manly hero and deflowered him. I'm sorry, but my knight in shinning armor doesn't ever get ass raped in my fantasies. What the hell was the author thinking? I would have given this book 5 stars if it were 300 pages shorter and the main heart throbbed didn't get buggered

I can't belive as I look over peoples reviews that a majority don't like books written in the first person. But then again most of the silly-soppy books are written in the first person so I can give some understanding.  This book however, stands apart from the rest, as you start reading it, you  will soon forget you are, and you'll feel part of the story (an important  one of-course).  It is possible, with next to no sleep and food in the  three days straight I was reading this unbelivable book, I really did start  to look the part!  Because it was written in first person it is great  because you don't feel like an onlooker as you get to see as Claire sees  and read all her thoughts.  And it will send you into hysterical fits of  laughter believe me! Well, Okay as you can tell I love the book!  I don't  think there is actually any other I have read that can compare to it or the  other books in the series!  So take my ramblings into account, and not the  size of the novel when you pass 'Outlander' in the book store, or here for  that matter!  It's a quality book worth reading!

Diana Gabaldon's Outlander series is amazing.  A friend recommended this book to me and I was skeptical--I mean time travel??  This would not be my favorite genre in the least, but the historical basis of the story drew me in.  I'm so glad it did.  Ms. Gabaldon made 18th century Scottish history come alive for me.  Her historical research was excellent and her ability to create fictional characters to meld with historical figures of the time was outstanding.  My family and I lived in Northern England for three years--making several trips to Scotland.  Scotland is an amazing place, but Ms. Gabaldon's story and the historical accuracy she maintained during the telling of her story made it that much more awe-inspiring.  If you continue reading the series (why would you not!??)you will continued to be impressed with the writing/imagination/research of the books.  If you ever make it to Scotland and hear the history of the country from tour guides and see the land described in the books, you'll find it hard to believe that Ms. Gabaldon didn't live in 18th century Scotland.

I have mixed feelings about Outlander. I read the book only becasue I watched the premiere of the cable show Outlander on Starz. The book at times is very boring and to descriptive. I like stories that set the scenes in a book, but this author goes way to far in her descriptions. She describes everything in detail. It caused me to loose the point at times. Outlander seems to have a lot of little stories that don't really connect with the main storyline. Like the Witch Trail. It did nothing for the story. As we all know Claire has been sent back in time to the Scottish Highlands where she meets and married Jamie Fraser. I understand her shock of finding herself in 1743 Scotland. However for a well traveled married women of 27 and a nurse in WWII she act very immature though out most of the story and gets herself and Jamie  and the Clans in lots of trouble. I loved Jamie from the beginning he was younger then Claire but he was what is referred to as a Alpha Male Warrior. He was so brave and so strong. What I didn't like was the author breaking his personality down by having him captured yet again by Black Jack Randall and sent to Wentworth Prison to be hanged . Jamie was tortured and raped by the sadistic Robert Randall, Claire's 6 times grandfather in law from her 19th century husband Frank Randall. Robert Randall and Frank Randall look exactly alike. Black Jack Randall as he is called is a sadist homosexual. Whose whole purpose in the story is to get to Jamie and rape and torture him. Jamie is captured several times in the story. This became quit disturbing to me. So much torture.  After Jamie has suffering so much over the past 4 years at the hands of Black Jack Randall and surviving he finally breaks in the final scene while in Wentworth Prison. Poor Jamie was sodomized whipped so many time the skin was removed from his back, Branded with Randal initials made to have oral sick with him, craw an beg for more. This is Sick!!  I don't like reading about rape weather it is a women or a man. I find authors that do this might have a fetish to be raped themselves.  The horrendous torture and beatings that Jamie withstood every time Black Jack Randall captured him should have been enough for any Sadistic storyline. I have bk2 Iwill try to read becasue I paid for it and I hate not to finish something. I want know how Jamie get on!! I am not sure at this point if I will read bk3 or the rest of the series. I might not watch the show on Starz either. It all hangs on bk 2 Dragonfly in Amber.

A co-worker at the bookstore I work at recommended Outlander to me. I read it and throughly  enjoyed it. The prose is lush, the characters are excellent and I love Claire's sense of self and strength. It's a good solid  read. It is however very violent in spots. BE WARNED: there is a very  contriversal scene in which Jamie, angered at the fact that Claire has  disobeyed him and in doing so threatened the llives of his clan, beats  her  violently.  She fights him back and it escelates into an all out brawl  between the two. Several interviews with Diana Gabaldon find her explaining  that scene, saying that it served to illustrate the character and time  differences between the two.  I can see her point (the idea that women  were not property in 18th century Scotland was radical at best) and can see  where Jamie and Claire would find themselves at an impasse. However, I  wondered if it wouldn't send a subtle message  to women that abuse is  "romantic" when seen in this lavish contest. Beating is still  beating if it happens in 18th century or in the 20th. Claire does tell him  that it's not like that in the 20th century and if he ever beats her again  she's "disembowel him with his sword". THAT I liked. True to  their understanding, he never does again.  After reading that scene I was  amazed at the fact that I repected Gabaldon as a writer because she deals  with an abusive situation, works through it and expells it. How many other  "romance" novels are there where the woman is abducted, raped and  abused by the man and then "surrenders her heart" or some other  nonsense? In those books, a romanticized abuse IS the plotline.  In this  scene, Gabaldon bravely and disturbingly presents a conceivable situation  between a man raised in the 18th century and a modern, liberated woman.  If you can swallow that scene, it IS an excellent story with some  wonderfully realistic and romantic scenes.  Love it or hate it, you won't  remain untouched by Outlander.

I can not believe how many good reviews this book has received here.  How can you like a book where the "hero"'s clan recommends that James *beat* Claire for not obeying him and leading them into danger at one point - - which he does - - and then she agrees, weepily, that it was "good for her"?  This is not a "love absolute," it is ABUSE, and Gabaldon is morally irresponsible for promoting it in any way.

This series of books is wonderful!  I started with this first book, "Outlander", and continued to read every following book until the end. Diana Gabaldon's writing is superb. Her attention to detail and gift of story telling has kept me thoroughly entertained over several months. The characters in the books have become my friends.  I was sorry to read the last page of the final and 8th book, but was left completely satisfied.  The relationships between the characters are what make these books so rich - especially the magical relationship between Claire & Jamie.  I used to read books like this & have thoughts like "I wish I had a relationship like that..." But this time I didn't because I've read other amazing books that have made my relationship with my husband just as sweet, loving & sexy as Claire & Jamie's. Check out Ariel & Shya Kane's books, "How to Have A Match Made in Heaven" and "How to Create a Magical Relationship". It's a possibility for all of us! Enjoy Diana Gabaldon's Outlander series!  It's delicious reading.
Although the subject and concept were interesting, it was a bit too focused on the sex and way too descriptive.  Turned into a trashy novel in my opinion... And I'm no prude.

I first read Outlander as a library director, after purchasing it for our collection. I was looking for good reads for our book discussion group. With Outlander I got more than I bargained for.  I have just finished re-reading the Kindle edition of Outlander while on my third trip to Scotland, where I traveled with other fans of the Outlander series to find the places and events Diana Gabaldon wrote about with such passionate, picturesque language.  I found that Diana had thoroughly researched the history of the Jacobite revolution, the customs, dress, language and most of all, the people of the Highlands of Scotland. I have since recommended this series as 'romance, adventure, science fiction, military fiction, and historical fiction,' packaged in one of the best reads I've ever experienced.  The story held my attention from beginning to end, and in the rest of the series Diana continued to hold my attention. I would never have visited Scotland without Outlander, and I would have missed so much!

I can't believe this is such a popular series. I bought this book based on a recommendation from someone that the series is better than Game of Thrones. That couldn't be further from the truth! It's a chick book to end all chick books. The plot line is thin and unbelievable, and it's a rare chapter without a love scene. Majorly corny! There are times when you wish George R. R. Martin would intervene and kill the main character.

I had never heard of Diana Gabaldon until about 2 months ago.  My hairstylist recommended reading Outlander.  She said....don't give up on it.  Its hard to follow at first, but she said keep with it and you'll love it.  For me, it was at page 200 that I couldn't put it down.  I had the next 2 delivered to my library just so I wouldn't have to wait for a time lapse in between.  Its been about 3 weeks now, and I'm on book 5 out of 7.  Going to the library to pick up the last 2 tomorrow...but I can tell you that by far, the best book (s) I have read in my life!  If you like historical books or period books with some romance thrown in, this is for you!  I have found myself going past the book and reading up on the history of the places, towns, etc. in the books.  Much infatuated now, I am ready to move to Scotland!  Definitely recommend the series of books!  Have to read them in order....wouldn't make much sense otherwise.  They are long...some parts are not as good as others...but its a journey!

I started reading the Outlander series when it was first released in 1991 and from the first page I was immersed in this great time travel story. Granted the books in the series are huge but the writing is such that the length of the book passes into insignificance as the pages turn. What could be better in a novel than standing stones, castles and men in kilts?? Once Claire is transported back to 1700's England/Scotland she finds herself in a world that she knew from the history books and she is in for the ride of her life.. this book is full of romance, mystery, history of Scotland, lots of engaging characters in the past and present of the book. There is violence and sexual situations also that contribute to the story. Once you start reading this series you will not want to stop and you will never want the story of Jamie and Clair to end... but the good news is that this is only the first in this series so you will be able to read about the love between Jamie and Claire for a long time...

I have to say, this was a book I will read over and over again. I am not a fan of romance and in fact, have stayed as far away as possible. (I'm more of a science fiction/fiction/mystery gal) But when my friend told me I had to read this book, I ran out and bought it.  It's packed full of adventure, history and if you can manage to get through the very wordy sexual scenes, then you're good to go.  Even though it, in a lot of ways, fits the typical romance story, there's something about the book that just draws me in. I have to give the credit to the talent of DG. Her characters come alive, and I found myself holding my breath as I was reading, practical screaming out loud for Jamie and Claire!  After finishing the first book, I ran out and bought the other three. My only disappointment; she has yet to finish Firey Cross (Hurry, hurry!) I really haven't run across anything else comparable, (although Janet Evanovich's Stephine Plum comes a close second) This is one book you can't pass up.

It took me forever to finish this book.  I am the type of person who finishes every book I start, no matter what.  I am not sure how long it would take if you tried to read this book in one sitting (the audio book says it is over 30 hours), but either way it's about 10 hours too long.  For the length of this book, there is really no action.  I like sex as much as the next person and like it in the books I read, but come on; there seemed to be so much sex between the two main characters that was so out of context that it was borderline ridiculous.  I loved the concept of the book..."time travel" during a period when it would have been technologically impossible.  I realize even today it is not possible, but having time travel when TV's were not even invented yet was an excellent idea.  Especially since there was no equipment involved.  Even though I gave it two stars, I am going to read the next one because I love the premise.  I can see why people would love this book, just not me!

I just discovered the outlander series two months ago and now can't imagine how I ever did without it. Diana Gabaldon simply has the most wonderful imagination. Putting the book down is nearly impossible. You are constantly left wondering what will happen next. Jamie and Claire are the most memorable characters ever made up. I am swept away with emotions right along with them through every adventure. There have been times when I have been so angry with Jamie I wanted to beat my own husband.I understand where the two star lady is coming from, but I think she missed the point. Jamie is doing what he thinks is right according to his times. Claire is extremely upset and indignant over the whipping but she knows she is living in a different world and can't fault him too much for his ignorance. Not to mention the fact that Claire herself is from the 1940's not from modern day so her perspective on the matter would not be quite the same as a woman today.

Diana Gabaldon is truly a gifted writer, and I feel she doesn't get enough publicity.  As others have written, her first book, "Outlander", was definitely the best of the four in the series so far.  However I have  to say that I thoroughly enjoyed all four books with an incredibly strong  hunger for reading that was new to me.  And if you think it is just because  I am a romance buff, you're wrong!  My husband wasn't interested until I  started reading "Outlander" to him before going to bed at night.  Now he hurries me to bed every night to read the next chapter!  Diana  really makes you see, hear, feel, smell and taste everything Claire  experiences in the story.  You really feel like you are part of the story,  rather than just an observer.  I am very eagerly awaiting the release of  her next book in the series.  If you liked the movie  "Braveheart", you'll absolutely love the "Outlander"  series.

I bought this book to replace the original one I had in hard cover that I loaned out that never made it back to me.  The Outlander series has been one of the best adventures in reading that I have ever had.  I love these books, and anxiously await the appearance of the newest installment on the market.  I have read them all and relished them.  They are long, full of history and the characters capture your attention and hold it, so you want to know what happens to them.  I just bought the newest installment, "An Echo in the Bone", and look forward to burying myself in that world again, and seeing where life takes Jamie and Claire to the back drop of the American Revolution.  I highly recommend this series, and all of the books in it to anyone who loves historical sagas and settling in for a retreat to another time and place, to take you away from the present, on an adventure in which you can't help but get wrapped up and swept away.

With over 5,000 reviews, there is no need for me to recount the plot or characters of OUTLANDER here.  Suffice it to say that, although I read hundreds of books a year, and have read thousands in my life thus far, there is no book that compares to Outlander.  Composed of absolutely riveting, fully round characters that you can almost hear breathing in the pages, and parts romance, historical fiction, sci fi, and adventure, Outlander is simply one of those rarely seen metaphysical oddities that is so much more than the sum of its parts...it is pure magic.  As a lit teacher and librarian, I have never quite met its equal...construction, research, literature, intellect, human condition, emotion....perhaps it is that no other book does all of these aspects so fully and so perfectly balanced together.  Outlander simply touches the heart, the mind, and the soul; mine bear a permanent mark.  How else can one explain magic?

I was with my Mom during the last three months of her life, holding her hand as she died, and was so very sad.  I walked into the San Francisco Main Public Library and thought," For God's sake and for my own sake,  would one of you books shout out to me and take my mind off this terrible  grief, even for a little while."  I walked over to the shelf and found  all four books in this series and checked them out.  Since my family is  half Scottish, I felt that I had gone home and visited with all the lovely  people in my family, long gone,I never thought I'd meet.  Sometimes a  person needs to just get away for a while to heal, and this humdinger of a  story is just what I needed to do that.  Hello to all the other people who  have written reviews of this series.  I wish I knew you.  I seem to be  needing some kindred spirits right about now.  Maybe you can wave to me in  your mind's eye.  Cheers!!

The author has a lovely style with rich metaphors and charming dialogue though I have no knowledge of the dialect. I was thoroughly engaged with Claire's life with frank and her early adventures on the other side of the stones. Claire is a gutsy, smart, and passionate woman as is her new husband. Gabaldon keeps us in suspense about Claire's future. Will she or won't she return to frank and the 20th century? But after so many misadventures and near tragedies the plot gets tedious and repetitious. I thought the scenes at the monastery were philosophically intriguing, especially with brother Anselm and Claire, but the scene of final "healing" was so bizarre as to strain credibility. Then too the dialogue in the very last scene between husband and wife was too cliched for my taste. This is a long read and I needed one, but the book would have benefited by editing.

I'll start by saying that this isn't a book for everyone.  Those people who can't "stomach" a few gory scenes shouldn't read this book.  Those people who don't want both a male and female hero, shouldn't read this book.  It is, however, the best book...no, let me correct myself.  It is the best series of books that I have ever read.  There are some that might complain that it is too long.  However, I was so entranced by the story and by the characters, that I couldn't get enough.  At least once a year (and I emphasize "AT LEAST") I read all of the books again.  And every time that I do, I fall in love with the series all over again.  There are so many wonderful characters in this book that I feel like I know.  Mrs. Gabaldon has done a masterful job on all of these books.  Read Outlander if you want to begin something that will last a lifetime.

I came late to this series and mostly started it because of the TV show, but I really enjoyed the time travel theme and the action and culture in 18th century Scotland. I'm not a huge fan of the level of erotica in the writing and I think I may take a pass on further installments in this series because of it, but also as historical fiction will probably be taking over more and the time travel/fantasy aspect taking less of the focus now that Claire is accustomed to being back in the 1700's and has made the choice to stay there. I do like the author's writing style and had a pretty good time with the characters. I'm sure I'll be missing some deft plot turns by Gabaldon; she does a nice job of spinning a tale. Would very much have preferred less lurid sex scenes, especially with the Black Jack Randall character. Made me feel very creeped out.

The theme of the book was good in the beginning.  However, as the book progressed the situation and choices the heroine made became more and more unrealistic.  By the end of the book, which was to long, you were wondering just how unintelligent she was.  The length of the book and the unrealistic situations developing in the last 25 to 30% of the book made you wonder if the author was just trying to hit a certain number pages.  Also, the ending was so abrupt it was like someone having a conversation with you when they turn and walk away in the middle of a sentence.  I thought I would download the second book sample to get some closure for the first book but NO.  The second book starts about 20 years later with no explanation of what happened in the gap.  I will not be purchasing the second book.

I was taken back and mesmerized by Outlander.  I'll admit it - I delibrately skimmed the book to figure out what happens in the end.  But now that I can read the book word for word and savor it, it's like a whole new experience.  Like anything, Outlander has a double side - and those who  read it are the only ones who can understand it - truly, this book made me  feel like these two characters can live and breath like we can.  That is  the power of Diana Gabaldon's writing.  It's prose is bewitching, it's tone  amazing and it's pace near break-neck speed.  I haven't yet read the  sequels and I'm not in a rush to.  I've got to recover from reading  Outlander first.  Thank you, Mrs. Gabaldon.  Your talent is amazing.  Outlander deserves any and all rewards in the catagories it falls into.
Weird, annoying main character (also the narrator). Stopped reading the sentence she "understood" why her husband beat her.

I usually like to read romances but I was getting tired of the cookie cutter plot lines.  I think some authors think you need to be brainless to enjoy a good romance.  How refreshing it was to find a book that challenged  my intelligence, that brought out every emotion possible and that was  totally entertaining; not to mention romantic.  I just have to add that  Jamie's accent was adorable and his character a rare breed.  I loved this  book.  I had my sisters read it also.  One loved it; the other hated it  (why, I don't understand).  I now love fiction and am on a quest for  something even close to the quality of Outlander; haven't found it yet.  I'll just have to wait for Diana Gabaldon to come out with a new book.  Even without the romance she's a great storyteller.

Excellent book! A co-worker bought me this book & told me that I had to read it. And I'm so glad she did. It's more than a romance novel, it's an education in history, herbology, medicine & so much more. Gabaldon is amazing! I can't even image how much research went into this book. It's long, but well worth it. The first few chapters drag on, but there's a reason for all the geneology & once it get's going, you're hooked. I'm on my third Gabaldon, Voyager, & I can't wait to read the next one. Her characters are so vivid. Jamie & Claire seem so real. And Jamie is just exquisite. He's vulnerable, highly intuitive, intelligent, innocent, & utterly sensual. That's why it's so easy to love him. He has flaws but they make him even more attractive. Before reading Outlander, I'd heard women speak of this "Jamie" character as if he's a real person. Now I understand why. This is the closest I've come to having a full blown crush on a fictional character. I am addicted to Gabaldon's novels.
