She makes other romance novels seem like short stories written for a creative writing class. Once you read Gabaldon, your standards may be so high that other historical romance novels will never satisfy you again.

I have bought these books one by one at [a book store], sneaking around the shelves, hoping nobody saw me in the "romance" section. I do not generally read romance novels; this may be the first since highschool (many moons ago). I cannot recommend this book highly enough! Extremely well-written, well-researched, great story idea. I laughed, I cried, and only stopped reading the series long enough to find the next book. I do agree with a previous reviewer that some of the treatment of Claire by her lover Jamie is horrible, but perhaps historically accurate? I'm addicted to this series, and about to start re-reading. This may be a bad idea: I'm a grad student and won't get any studying done! I wish I could find another book/ author so capable of holding my attention...

The dark circles under my eyes probably speak volumes as to how much I enjoyed this book.  Since finishing book Five of the A Song of Ice and Fire Series (Game of Thrones) I have been on the hunt for the next series to fill the void left behind.  If book one is any indication, this series is off to a great start.  The main character is a willful, feisty, intelligent female, who has the opportunity to say many of the things (albeit, not fitting the period) one wishes female heroines would say in historical-based fictions.  The romance is a bit on the lovey-dovey side, but I am withholding judgment until a get further into the series.  This would be a great book to bring along on an actual vacation, or a time when one is looking for an escape into a good book.

Anyone who has read the ENTIRE book or the series would not for a minute think that Claire is wrong in forgiving Jaime.  I too am an avid reader, 4-6 books per week, (I'm an addict), and I have to say that these books are the best I have ever read.  Jennifer, you took one scene from thousands that you didn't read and judged the whole based on a fraction. This is the true shame.  Do yourself a favor, read these books.  As you can see from all the other reviews, this story is exceptional.  Just because women should be treated equally doesn't mean we always were.  You have missed out on one of greatest stories ever written.  I urge you to read this story completely, then see if you don't agree with the rest of us.  I'm only sorry there isn't another chapter.

This book was recommended to me and I am really ticked that I shelled out the $8 or $9 that I spent on it.  First of all it is basically a trashy romance novel (I do not like trashy romances, but I do have some friends who do, so no offense - just not my taste).  It is also poorly written and it is too wordy.  I tried to like it; there are so many books in the series and I thought, "Awesome!  I've got reading material for months!"  But no.  In addition to the problems listed above, the whole premise just wasn't believable.  I have enjoyed many time-travel books, so the genre, when well written, can be pure escapism.  But I just didn't buy into this book.  Claire too quickly accepted the switch from present day to past.  There was very little questioning of the circumstances, plus she gave little thought to her husband.  I just found these things to be ridiculous.  Then add the numerous sex scenes, rape scenes, attempted rape scenes, attempted gang-rape scenes, sadistic sex scenes, homosexual sex scene, etc., and, well...you've got a book that might come in handy as a doorstop.

This is an amazing book.  Ms. Gabaldon makes the characters and situations so real that you completely empathize with them, and often become so lost in the book that you feel as if it is happening to YOU.  This makes for a very powerful, sometimes very stressful read......and when it's over, you will feel as if these characters were/are living historical people, not just "characters."  Do not make the mistake of passing the Outlander books off as "romance" novels; although the earlier editions had some slightly cheesy cover art, these books are meticulously researched with much love and devotion by their author. You will learn about history, folklore, medicine, and many other subjects while escaping into this fascinating world.

I heard a review of Gabaldon's 4th book in the series, and it sounded so good I went to the bookstore, and found that it was a series. Started with Outlander, and couldn't put it down, through all 800+ pages! I read a few pages aloud to my husband, who likes history and mystery stories. He was hesitant, and I suggested he read just the first 100 pages. He is hooked, and we both got copies of the second book, and he is now through book 4. Wonderful writing, great twists of plot, characters are fascinating. I hope that Gabaldon gets more recognition. She certainly deserves it. As a last note, I enjoy seing how an author's past experiences affect writing... Gabaldon's knowledge of plant medicines provide an excellent bridge for Claire.

my entire family tree is rooted in Scotland and Wales. I have visited Scotland and so was familiar with some of the history and place names. Now I have to go back and revisit all over again. I just finished the second book and am now on to the third. the character development is round and rich and entices the reader to participate in the love affair and adventure of Claire and Jamie Fraser. The books are a peek through a window in time and has inspired my lust for more voyeuristic experience in 17th century Scotland. :) (I've been reading the books on Kindle, but since I am also a paper page lover, I will buy the hard copies and dog ear the pages for favorite passages.)  Thank you, Elaine for recommending these books to me!!

Armed with only my naivete' and an interest in Scottish History I was lured into the tar baby which is Diana Gabaldon's Outlander by the glowing reviews here in the readers comments section. Eight hundred pages later I  emerged a bitter and angry young man, most reviewers didn't want to put it  down, I hated to pick it up.  Our heroine is transported back to Scotland  in the 1700's by a mysterious circle of celtic stones.  Alone in a hostile  environment with only her wits and her insatiable libido to guide her,  Claire Randall gets caught up in the battles between Scots and English and  between various clan factions.  If you are truly looking for historical  fiction on this era I suggest Sir Walter Scott, but if you want the  bodice-ripping version than Outlander is the book for you.

When a friend let me borrow the book in Novemeber 2000.  I was hesitant.  After all I thought all "romance" was the same story line over and over again.  Gosh was I ever wrong.  I couldn't put the book down,  I then went out and bought the rest of the series.  And this Christmas my husband bought me the Fiery Cross.  I can't wait to start it, I started through the series for the third time in under a year when I found out that her new book was coming out in October.  I just love the series, she makes you feel as if you are living right along side Claire and Jamie.  She is a wonderful writer and draws you in so that you never want to put the book down.  I refuse to lend my books to anyone!!

I've read this book twice now, and could probably read it several times more. It's 1945 and Claire Beauchamp Randall is recently reunited with her husband after serving as a combat nuse in World War II. During their second honeymoon, Claire is drawn to a ring of stones, and when she steps through is transported 200+ years into the past, right in the middle of a skirmish between British troops and a band of Scottish Highlanders. From that point on, the book is constant action and suspense, with Claire torn between her love for Scots warrior Jamie Fraser and her husband some 200 years later. This is a truly wonderful love story, and although the book is long, I wanted it to continue on. Loved it!

As a fan of historical romance novels my review is not exactly unbiased.  I found that I outgrew Victoria Holt and there wasn't much for more sophisticated historical romance fans. After seeing the reviews for Diana Gabaldon's books... I decided to give her a try and am I ever glad I did!  This book has fascinating characters, an interesting plot and some history thrown in.  The love story between Jamie and Claire is so intense and passionate but not without it's ups and downs. For anyone turned off by the time travel aspect, it really plays a fairly minor role.  I'm so thrilled to have found such an excellent author because now I've got several weeks/months of compelling reading ahead of me.

Dived right in, the most pleasent part of this book aside from the fantastic story line and great characters is that it doesn't have a lot of mindless fillers to skim over.  Every page is important and every sub-plot has real value. I found myself after several hours of reading and growing tension wanting to skip ahead and find out how it ends, but it ruins the details. The details are savory and not at all to be missed. Being that I am a die hard quicky romance novel lover the size was a bit daunting, I worried it was a bit too scholastic for my daytime reading tastes, but the pages turn quickly and then I realized that 850 pages weren't enough. I am happy to recommend this to everyone.

Gosh, how to describe the start of this series...?  I'd give it ten stars and gold-plating if I could.  (Any review I give will not do this work justice at all...; that said, IT'S ABSOLUTELY BLOODY BRILLIANT.  While this  series is most definitely the best I've ever read, I agree with those that  have mentioned that 'Romance' as a genre stifles the scope of Gabaldon's  work.  How many people have written the book off as just another  bodice-ripper with little plot and less intelligence just because it was in  the romance aisle?  Even the author herself doesn't catalogue herself that  way.  I think what makes this series so stupendous is that it defies any  catagory, right?--  It's just simply a great work of literature.  As a good  fan of fine writing, I wish potential readers would get past the  appearances and experience how great these books are...Like everyone else  says:  DEFINITELY WORTH IT.  Not to sound repetitive, but I firmly believe  that once you've read "Outlander", you'll be hooked.  Very  intelligent, and very addicting!

Since September 11th, my reading tastes have changed somewhat in that, when I'm not reading the newspaper, I want to totally escape from this troubled world into a place that can't be touched by all this. I had read this series before and realized it was the perfect set to read again. And I'm not disappointed on the second reading. The characters of Jamie and Claire are some of best I've ever encountered in books of this genre, and Gabaldon's research seems to have been thorough and loving. For once, you have 18th-century characters with actual body odors (witness Claire's wedding dress). But that's what makes them all the more endearing. Trying to escape as I have? This is your book!

When I first read the back cover of the book I immediately had visions of some viking time travel story with the damsel in distress. I decided to give Mrs. Galbaldon 15 minutes of my time and check out the story line.  The first chapter got me hooked and the book is now my favorite!  While this book is listed as "romance", it is a far cry from the cheesy, lustful novels we all pretend not to really read.  Mrs. Galbaldon painted the main character as a real woman dealing with reality and created a love story that was very believable.  I got swept away by the story and couldn't wait to read the entire series!  It has to be one of the best romance novels I have ever read!

This book is NOT a romance. Yes, it has romance and enough passion to singe the reader's fingers, but that is not what it is. It is not a historical novel or a time travel novel. This book -in fact, the entire  series- is unique, and is GREAT. The whole concept is original enough, the  research is obvious and impresive but it is the WRITING that is truly  superb. The main characters, Jamie and Claire, and the host of secondary  characters, are funny, many-layered and believable. There is good and evil,  mainly in the person of Black Jack Randall, and there are many subplots,  complex and interesting in their own right. Nothing is wasted; every little  comment or incident is tied together, bit by bit, to form a complex and  remarkable pattern. This is a book that you cannot put down and that you  come back to over and over again, discovering new facts every time.  The  whole series has become one of my all-time favorites. I know that I am only  one among many others waiting with bated breath for the next book in the  series.

This is one of the best books I have read. I was thrown off by the size of it at first because I never have enough time to read a lot and thought I would never finish such a large book. After reading comments and reviews on the book for the past 2 years I had mixed ideas about getting the book. I'm glad I finally did. I couldn't put it down for days and kept pulling it out to read in every spare moment I could find. Gabaldon is an excellent author and the h/h were complex and had depth. There was non-stop adventure, romantic scenes, and historial insights that kept me interested. I definitely recommend this book. I'm eagerly anticipating the next book in my mailbox.

I picked up this book on vacation not really expecting much.  I was pleasantly surprised, becoming completely engrossed in it.  It is very much escapist literature.  However, if you aren't very keen on history, you might find the novel boring.  Gabaldon includes a lot of details pertaining to the setting, which makes it interesting to me (I am a big fan of historical fiction like Sharon Kay Penman), but may not be what some readers want.  The characterization is also particularly good (though it may be too subtle for some who are expecting a cookie-cutter romance).  The other books in the series are also good, and are even less similar to "romance" novels.

I started with Outlander and have just received (from Amazon) the last book in Diana Gabaldon's Outlander series, A Breath of Snow and Ashes".  I can't wait to get started on it.  You must read the books as they occur in the series and good luck trying to put them down or get anything else done.  I had never read any "time traveler" type books before, but a co-worker got me started on this series and I am so hooked that I find myself trying to cast the characters in a movie!  No movie could possibly be as good as my imagination as Diana has stirred it up.  Amazing series, you will look at life, morality, mortality and history differently than you ever have before.

Women love this book and it's hero Jamie Fraser ...but I'm puzzled because the romantic dialog written for hero Jamie Fraser is written for women by a woman.  Fraser is handsome, strong, gallant, vulnerable, sensitive, boyishly charming, and able to articulate all his romantic feelings....sorry, ladies, men like that only exist in women's imaginations.  That being said, I admit to skipping over some of the semi-erotic nonsense and found the plot to be no more than an average historical novel.  While I know this is the first in a series of the adventures of Jamie and Claire, I am going to save my money and hope that Jamie and Claire live a long and happy life.

I got it thinking it was sci-fi. It has a great concept which could really be interesting but there is sooooo much diversion into the faux drama of "over the top" love affair and sex that divert from the story. I'm ok with sex and some romance but I think it diminishes the power of women to have this kind of possessed romance. The man in the story seems like a great guy but gradually becomes a stereotype swashbuckler with mindlessly excessive obsession with the leading woman. I read thru the story and enjoyed the parts where the story was told and learned to skim the hyper-empassioned love affair parts. Still not worth reading the rest of the series.
This story was okay but goes on and on.  Not for me, it needs more history and plot, less dialog and fluff.

When I accidently stumbled on the unabridged audiocassette version of Outlander, I haven't been able to stop listening.  I listen on my way to  work, at lunch, on my way home and while walking my dogs.  Ms. Gabaldon is  a wonderful writer!  If I were reading it, I'd surely be up until the  "wee" hours of the morning.  Listening to the book makes all the  difference, what with the Scottish accents and all.  I find myself crying  and laughing out loud.  I just love these types of books, and my mother's  maiden name was Beauchamp (go figure).  I'm overjoyed I found this book and  can't wait to read or listen to the rest.  Makes you believe!

It has been a long time since I have read anything so well written and researched - thankyou Ms Gabaldon for enriching my life.  For those who have not read any of Ms Gabaldon's books, you are in for a treat.  Even if time-travel is not your thing, you would be remiss to not read her books.  They are well written, well researched, and told with eye for detail.  This author knows what she is doing, and is not to be confused with the other romance fluff she is often found alongside in bookstores.  If you thirst for the best, then this high caliber series is for you.  I highly reccommend Outlander, and the other books in the series.
Gag me with a spoon. Sappy story. Couldn't relate to characters. Gave it away after first two chapters.

Not one for historical romance, this novel grabbed me and I read this and the subsequent three novels all in one month.  I can't remember the last time I sequestered myself in my room, reading up to 6 hours a day. I even irritated (oops and neglected) my family with my passion for these books.  Although there is some violence, especially with "women's issues", they fit the violent times in which the novel was placed.  Claire is a spunky, no-nonsense person who gets lost in a fantasy... what an escape... for Claire as well as for me!! I've passed the series on to my ENGLISH mother-in-law, who is now a fan as well!

For as hyped up as this book has been (thanks, STARZ), I was really disappointed. There were too many things going on, too many characters, and too much sex. Romantic time-traveller stories have been done before and much better. I struggled through the book because I paid for it, but I was in no way enamored of the lead characters and really didn't care about what happened to them. On top of that, the writing style is a bit immature; It may have been better told from a third-person narration. I very much doubt that I will read any more of the books in the series unless I get a free copy, and even then probably not.

This is the most amazing book I have ever read.  I have never been so entirely absorbed by a book, and I have an English Literature degree.  This book completely touched my soul.  For two days, I did nothing but read, I  couldn't and wouldn't put it down (to the annoyance of my husband). Several  of my co-workers read this entire series and have tried to get me to read  them for some time.  I was hestitant, thinking a "romance" novel  would not be something I would enjoy.  But, this book is truly so much more  than that.  The history is rich, the imagery is fantastic, Gabaldon is  truly a talented writer.  But, let me tell you, this book does have it's  romance (and it is very good!) but it is also not for the sqeamish.  Anyway, I just had to give my two-scents.  I HIGHLY recommend this book.  And the next three (I am almost finished with the fourth).  I have been  utterly hooked for the last month.
I managed to read about 50 pages of this thinking it would get better. It didn't. I found it boring

Although the plot style is not typically my preferred style for romance (not so much a fan of older women with younger men, and time travel) - this book is amazing, and honestly everything I heard it would be. The time travel is done very well, and the book is filled with historical detail that makes it not only wholly romantic but also very intelligent. Claire & Jaime's romance is beautiful - they fall in love slowly but so wonderfully, despite the husband she left "behind" in the future, and some demons in his past. Their adventures are fun if sometimes disturbing. The pages will fly by. Beautiful!

I read a lot and I read all types of books. This one blew my mind. It had some of everything in it...adventure,romance,mystery,history  and fantasy. The story was woven in such a way that the reader becomes part the action. I could feel the cold, smell the air, and see the action. The fears of the characters became my fears and the pain of the characters were so vividly written that I could feel it and see it. I actually felt as though I was there and physically observing the action. I t was a great story and I enjoyed every page of it. I loved this book. It was time travel at its best .

I admit to being a little skeptical when this book was recommended to me and I found it in the romance section.  Not thinking of myself as a romance novel fan, I wasn't sure I would like it at all but I gave it a try anyway.  Well, it's wonderful!  There definitely is a romance angle but it's much more true to life than the average romance and the other aspects of the story are fascinating.  Rich characters and realistic situations make for a thoroughly entertaining read from the second Claire appears on the scene.  And then there's Jamie! Wow!  You will not be able to put it down.

I was very disappointed to read some of the negative reviews mentioning their dislike of the violence & lust in this book.  That  was indicative of that time period, like it or not.  The characters were  wonderfully strong with vivid personalities. I read the book for  entertainment not to judge the content of it.  Diana Galbaldon has an  amazing talent to capture detail and immerse her reader into the story.  I  am interested in my Scottish ancestory because of these books and hope to  do some research into them.  I eagerly await her next work of brilliance!

I live very close to Culloden and have visited so many of the places that Diana Gabaldon has written about in her four novels. The ones that she has created have set me wandering in search, in Edinburgh and in Inverness, and I try to imagine the scenes there over 200 years ago.She has made my soul ache to be adored by such a man, (if one could exist),and to be as capable as Claire. ha! I hear you snort.... I don't care - these books have given me tremendous pleasure, so think what you will. I hate the thought of waiting yet another year until the next instalment.
This is a  long winded book. A friend just loved so I gave it a try. Rambles on. Not for me.

I was told by many people to try this author out, but held off for several years.  The books are so large and intimidating.  I never felt I would have the time to read the whole thing, not to mention I normally hate romance novels.  I finaly gave in and tried Outlander and what a surprise.  This is no ordinary romance novel...this is an adventure, fantasy, action novel.  I read the whole book in a matter of three days.  They ran to the local book store (no offense amazon) to pick up the next.  I can't wait until Gabaldon continues the series with another novel.

Obviously, if you are purchasing the anniversary edition you probably have already read Outlander and love the book/series.  I was actually surprised at the quality of the book, itself.  It has a raised cover and a built in bookmark which made it kind of special.  It also comes with a CD in the back that helps you pronounce some of the Gaelic and some other bonus goodies.  I ended up ordering two of these.  One for my best friend that originally hooked me on the Outlander series in the first place.... and later one for myself because I liked it so much!

I started reading this book about the same time I began a new job. I had  been vying for that job for 2 years, but I could not get this book out of  my mind! I'd stay up late to read, get up early to read, then think about  the book all day until I could go home and read. When I found out that  there were sequals, I was delighted! As far as I'm concerned, I could read  sequals of this book for the next dozen years and never get bored with the  story of Jamie, Claire, Brianna, and the rest of the Fraizer/MacKenzie  clan. Keep it up Ms. Gabaldon.
STOP all Science Fiction Lovers!!  This is not science fiction novel, but a romance novel.  Kindle needs to categorize it as such!!

Davina Porter did a marvelous job in the narration. She brought to life the words and it was a thrill to listen to the English and Scottish accents, not to mention the Gaelic pronunciation.  Jamie and Claire came to life and so did all the very fascinating characters.  Another plus is the packaging of the CD was attractive.  I cannot wait till the other unabridged CDs for the other books in the Outlander series become available on Amazon.com.  I highly recommend anyone who enjoys Diana Gabaldon's books to get a copy of this unabridged CD set.

Who ever had the audacity to say that books two, three and  four of this series were not as good as the first must  get their head examined. I read all the time, my favorite type of novel being the "historical romance type". Never in any book that I have ever read have I gotten so completely swept away. These four books are one giant masterpiece, and I fear that ABC will not remotely do this story justice when they make the made for T.V. mini-series. Diana Gabaldon is a genius and master story teller. These books are a must read.

I did not care for this book, although a managed to finish it, barely. I thought Claire was shallow and conceited and a know it all.  Also the treatment if the 1700s was so rosy tinted - little mention of the daily hardships of that era - but lots of lusty sex with her 'perfect' man. It was a bit harlequin romancy. Also some characters (the ancestor of her husband) were way over the top. I absolutely could not imagine reading another one in the series. To be fair, I saw the trailer for the tv show and I thot that it looked pretty good!

When this book was first explained to me, I was not interested.  Time travel just was not on my list of interest despite the fact that history was something I was interested in immensely.  When I finally read this book, I absolutely loved it and began collecting all of the following novels.  Diana Gabaldon is absolutely brilliant!  Do not read this unless you are prepared to spend the time reading all of her following novels because you will most definitely want to read what happens to Jamie and Claire, your new instant ancestors.

I have just finished this first book of this series and haven't been so enthused about a new author for many years.  Her wonderful attention to detail and the contrasts between life in the 1940's and 1740's were great!  What impressed me most of all was her ability to write in Gaelic dialect so well, I could just HEAR it!  (The fact that one of my best friends is Scottish helped a little I guess.)  This book has EVERYTHING--history, lovable characters, great love scenes, and nasty villains.  I can't wait to start the second one!

I started reading this book at the insistence of my sister.  She has really enjoyed all of the books in the series. I am not usually a fan of romance novels so I should have known that I would not care for it. I disliked the protagonist almost instantly and thought she was a most unbelievable character. Continuing to read, I found that most of the characters felt insubstantial. I enjoy a good fantasy novel but prefer my characters to be realistic and comprehensible.  I finally stopped torturing myself and put the book down.

Thank God I was lucky enough to be in a bookstore one day when a stranger, also in the romance section, recommended this book! These characters get into your mind and heart.  Truly unforgettable! Looking back, I should have  recognized the twinkle accompanying the demure smile on her face as she  handed me this amazing story! I haven't been the same since...Now, I too  feel like standing in the aisles and casually recommending this book to  browsing romance addicts, and unleashing this magnificent adventure onto  them...:)

I first read Drums of Autumn and immediately went looking for the first 3 books. I next read numbers 3, then 2 and finally read Outlander. I fell in love with Jamie and Claire. Their trueness and devotion to each other,  their intelligence and insight and caring natures are inspirational. I  NEVER reread books but... I reread this series (in order) not once but  THREE times!  Even at 4 times through I still found things I missed the  first 3 times. I may even read them again! Anxiously awaiting the next  one,Fiery Cross.

I loved this book. Don't let the number of pages turn you off. The book captivates you and makes you feel like you have been transported into their era. I found myself laughing out loud and talking to the Claire and Jamie like they could hear me. This book was an emotional roller coaster. When they were in danger I felt like I was in danger... I felt their pain, love, sadness and I feared for their lives. Excellent story and now I can read something light hearted... in order to give my emotions a break.

This book horrifies me. I have no problem with sex in books. I have no problem with books that are simply fun reads with no thought provoking ideas or moral lessons. I totally respect that people have different taste in books. I like many different types of books. I love history, especially Scottish history. I love to be entertained when reading. I love learning while I read. For all of these reasons, I decided to try reading Outlander. I had to stop reading less than half way through. This book affected me on a visceral level and I cannot get it out of my head, in a very negative way. My stomach literally turns when I think this book. The main female character is an abused woman. The main male character is abusive. Regardless of the historical accurateness of the book, it saddens me that we are praising a book where the main female character allows herself to be abused. She agrees that she did not obey her husband and understands why he has to beat her.  As a woman, teacher, and mother, the acceptance of this book terrifies me. Why do we still allow ourselves to be objectified and abused, even in literature?

I have never been a 'romance' fan, and have actually been a non fiction or war/military reader most of my life.  This book was suggested to me by a co-worker and I hurumphed at the idea.  Imagine my total surprise when I was nearly at once mesmerized by this story.  What initially inspired me to even give it a glance was the fact that the heroine was a WWII nurse....nothing less would have even enticed me to look at the back cover.  However, the humor, the sexiness, the intrigue won me.  This is one sexy novel, but also funny, readable, and so enjoyable.  This non romance reader found a real treasure in this story.  Do not be timid about giving it a try.  Like me, you very well may just find yourself quite surprised!

I first read this in the mid 90s and recently reread the entire series. I truly fell in love with Jamie Fraser with the first reading! Gabaldon made me feel like I was there with Claire. It is a real, powerful, and truly breathtaking book. Sometimes the author seems to get a little off on tangents with describing details or scenes, but I have found that it is the journey with author, not always the destination, that makes this entire series truly magical. I would give this 10 stars if I could!

This is one of my all-time favorites, and since it's the first in Gabaldon's saga it's a must read first to enjoy and benefit from the entire series.  But be prepared for a 2-year commitment because that's about what it takes to read all 6 books.  And I dreaded seeing each of them come to an end, until I learned that there was another sequel coming soon.  Now, after waiting to hear if there will be another, I keep hoping and wondering how this wonderful author can continue to fascinate us.

If someone would have told me that a time travel book where fidelity is challenged would be one of my absolute favorites of all time I wouldn't have believed it.  When you read the book you won't think about time travel, fidelity or anything other than Jamie and Claire together.  I read it years ago and it remains in my personal top five books ever.  Read it.  You won't be disappointed. It is one of a handful of novels with worthy sequels.  Speaking of which, Ms. Gabaldon, we're waiting...
A little too many rape scenes, witch trials, and explicit sex scenes for me to even get more than halfway through.

This story starts our very well.  I was, in fact, mesmerized by the story line.  But then Gabaldon begins endless descriptions of the love aspects of the two main characters.  Just when I thought I could not stand it anymore  things get really worse.  I started wondering about this author when she  descibed a belt whipping that the heroin got from the hero.  Then the  heroin went through the process of convincing herself that she deserved it.  (NOT!).  Later in the book a very detailed description is given of a  homosexual torture rape, complete with knives, blood licking, and you name  it.  Then close to the end, to save the hero, the heroin reinacts some of  the same acts on the hero.  It was too much for me.

I'm an avid reader, but I rarely read books more than once.  This novel, in fact the entire series, is an exception.  I first read Outlander in college.  Since then I have read the entire series three times and listened to it on CD.  There is just something about the world Gabaldon has created that is endlessly fascinating.  Unlike many romance novels, the characters are deep and nuanced and, despite the implausible time-travel premise, their lives feel engaging and real.

The first 50 or so pages of this book are good. A woman, who was a nurse during the Second World War, gets transported back in time to the mid-18th century Scottish Highlands. Then it all goes downhill. It becomes a sappy love story with a whole lot of violence, torture, sexual abuse, and witchcraft thrown in. Diana Gabaldon seems to really get off on describing torture, as a majority of the book revolves around abhorrent abuse. I HATED that she made her primary villain a sadistic homosexual. And her new husband Jamie gets tortured so cruelly that there is no way in hell that he would have survived. Read this book only if you want to know about man-on-man rape and horrific violence.

I was talking to a friend about books and she showed me her 4 Gabaldon books as her "all time favorites" and offered to loan them to me  so I could enjoy them as well - I got through Outlander in 4 days and it is  my favorite so far (I am working through the last 100 pages of Voyager now)  and it's a truly enchanting novel.  It's part romance, part historical  ficton, part adventure - it's a light read but not entirely mindless - all  in all a wonderful book!

A few of my friends told me about Outlander and I kept putting them off--it didn't seem like the kind of book I would like to read.  I reluctantly picked it up one day and never put it down.  I tried to make myself slow down and savor every page but I couldn't.  When I did try to put it down I would worry about Jamie and Claire every second I was away from them.  I've told everyone I know about this book, I've even told them the best pages because I have them memorized

I will never recomend this book to any one I know personally.  The Outlander and I have a special relationship, and for others to read it and know about it would be embarrasing.  I resisted reading this book when it was recomended to me, and I have never told the person who recomended that I read it.  I can not bear to talk about the very personal feeling I have about the Outlander with others.  Weird huh?  I have never felt this attatched to a book before for this long.  I was so wrapped up in it I found myself laughing out loud, crying and barely able to leave the couch and my book for four days.  Even more strange, I read this book in early summer in the high deserts of Wyoming, it rained the whole time I was reading the book, those four days were the only time it rained all year here.  It was like the whole world wanted my to feel at home with this book.  I hope that others will pick up this whole series, just as long as they dont tell me about it!

I loved this book so much, that I immediately went out and bought the rest of the series.  If you're considering buying this beek, I reccomend you buy at least one of the books which follow it, you'll want them.  I fell completely in love with Jamie and I wanted to be Claire so badly that I didn't want the series to end--I wanted to continue living vicariously through her.  This book, and the ones which follow, are a MUST READ if you're a romance novel lover!

When this book was recommended to me (an avid historical fiction reader), a time travel romance didn't seem appealing.  Finally I read it and...wow!  These characters are so interesting and well written.  My only qualm with the book is the way Gabaldon switches back and forth between first and third person -- it is distracting to say the least.  Otherwise, I highly recommend this book.  And don't be intimidated by the book's length, it is a quick read.

This was a great read, in terms of not being able to put it down, but my only complaint is that it doesn't seem plausible that one human being could endure the amount of bodily pain and suffering as Jamie Fraser.  It seems like the author enjoys describing physical pain and suffering.  The main characters are definitely likable and as I'm finishing up this book I'm debating about whether or not I care enough about them to pursue the next installment.

This is an absoutely wonderful story. I've read the first four books so far & can't wait to read the last one. In the mean time, I'm reading Outlander again! My husband is planning on reading it also.There is supposted to be another book comming out soon & possible a 7th. I've been to Gabaldon's web site & she's debating on a movie. Most of her fans can't wait to see this story on the big screen. Personally, I think Outlander is the best one so far!

...this would be it. I don't normally read historical fiction, but this series takes the cake. I'll learn history all day if it's this sexy and well-written! Gabaldon creates an amazing blend of history, fantasy, and romance that I read at least once every six months. If you like time-travel novels, books-borderlining-erotica, or want to get yourself into a new series, pick up Outlander. It's a huge book, but you will by no means be disappointed.

I can't believe I haven't reviewed this book yet. I first read it about 6 years ago when a good friend gave me a copy Since then I've read the whole series several times and I've been slowly upgrading my paperbacks to hardback.  This book has everything - adventure, romance, war, history, time travel, etc.  Even though it was categorized as a romance, my husband has also read all of them and enjoyed them as much as me. I recommend this book often!

This series is outstanding!  If you read the original, you MUST continue on with the entire series.  I even read them out of sequence and because of the exceptional writing skill of Diana Gabaldon, that didn't matter.  She gives you just enough information from book to book to follow the story line, but not disturb the current episode. I wish she would continue this series and just fill in more years between the start and the finish! --Georgene
This book was too long, too explicit and too violent; did not entice me to read any more of the series.

This first book in the Outlander series has some very positive aspects, among those being the historical context and references interspersed throughout the plot. Even some of the characterization and dialogue was quite enjoyable to read. However, the novel was just too long and I thought there were too many highly detailed and gratuitous sex scenes. Very reminiscent of Fifty Shades of Grey in that regard; it just gets boring after a while--

My Favorite book (and author) EVER.  The Outlander draws and drops you into a world that becomes your own quickly, and is the forerunner of a BRILLIANT series by Diana Gabaldon.  I have re-read the entire series about 14 times, and Outlander remains my favorite ONLY because it is the one that introduced me to the world of Jamie and Claire.  Each and every book of this series is wonderful.  I highly recommend that you keep reading.......
It only took a few pages until I decided this was not the book for me.

I was a little intimidated when I found Diana Gabaldon's 850+ page "Outlander" series.  I was so captivated by Claire and Jamie and their story that became so real for me. Romance, adventure, loyalty, funny, sad, love for all-time and overall the one of the best series I have ever read.  Although each one of Ms. Gabaldon's books get heavier in size with each turn of events-don't shy away from any of them-you will not be disappointed.

Take the day off work, have food and tissues nearby and get ready to immerse yourself in this book. I actually handsold this book for years at a bookstore where I worked. One customer came back after she'd read it and was furious. She told me I'd ruined all other books for her after reading Outlander. Nothing compares!! It is THE BEST historical/time travel/romance I've ever read. But trust me, you'll enjoy the sequels, too!

I enjoyed this book, but felt it was a bit long.  The author could have shortened it considerably by cutting off details that didn't help the story at all.  I ended up skipping ahead several times, but maybe that's just me.  Still, the overall story is a good one and one I recommend.  Not sure if I will get the second book (Dragonfly in Amber) as I have read the reviews of the story and it doesn't really interest me.

I bought this based on the premise and expected to love it. It was pretty good until about a quarter of the way in when the story lost all focus. Then the boring sex scenes started and never seemed to stop. I began skipping them and discovered how little there was in between and even that had nothing to do with advancing the story in any meaningful way. A total bore. I quit at the 45% mark in my kindle edition.

If Rape, adultery and abuse are your ideas of romance, then this book is for you. I had heard so many good things about this book and decided to give it a try. I love a good romance and the time travel added interest. Instead I got a book about how it is ok for the hero to beat he heroine and that is ok. I stopped reading after he did that. That is NO HERO!! The fact that the heroine accepts it is even worse!!

In that tired old game of "desert island books," I would without hesitation include this on my list. It's a feast, one on which I could dine for many years. Full of adventure, romance, intrigue, and danger, it's like nothing I've ever read before. If you're put off by the fact that it's shelved with the romances, as I initially was, get past it. Buy the book and settle in for an outstandingly memorable read.

Initially, I did not think this was my kind of book, with time travel, etc. But I have read the whole series twice and am thinking about a third time! I spent many nights up to 2am with Jamie and Clair (the main characters). Needless to say, the characters come to life, and you can learn quite a bit of Scottish history.  Everyone I have turned on to this series becomes hooked too! Can't recommend too highly!

Love this story!  But more than that I found myself inexorably drawn to the lovely crafting of the words on every page.  The author is simply a terrific writer & I savored the rhythm & feel of her words every bit as much as the delights (and horrors) of the story as it unfolded.  In addition,  I've rarely seen the intimacy of love so accurately captured as here.  Thoroughly enjoyable & highly recommended.

I as a general rule and not fond of paranormal stories. This is a historical romance that captures the interest in the second chapter, when Claire story really kicks off. I loved the story, loved the writing style, it was long, but I never wanted it to end. Jamie's capture and horror at prison made me ill, but the truth usually does make you cringe. I bought the next book and am fast a fan of this author.

more like 2 and a half... pretty entertaining but very silly story. I got into it at times, but seemed like whenever the lead couple is not coupling, they are being beaten, raped or tortured. Too much gruesome violence for light reading. The story has its moments that make it worthwhile, but a lot of it was like a supermarket romance novel meets hollywood action flick. it didn't really do it for me sorry

I love historical fiction and I really enjoyed this book until the end.  There were two currents throughout the book that were troubling:  torture and homosexuality.  Until the end, they were easy to overlook and were not so overt as to be unpleasant.  Unfortunately, they rear their ugly head and consume the end.  I spent the last of the book skimming as quickly as I could in order to find out what finally happened.  I liked the characters and the writing; but, because it was so graphic, I decided that that was the last book I would read from this author.  So, beware.

I won't go into what this story is about...by now we all know the plot. What I will say is that it is a powerful and breathtaking look at men, women, family, loyalty, honor, marriage and love. Claire and Jamie's loyalty to each other is not only essential to their very survival, but to the lives of their souls as well. By the end Jamie is more human than he will ever be,and you will be out of breath!!

I just finished rereading _Outlander_ for the second time, and I am sure that I will be rereading it many more times in the future, as well as all the other books in the series. This book has some of the best characters ever written as well as one of the most riveting plots and probably one of the best love stories of all time, right up there with "Romeo and Juliet" and _Pride and Prejudice_.

The writing consists of an endless series of simple declarative sentences, some so ridiculous I read them aloud to my husband.  The characters are all one-dimensional. The hero declares that he enjoyed beating the heroine with a belt (sadism) and admits that he enjoyed being fondled by the bad guy. If you value good writing, a sexy hero, engrossing plot, read or re-read Gone With the Wind instead.

Diana Gabaldon shows the world how to write fascinating, compelling fiction. Her characters are real, with strengths and faults just like the rest of us. The situations they encounter seem just as grounded, if adventuresome, as the characters themselves. Her style is wonderfully descriptive and witty, evoking emotion in sympathy with the characters. Hell, if she wrote a shopping list, I'd read it.

To Bad.... the author can't stop herself from letting graphic sex get in the way of what could have been a really good story line. I didn't actually count pages, but I would estimate that 40%, or more, of the novel is sexual in one form or another. I outgrew this stuff when I left puberty.  Having read the reviews for novel #2 of the series, it appears to be more of the same, or worse. I'll pass.

if you are willing to get lost in time,this is the series for you! i did not want to come back from that wonderful story. i felt as if i was right there with jamie and claire.i wanted to be right there! i truely believe  anyone who picks up these books will enjoy them as much as i and so many  others did.being from scottish decent really made it enjoyable to see how  right on she was to the time.

When I saw this would be a tv series I wanted to read the book because in most cases the book is always far better.  Since the tv show hasn't aired yet I won't know.  The book is a time travel romance right up there with all the others that seem to dominate used book store shelves. I found it too detailed in menial subjects and hopefully someone really clever will make the tv series interesting.

This first installment is sensational. I am very intent to read it again after I've finished the last book. A very great love between two people is born and is nurtured. Interesting, unpredictable and it leaves you with a feeling of wanting. Awesome!! I am a bit disappointed that I am unable to purchase most of Gabaldons Outlander series on Kindle format. Not available in Australia!! Not fair!!

I read the 4 books in this series in a whirlwind!  I read them slower the second time around.  I read them again to my husband, he loved them!  I read a chapter or 2 every night to help set the mood for my dreams.  There are literally thousands of people that have read these books and are discussing the characters as we speak, just check out Ladies of Lallybroch!  If you've read the series and feel alone with your obsession for Jamie and Claire Fraser, don't fret, there are others that want to here from you.  This is a series that won't soon be forgotten!

The writing in this book is rather juvenile, seems geared to middle school vocabulary and sentence structure. The descriptions are long winded and monotonous. The genre-historical fiction, erotica mixed with fantasy is just a mixed up mess. I have a "rule" about always finishing a book and did read this one. But, I am wishing that I could get those hours back. Just a waste of time.
So depressing. How much bad stuff can happen to a character?  I couldn't even finish it.

Too graphic and explicit for my taste. Non stop action. Randall is developed too far in to a violent sociopath that feeds homosexual masochistic side to find love. Every character seems to be a Jekyll/Hyde personality with deviant ideas on love, family and loyalty. One hopes this was not representative of Scottish life In the 1700s. I realize it was hard, but this was not survivable.

I found this book several years ago in a public library. And let me tell you the characters in this book will stay with you for years. Their personalities are so strong and the storytelling so good that it makes every emotion palpable. This book made me laugh. sigh. and shake with fury. A must read for people who enjoy a good rollercoaster ride for what it is...delicious fun.

This book has everything; romance, laughs, history, cute guys with accents - you name it.  It was so rich with Scottish history that I made my husband read it - and he loved it.  It's not labeled "romance" but fiction, however, Jamie and Claire are one of those couples that haunt you long after you're finished reading.  Definately pick this one up if you haven't already.

I've never been so consumed by a book and its characters as I was with "Outlander". Diana Gabaldon is the greatest, and I'm hooked for life. I'm now halfway through "Dragonfly in Amber" and have the  other books of the saga waiting to be read next. Jaime Fraser is to die  for, and Claire and Jaime are of the greatest couples ever written about!

Usually I like books by, say, Margaret Atwood, Susan Sontag, etc. but I thought I'd give this a try although I am inclined to put down any book where men call women "wench" in jest (seems cheesy). But I was delighted for most of the book. The writing is excellent and the time travel was done so seamlessly I could suspend my disbelief even though I was trained as a scientist. However, I'm not from the generation that seems to have become immune to violence and suffering and the final villain scene left me with bad taste in my mouth. I want a novel to leave me with lingering pleasure. It jerked me out of the fictional dream and started me speculating about the psyche of the author.

There's soft-core porn tossed in -- here and there -- for just about every interest except bestiality I guess.  If those scenes had been wrapped by a coherent plot with believable dialog, I would probably have found them more than merely gratuitous.  After all the recommendations I really expected more.  At least there're no grammatical errors but there are a number of really jarring anachronisms that tended to throw me off just as I thought I might at last really get into the story.  Much is made of the idea of honor, but only for men and love is indistinguishable from violence; that's too bad.  I'm not going to be moving on to the next in the series.  Maybe the movie will be better.

Enjoyed the story but not the telling. I thought it was unnecessary to be sexually explicit so frequently. Once established that Claire and Jamie had an extremely passionate relationship an allusion to it only needed a lead in and not the detail. I am currently reading the 2nd book in the series as I did really enjoy the plot - I'm skimming the bits aforementioned and that's working for me. I'm not a prude by any means but the sexual content was all a bit too overstated, less is more you might say.
I've already read the book, and wanted to get a used copy for a friend to check it out. It was a little warn, but knew it would be used. Hope my buddy loves the story like I do!

This was one of the most fabulous and engrosing books I have ever read. I think the problem some people have with it, is that it is life, not typical of a romance novel. The violence is part of life, as is the humor, the  intrigue, the history, and the sex. Don't expect a bodice ripper, because  you will be shocked! But read it! You won't be sorry.

I had heard such great things about this series, but I am finished after the one.  By, the middle of the book all I could think was, "Really? Rape. again." or "You don't say, they are in mortal peril. again." It was just too repetitive for me and I found it gorier than necessary. How many times do we have to relive in detail the various torture scenes?  I didn't mind the time travel. I found the characters interesting. I like historical fiction. I like trashy romance. I like thought provoking characters and intriguing plots.  But, this book just didn't do it for me. I kept getting bored with all the running for their lives and wanted more of the boring home life.
I kept waiting for something to happen.  Bland writing.

Claire and Jaime are so well developed as characters.  I loved them both.  Jaime was such a gentle lover but rugged warrior.  Clair was strong, independent, and intelligent.  I loved the scottish brogue in this book.  The history was great too.  I loved Scotland all over again.  I immediately read Dragofly in Amber.  Both books were wonderful.

I can't think of any novel I have enjoyed more in recent years than Outlander.  I found the prose to be lush and expressive and the pace, breathless.  I have read several critical reviews concerning Diana Gabaldon and heartily agree with those who called her books "Harry Potter for grownups" or compared her to Dickens -- my thoughts exactly.

I do not read romance novels. Not that I am opposed to romance, but a lot of the novels are vapid junk. I do like historical fiction. My friend in a book club recommended this to me. I really enjoyed it, and couldn't wait to get on with the series. It is a fun book and I recommend it for anyone who likes adventurous historical fiction novels.

Very well-written, and an interesting story, but just being real: too much romance for my tastes. There is a wedding/bedding scene that goes on for chapter after chapter, and I think there are readers that eat that kind of stuff up and readers like me that are like "do we REALLY need to go into this much detail?" I am the latter!
Just awful. Long, boring and historically inaccurate.

This is one of those books that so many people seem to love, a book that is supposedly head and shoulders above its competition.  And that may indeed be true, because the competition for this book is really crappy romance novels.  Really, take any trite romance novel, throw in some very forced time travel, add a dash of research to give it a veneer of historical verisimilitude, and you've written a Diana Gabaldon book.  When I realized that I was waiting for it to start wrapping up because I wasn't sure how much more I could take, only to discover that I was not yet halfway through the book (I was reading it on a digital reader), I just had to put it down.  Maybe it got better in the second half, or maybe it had a great ending that somehow redeemed the first half, but BROTHER, was that a slog! One of the most overrated books I've ever (halfway) read.

Hated it. Hated it. Hated it. The author started with a great concept and potentially great characters, but that was soon lost. After slogging through a couple hundred pages, I drew the line when Claire sees the Loch Ness Monster. I wanted to throw the book across the room and down a wormhole never to be seen again

A great beginning to one of the best romance adventure novels in decades. 'Outlander' is what started it all and this being the anniversary of the release, I was happy to dive back in at the start. You won't regret the time spent. Diana is a wonderful author with vivid details poured into every emotion.

I dinna like it verra much, but embarrassingly enough I give this glorified Harlequin romance bodice ripper 3 stars since it was so entertainling I made it through to the end. Thank god I don't feel compelled to read the numerous sequels! I look forward to watching the tv series, though! Sam Heughan!

Engaging, exciting, romantic, realistic characters, and the history is even somewhat accurate!  I loved this book, and devoured the remainder of the series.  Not to give it away, but this book is after the happily ever  after, and a satisfying read for anyone who is in love (or wants to be)

This is one of those series everyone seems to have read years ago except for me.  It is what I read in between my "literary" adventures-- but what an adventure it is.  Time travel, Scotland, History, Love... The whole series is a lot of fun.  Very escapist.  Definitely not for teens.

With out a doubt one of my most favorite books! The series is excellent, alot of historical content and a good storyline. Have never been a big fan of time travel books  but Outlander was so good I had to have the whole  series.  One you read it you will never forget Jamie and Claire

Wonderful book! I must have them all! Couldn't put it down, fell in love with the characters. A real page turner! If you're looking for books with history, romance, a little time travel, this is it. Very well written. I'm hard to please, but Diana Gabaldon really has me addicted!

The only reason I am giving this book three stars and not four is the graphic sex scenes.  I really enjoyed the story line and the history, but I felt like I was reading a cheap romantic novel.  I will probably not read the other books for that reason, which disappointments me.

I read Outlander when it was new, and remember being carried away by it. I also remember thinking that maybe the compelling aspects of the story weren't worth struggling through the deeply unpleasant parts. Rereading now with a friend from work, I find Gabaldon's first novel too long, overstuffed, and more than a little disturbing in its fetishization of rape. The strength of it lies in her penchant for characterization--Claire, Jamie, the brothers Mackenzie, Jack Randall, and the rest of the cast of thousands come alive in a way that makes it nearly impossible to put the book down. Perhaps this is why the sadism of the Randall plot line and the disturbingly blurred boundaries throughout--between love, aggression, desire, consent, and increasingly brutal violence--left such a scar on my first reading, 20 years ago: the book is, on more than one occasion, painful to read, but the characters are so compelling that they stick with you, and you want to know what's in store for them. If it had been a movie, I'd have watched it through my fingers, staring only at a corner of the screen until I was reasonably certain there would be no more terrible images of brutal violation and pain. As it stands, even reading quickly (unlike the author, I had no desire to linger on the lovingly sketched portrait of Jaimie's torture) can't completely obscure the poison that runs through a story that is otherwise enticing, if sorely in need of a editor. The growing love between Claire and Jamie is gripping, as are the adventures, the list of which is surely too long. But it's the sadism--the extent to which author, antagonist, and hero alike revel in breaking human beings both literally and figuratively--that held the tightest grasp on my memory. Rereading it now has done nothing to lessen that.

Okay, first of all, for those who don't seem to understand that this book IS a romance, check the section!  I am a fan of both romance and fantasy fiction.  I am also a history buff.  This series has all of that!  True, there are some descriptions that are quite graphic, a few things I found questionable (but this is from MY viewpoint, not Claire's), and Claire is a little dislikeable.  But I thought the first person writing gave the series an interesting edge, especially since the character is nothing at all like me!  And of course, as so many others have admitted, I have a bit of a crush on Jamie.  I found all of the characters to be well developed.  Voyager was the first of the series I read.  It was in a bunch of books given to me and although it sounded interesting, it was the last of the bunch that I picked up, because I don't do thick books (they cause problems if they are hard to put down...like this whole series).  When I realized there were two prequels and a sequel in the works, I bought and read Outlander and Dragonfly in Amber and read Voyager again while I awaited Drums of Autumn.  I intend to read them again before the next release.  I have also gotten my mother hooked on the series.  I researched some of the general history and found it accurate, which was wonderful.  I am a descendant of the clan MacKenzie who is into geneological studies.  I'm still working on the accuracy of that one.  I did find all of the exquisite detail inspiring as well as interesting.  Some folks may think it's filler, but it's well researched!  As an aspiring author, I am totally jealous of Ms. Gabaldon's writing talents and imagination and the patience it must've taken to research these books.  This series is well-written and blended wonderfully to allow all facets of fictional writing to shine.  It may be a romance, but I'd recommend it to any man who likes adventure.  I eagerly await the release of the fifth book.

When I was a little girl, I remember sitting in the back seat of our station wagon while watching my mother sitting in the front passenger seat reading one of her romance novels.  I always asked her whether she was reading a good book, to which she almost always replied, "it's alright . . . but it's pretty much like all the others."  I always wondered why she bothered . . . after all it seemed like a horrible waste of time.  When I was older, however, I found that what she said was basically true . . . romance novels are pretty much just the same book but with different covers and characters with different names.  But, after reading Ms. Gabaldon's work, I believe that a new trend in romantic literature has arisen.  The only book that I like better in this genre is "Gone with the Wind" for one simple reason . . . with Scarlett I knew what motivated her while with Claire I wasn't quite sure what she was about.  Since, for the most part, she wasn't very interesting, I never really cared about her (I didn't want her to die, I just wanted her to be more exciting and three dimensional).  On the other hand, I really liked how the character of Jamie was set up for development.  As a reader, I saw constant and detailed instances of how and why he was the man he was in the story e.g. very specific and detailed flash-backs in his life.  I also say "Bravo" to a wonderfully complex villian in Randall. He was not merely a storybook cliche. I was left wondering how he grew into the cruel man he became and what exactly was his relationship with his brother Alex?  I also loved to hate Dougal -- he was a hoot! I didn't know if I wanted to have him slapped, shot, kissed or spanked, but I do know that I would have volunteered for any of the four.  I really enjoyed Geillis too.  I thought the part where Claire sees the small-pox vaccination when Geillis sacrafices herself was really quite memorable.  I would recommend this book to people who enjoy history, romance, or just plain old escapis! m.  It is a wonderful story.

This story is well written with amazing detail, vivid characters, and of course my new favorite hero, Jamie Frazer. I've already started on the second book in the series and strongly recommend this book if you are looking for a great romance or if you enjoy history.

This is a book which makes you feel like Diana Gabaldon is your best friend.  She must have written it for me because few books draw me in like this one.  I hesitated because it is long, but I'm so glad I read it.  My recommendation?  ->  It's summer - dive in!

"Outlander" is one of the most compelling, absorbing books I have ever read.  I just couldn't put it down!  Claire and Jamie are so well drawn, so REAL, that it is sometimes hard to remember "Outlander"  is a work of fiction.  If you like a strong story, fascinating  characters and a romantic setting - you will love Outlander.

Unusual setting and plot but I find the main character shallow.  I can see why this series is selling like crazy due to her  "relationship" with Jamie.  The writing style is lacking in depth, and I can't get myself interested in reading on.  Sorry I bothered!

The author describes characters in extreme detail so you really care about them. However when the main male character beats his wife and this seems to be acceptable, was upsetting. Also the complete lurid description of the sex scenes borders on pornography.

I listen to Audibles when I drive, travel, or walk for exercise. Months ago, I got a freebie that seemed to go along with my favorite theme -- time travel. It was 60 hours long and I thought I would finally listen on the train ride from New York to Denver. Four hours into it, I was getting very confused. Claire was a grandmother. Her daughter who was conceived in the 18th century had lived with her husband in the 20th century. Could a 60-hour long listen be part of a series? I wondered. I stopped the book in its fourth hour and discovered that I was listening to book 6! I had extra Audible credits and ordered *The Outlander* and haven't listened back since May. I am now 1/5 through the fifth book and am looking forward to finally getting to *A Breath of Snow and Ashes*. *The Outlander* series is everything I love in fiction -- time travel (in small doses with little woo woo about it), historical fiction, these two being my favorite genres; romance; comedy; and fantastic absolutely poetic writing. I am so happy that some eclectically educated college professors have turned to writing fiction (see also *A Discovery of Witches* by Deborah Harkness). I've been an adjunct instructor at a community college for 20 years in addition to a freelance dissertation coach and can only hope I might be able someday to add to the universe of literature. Meanwhile, I will be immersed in *Outlander* for months to come (I am traveling to Scotland in a few weeks!)... I am reviewing the series on a book site though I listen to Audible or sometimes follow along in a book because I just ordered the book for my mother and sister.

I too read this book because of the number of excellent reviews. It was a quick read (for 850 pages!), but it was not one of the greatest books I've ever read. I could go with the story up until the last 150 pages - the  torture/redemption bit was just too much. It was disturbing and not what I  expected from an escapism novel.

I took this book with me on vacation and could not put it down.  Ms. Gabaldon has done a fabulous job of telling the time travel story with so many twists and turns.  If you want an easy book to read to get away from it all....pick up Outlander!

I was hooked on this series right from the get go. Diana Gabaldon has all but ruined me for other authors. She has an amazing ability to keep me mesmerized throughout the book(s). I wish I knew how she did that! I hope she never stops writing.

"MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS" The adventures while exciting in some places are simply unbelievable. While the heroine's character is mostly likeable I can't get over the fact that she completely gives up on her 1st loving husband (Frank) for this young Scottish hero (Jamie). I have read other books in the series as well and in one of them she is forced to return to her modern life to save her unborn child by Jamie. Frank takes her back, baby and all, but her reaction to Frank's attention (indifferent and arrogant enough to say "I loved you ONCE" and "You may divorce me") and her decision on their state of marriage are annoying and frustrating. Who could blame Frank when he is driven to have affairs. This goes on even though Frank stays with her for the next 20 yrs and she believing that Jamie is dead. This makes her character questionable, to me. I can understand all the rave reviews. I would've given 5 stars too if I'm only focussing on Jamie/Claire love story and their incredible adventures, but it also matters to me how they deal with other people around them. In this case I consider Claire as being very selfish and unfair towards Frank. I can't like her. It would've been much better if she is back to being a wonderful wife to Frank as she was before, after all she believes Jamie is dead and Frank loves and dotes on her daughter and they remain married for another 20 yrs. This won't affect her story with Jamie because she only meets him again after Frank dies, but it would've tremendously improved her character in my eyes.

"Outlander" known as "Cross Stitch" in Australia, I believe a far more appropriate title given the time travel aspect, is the  first of Diana Gabaldon's novels of Claire and Jamie. As other reviewers  have noted, one must start the series with this one. Not only does it  outline the beginnings of their adventures together but it also shows how  the character of the author herself changes throughout. The book starts in  a typical English fashion where, during World War II, Claire is a nurse in  England being from a conservative English family with English mannerisms  and sense of etiquette. This is wonderfully portrayed throughout the first  novel but undergoes a wonderful change as you progress into the second and  third of the series, Claire rises from the almost staid woman of the first  novel to a woman not afraid of her passions. One can feel the effect Jamie  has on her, perhaps a sign of Gabaldon's own life changes. This is also  remarkable considering the fact that Gabaldon is herself American and yet  is able to show a certain "Englishness" which is very authentic,  not to mention her character portrayal of the Scots involved such as Jamie  or his Uncle. The aspect of magic and sorcery present in the time travel  and other fascinating incidences are presented more as natural forces  rather than any fantastical experiences you would expect from typical  fantasy novels, I think this also is something to be praised. A wonderful  book which I've read several times and will read again.

This was the third copy of the book I have had over the past 20 years.  Others never found their way back to me after being loaned.  If those who have the the book loved it as much as I do, I  am glad they kept it.  It is a tremendous book.

BEAUTIFULLY WRITTEN WITH STRONG, EXCITING CHARACTERS.  I'VE READ IT AND IT'S SEQUELS SEVERAL TIMES AND DRAW SOMETHING NEW FROM IT EVERYTIME.  DIANA GABALDON BY FAR EXCEEDS OTHERS IN HER FIELD.  I LOOK FORWARD TO ALL HER  FUTURE PROJECTS.

I guess I am one of the few who didn't find this book absolutely amazing. It was a pleasant way to pass the time and I was interested in finding out what happened in the end--but I wasn't totally consumed by it. The concept of the book is interesting enough: A woman from the 1940s gets transported back in time after stumbling through a cleft in a mini Scottish version of Stone Henge. Unfortunately, there were some parts that I just couldn't come to terms with. First, after Claire gets transported back in time, she just kind of rolls with it! There are a few times that she freaks out about it, but for the most part she takes it all in stride and is extremely calm about the whole thing. Honestly, she seems a bit one-dimensional. The fact that the book is written in the first person requires that the author be adept at expressing the characters inner thoughts and feelings. Gabaldon just didn't deliver on that. Perhaps she would have been better served writing in the third person. And, as if the magical time traveling stones aren't enough, the Loch Ness Monster also makes a cameo. Really? Finally, while there was a lot of detail in the book, I felt as though some of it was gratuitous and didn't add anything to the overall plot. Despite those misgivings, it was still enjoyable to read. After finishing the book, I liked it enough to get the second novel "Dragonfly in Amber" from the library. I'll probably finish the series--who knows, maybe it will get better and better with each book!

For someone who is not a native speaker of English, Gabaldon is a challenge but makes every effort worthy of a beautiful realistic but larger-than -life tale and love that everyone would want to experience. I loved every word of it ;]

I just finished this wonderful and exciting book and loved, loved, loved it! Excellently written. I felt like I was right there in 18th century Scotland. I'm off to find the rest of the series before the excitement wears off.
With all of the great reviews, I really tried hard to like this book but I just didn't. I got half way through and had enough.

The book and series were recommended by some friends of my Mum's and she went searching. Not really a "romance" kinda gal, the book store lady assured us--in glowing terms usually reserved for the most elite of movie stars and politicians--that these books were the read of the century. Well, she said the magic words to me--"time travel" and "Scotland." Hey, I'm there. What I was not prepared for was not only an action packed piece of historical fiction, but a hero that I fell in love with as well. There is something so unique and endearing about Jamie Fraser, that I couldn't help it. He is, in turn, the hard headed, pragmatic Scot of his time (1743) and the big, dumb, romantic kid with his wide eyed innocense of love and marriage. And his ability to whip out the one liners had me laughing hysterically. But this book is action from beginning to end as we, through Claire, discover life in the Highlands prior to the Culloden uprising. It was brutal and not at all the romance we've been led to know. Ms. Gabaldon has written an incredible piece with real characters performing real life and I was so caught up, I stayed up far too late to read. I was not disposed to put it down to sleep or eat. I doubt you will be either. I've started the next book in the series and the promise of holding me rapt is there as well. Bottom line...GET THIS BOOK!!! READ THIS BOOK!!!

Very romantic with realistic characters with whom I am always happy to spend more time. The TV show just adds to the pleasure, as the casting is good and I now have a clearer picture of the characters and setting.

This is an excellent time travel story that takes the reader away to a bygone era in Scotland.  A slow starting novel, but captivates the reader after  about 100 pages into the book. I was sad when it was over!

In this, my fourth reading of _Outlander_ I found that I was just as enchanted and caught up in the magic of Jamie and Claire as the very first  time I picked this book up.  And though there are over 500 reviews for this  book already posted, I just had to add my thoughts.  A good friend  recommended _Outlander_ to me well over a year ago and I was surprised and  dismayed that the book was nowhere to be found in my town.  I finally  hunted down a hardcover copy at the local library -- this thoroughly  surprised me because our library is sadly lacking in any sort of modern  books!.  I immediately checked it out and devoured it in roughly two days  -- stopping reading only to eat occasionally and sleeping even less.  I was  hooked -- here was a book which incorporated all the things I enjoy in a  romance novel:  time-travel, Scotland (I'm a sucker for a Scottish burr and  a kilt!), a heroine who is brave, strong and intelligent and a hero that  melts the heart and boggles the mind.  Promptly when I finished the book  the first time I turned right around and read it again -- it was *that*  good!  In _Outlander_ Ms. Gabaldon has set forth an epic story full of  love, honor, passion and steeped in history.  Yes, the reader is given a  good dose of history but is certainly not bored to tears -- Ms. Gabaldon  brings the action and the scenery to life and quickly you go from reading  about history to experiencing it almost firsthand.  I could almost smell  the heather of the Scottish Highlands as I read and each page I turned  pulled me more into the story.  Not only is the plot intriguing and the  history exhilarating, the characters are so well drawn that each person you  meet along the way seems as real as if they were standing right beside you.  I really related to Claire and though I was skeptical at first reading a  first person novel, I was quickly snared and started feeling part of the  story.  In Claire Randall Fraser, Diana Gabaldon has created the epitome of  a romantic heroine.  Faced with innumerable obstacles, Claire realizes that  a love worth having is worth risking anything for.  She faces the world  head on, courageously meeting each impasse and standing by her man no  matter what.  In James Alexander Malcolm MacKenzie Fraser, Ms. Gabaldon  created a romantic hero that is impossible not to fall in love with.  Any  man when faced with certain tragedies can be brave, but Jamie Fraser *is*  brave -- it's part of his core being and it fairly seeps from his pores.  His is an honorable, loving and giving person who takes what is handed to  him and through tragedy grows and becomes a better person.  No man should  have to face what Jamie faces in this book and as you read of his trials  and suffering at the hands of Black Jack Randall you will weep with him and  for him.  Perhaps it's crazy to say that you could fall in love with a  fictional hero -- but if ever there was a fictional hero worthy of love it  is Jamie Fraser.  I often become so immersed in a story that I have trouble  putting it down and continuing on with my day-to-day existence but with  _Outlander_ I put the world on hold and relished each and every word.  You'll have a difficult time pulling yourself away from this book until  you've successfully turned the last page -- and then you'll have trouble  deciding what to do first:  read it again or search frantically for the  other three novels in the series.
