If you read no other book in your life,  read _Outlander_.  It is a story that can capture the heart and the  imagination.  And in the end you're left with but a question:  How far  *would* you go for the one you loved?

Friends of mine kept telling me about these awesome books by Diana Gabaldon, but I could never find them in the store.  Finally I swallowed my pride (I like to think I know bookstores inside-out) and asked a clerk where the books would be.  When she said in the romance section I was not thrilled.  Sorry, no offense to romance readers, I just tended to lump all "those type" of books into great on "passion & pleasure" at an unrealistic level and weak on story line and value.  After purchasing a false mustache and glasses, I nonchalantly made my way towards the only unexplored territory in the bookstore...the ROMANCE section!!  Gotta tall ya, by the time I was half way through with Outlander I returned plainly and clearly to purchase the rest of Gabaldon's series.  I am HOOKED!!  Roamnce...yes.  Passion...oh yeah.  Historically acurate, amazing, amazing! character development, sights, sounds, smells...they jump out at you.  I lost myself in this book and in the books that follow.  I am so greatful that I took a step into the romance section and was so pleased to have discovered a series that gives readers all the passion they could want and throws in plenty of story line, character development, adventure, history and just pure MAGIC.  READ OUTLANDER and the rest of the series will find their way to you quickly!!

Omit the steamy and repetitive sex scenes in this book, and it would shrink from 600-plus pages to 200, and then might be readable. I only continued reading because I wanted to find out if there were other 20th century people tranported back to this only-in-the-author's-imagination 18th century Scotland. The last section, with Jamie's rape and subsequent rebirth, thanks to Claire's psychological sexual torture, rang false and offensive.

Tried my hardest to enjoy this book. I continued to find myself skimming than actually reading. Seemed to drag on for too long. I was hoping to be captivated, but was left wanting. Couldn't even finish it. Had to move on to another book to fill the void.
I started reading her years ago when she only had the first few books in the series... I could NOT put the books DOWN! If you are looking for a wonderful series to lose your heart to, here you go!

This book is the beginning of a fabulous journey with characters that have become like friends and family. The history and views into an era past are enlightening and most informative. I can't wait to begin the next volume in the "Outlander" series.
What an awesome book!  I hated to have to put it down (and get back to reality) and when I did put it down, I couldn't wait to get back to it.  I'm looking forward to getting into the next one!

This book is one of those rare stories that transports your soul into a place that just seems so far away that it couldn't be real. Outlander amazed me from the first chapter with it's complex and extraordinary plot. It's a romance, it's a mystery, it's a action, and it's historical stories all wrapped into one spell binding soul ripping story. You sink into your place as the main heroine Claire and you follow her life with her, as her, and deal with the difficult decisions that she has to face on a day to day basis in two worlds so different from each other yet in some ways so similar. You fall in love with Jamie Fraser and you love Frank Randall along with her and you decide with her what to do about all the hard decisions she has to make this this life that she was thrown into unexpectadly. By the end you have been on this amazing emotional roller coaster and what was a 800 odd page book that looked daunting when you bought it now seems like a part of your life and you are just waiting to start the next chapter of it. This series is amazing and I recommend these books to everyone I come acrossed. Sink into the world of Outlander and be captured by it's magical spell binding weave of words that only Diana Gabaldon could create.

Usually, I am the avoid the romance book section woman; thinking many books there are less prolific than my tastes - however I held my head up as I searched for Outlander!  Diane's treatment of the historical aspects and  the ties that bind it together from continents to timezones held me captive  once again!  My dear husband even encouraged and drove me to get the  hardback version of the book - as I have enertained him with read aloud  excerpts from the first few books.  I am again a selective reader  with precious time for two children and their books, husbands computer  manuals and my dry college textbooks; as a rule, I avoid trilogies or book  sets - choosing to think the first book is usually the most delcious and  having diminished appetites for consecutive efforts.  However, this is not  the case in Diane's gift to us with her ability to weave stories around  history and capture us into Clare's lifelong love story as it unfolds.  How long must we wait for the next episode to this fantastic journey?  Time does not matter where quality is concerned - patience and persistence  will grant us a passport to continue the lifelong quest for intrigue and  the deep commitment Diane grants us in her storytelling.
It was listed in the Kindle store as sci-fi or fantasy. There's only a couple of paragraphs about time travel. The rest of it is pretty much just a romance novel. I was pretty disappointed.

What makes this pornography is not the presence of graphic sex scenes, but the fact that the entire novel is driven by sex and is in fact nothing but one (tiresomely) long sexual fantasy. The only interest this book held for me as a heterosexual male was the insights it afforded into the nature of female sexuality. I found it interesting how naturally a woman's fantasies turn to men of the past: dirty, violent, scar-covered men with gentle, childish hearts and lots of stamina. Aside from speculations on a few legendary beauties from the pages of history, I don't think men have many sexual fantasies set in times before indoor plumbing was prevalent or Lady Schicks were invented; whereas the plucky heroine of this tale was clearly thrown 200 years into the past for no other reason than to get lucky.

So this was a book that had been recommended to me by a friend. I have to admit, I was slightly embarrassed to find it listed in the romance section, but was determined to read it anyway. I'm really glad I did. Barring the necessary sex passages that lovingly describe muscular loins, the book is really more historical than out and out romance. Claire Randall is a former combat nurse at the end of the second world war. Recently reunited with her husband, they are vacationing on the Bristish Isles when she is transported through a circle of stones to war battered Scotland. My one quip with what I otherwise thought was a very enjoyable (if not a bit too long) book, was the premise of her having two husbands in two very different times. Her husband is only in the first fifty pages of a nearly nine hundred page book. So unless he returns in later books, it's really her courtship and relationship with the Scotish warrior Jamie Fraser that the book is about. Still, I'm very curious to see where the series goes,  if her husband Frank returns, and where Claire and jamie will escape to next. For those who want an enjoyable escapist read ripe with sex and 'Braveheart' type violence, this is your book!

Bored me to tears, no characters that made me want to get to know them. I couldn't finish it, and as an avid reader that hardly ever happens! Only bought it after rave reviews from a friend and my mom, I just don't get the hype one bit.

I am a fan of time travel novels.  I picked up "Outlander" at a flea market recently.  When I got into the book I was riveted and fell in love with Claire and Jaime.  Claire's travel back to 18th century Scotland opens the reader up to a world of history that is fascinating and intriguing.  The love between Claire and Jaime Fraser is breathtaking and I found myself hoping she never returns to post-war Scotland.  I found that I didn't like Claire's present day husband all that much, especially after meeting Captain Randall in 18th century Scotland, an ancestor of her husband's.  Ms. Gabaldon's characters have such strength of character and courage, enduring the hardships of Scotland in the 18th century, it made me wonder what I ever have to complain about!  I was sorry to see this epic end.  The good news was when I went to amazon.com I found that this was the first of 4 books in the saga!  I order the other 3 books from amazon and I am now reading the second of the series, "Dragonfly in Amber".  Outlander is a fabulous book about the extraordinary courage of a woman and a romantic love that spans the centuries.  A must read for all lovers of historical, romance and time travel novels!

For the last 16 years I've believed I would never find a romance novelist that I enjoyed as much as Kathleen Woodiwiss.....but Diana Gabaldon has done the impossible!  I've read this 4 book series and my only regret is that I'm not able to erase them from my mind so that I can devour them again and again.  These books are jam packed with historical, cultural and scientific information, yet you are so spellbound by the characters that you aren't even aware that you're reading much more than a romance novel.  Jamie & Claire are so much more than characters in a book, they are REAL people.  The author's inate ability to bring them to life is beyond compare.  Once you begin reading, you will live and breathe their every moment with utter fascination and a resounding refusal to put the book(s) down.  No one's imagination could ever create a more perfect man than Jamie Fraser or a more perfect companion than Claire.  I can't even begin to hope that Ms. Gabaldon will be able to match much less surpass the sheer enjoyment her readers have been treated to in this series, but she has an incredible fan base throughout the world now and the pressure is on.  Diana....give us MORE!

I am a Romance writer myself. I started about six years ago and now am "on the verge" of being published. It annoys me when people put down Romance, especially Historical. It requires a lot of research to write a good one. OUTLANDER is just an example of some of the great ones that are out there. I looked down my nose at most until I was challenged to write one. It's damn hard to compete with doctors, lawyers, and Ph.D's (like Gabaldon). I was an English teacher and it's taken me 5 years to finally write a truly good one. It concerns a hero whose best friend is Wellington. Believe me these books are well researched. Gabaldon was reluctant at first to have the novel published under the Historical Romance list. But it was those readers who made her books sell. I liked the first two (second, DRAGONFLY IN AMBER). After those two I think the romance went out of the novel and they became repetitious. Also having the hero and heroine grow old in the fourth book dismayed me. There were so many devices she could have used to keep them young ( esp. in SF or Romance genre). I still think OUTLANDER is a well written and memorable work. Grace

I first read Outlander in 1991 when it was first published.  In anticipation of the upcoming STARZ Television series of Outlander set to premier on August 9, 2014, I wanted to also have the "tie-in" version of this wonderful novel by gifted story teller, author Diana Gabaldon.

Diana Gabaldon's Outlander series is an addictive, fantastic, engrossing journey into 18th Century Scotland, post-war England, and modern-day Boston. I must admit that I am not a fan of romance novels, but this series has me hooked; I have read all 5 of the books and the Outlandish Companion at least two times each. I have now introduced no fewer than five friends to the series. I consider it the thinking person's romance novel; it is well-researched, beautifully written, original, pithy and lusty. The sex scenes are realistic and fantastic without being gratuitous. The history is detailed and accurate, and full of enough information to satsfy even a gentleman's desire for action. The characters are well-drawn and human; one feels they really know these people. I discovered these books five years ago and never tire of picking up one and sitting down for a quick "visit". When Ms. Gabaldon wrote her first novel in the series, she had never even visited Scotland. But her incredible talent for writing has given her legions of fans from all over the world, all of whom wanted to know upon first reading the book "where in Scotland are you from?"
I thought the idea for this novel was original in that I haven't read too many time travel books however after the first 100 pages I just couldn't make myself read another page.

This is the best book I have EVER read, by far. It's a beautiful story with a little bit of everything. There is magic/fantasy, a little bit of sci-fi, it's historical, and it's a deep romance. The book thrilled me from beginning to end like no book or movie has ever done before. I cried, I got angry, I got stressed out and worried, and I got extremely happy and inspired by the thought of my life being as beautiful, exciting, and fulfilling as the lives of the characters in the novel. If any man wants to be the perfect love for a woman, read this book. It's not all about romance though, no way. It has a lot of psychological stuff in the book that will shock you. Men get raped and psychologicall y screwed up from it; there are many parts where people are so close to death.. and it puts you there in person.. the writing is so brilliant that you feel like you are there, watching what these people are going through while they are deathly sick, or experiencing various things. The main character is a nurse, so you go indepth into her knowledge and you learn a lot. It's just.. simply a brilliant novel and has elements that could please anyone. It's probably meant for a woman to read because the main character is a woman, but even men love the book. I highly recommend it, and in way, it has changed my life in the way I see and understand things. It's also made my standards of books go way up, which might be a bad thing hah.

Although it's been over a year since I finished Diana's third book, when the subject of "something good to read" came up at a business lunch today,  I found myself blabbing on and on about Claire and Jaimie.  I  saw my companion's eyes glaze over when I mentioned "romance" and  "time travel" but I hope I convinced her to try Outlander.  After  that she'll be hooked.  I too am a bit snobby about what I read and would  never stoop to buy anything with Fabio on the cover, but these books are  different.  I was unaware of my surroundings for days and read while  eating, dressing, walking, you name it.  I carried my book everywhere, even  in the car, just in case I'd have a spare second at a stop light.  When I  wasn't reading I was thinking about the characters.  I've been a voracious  reader for nearly 40 years and never had characters take up permanent  residence in my head the way Claire and Jaimie have. I've got to get to  Scotland some day!  I bought the 4th book, Drums of Autumn, some time ago  but am actually SAVING it for a special, long, luxurious weekend.  ENJOY!

When I started this I was prepared for a time travel..the kind I have been used to where the characters go back and forth in time. Unfortunately, to me, this was just another historical romance that did not really have much time travel...in fact none other than the beginning. I got to the last 100 pages, and was bored...never finished it...

Why I did not pick up this book earlier, I don't know (perhaps because of the daunting 850 pgs in the first book of a long series), but I absolutely loved the main character of Claire Beauchamp. I have found that it is nearly impossible to find a strong educated female main character in books, but Clair was a joy to read. As a World War II nurse all she wanted was to spend a quiet honeymoon with her husband Frank in the Scottish country side, but was transported two hundred years in the past (1743) where she had to learn to survive in one of the most dangerous and superstitious times in Scotland's history. While tangling with the evil "Black Jack" Randall she finds love with the wonderful Scottish Highlander James Fraser. Filled with scenes of action, intrigue, and romance this book was a fast read despite its length, and it did not forget to add the struggle of Highland life. Though the fight with Randall became a little too much at the end of this novel, I still cannot wait to read the next story to just enjoy the complex characters that Diana Gabaldon has cleverly created. This is a must read!

This book... is probably ruining my life. As a high school English teacher, I wake up very early, around 6am. When I started reading this book a few days before school started I had no idea the power it would have on me. It was like a vortex every time I opened the book. I carried this book everywhere just in case I found a few precious minutes to read. I found myself sitting at the copy machine... reading my book. When I was cooking dinner for my family, I did it with my book open. The last straw was when TWO NIGHTS IN A ROW I found myself climbing into bed at 9pm and staying up until 4am reading! Tired as I was the next day greeting my little smiling students' faces: I had a brilliant idea. Silent reading! Yep, I rearranged my curriculum to allow me to spend 20 class minutes three times a day to read this book all under the guise of having students practice reading. I have literally gone delirious reading this book. I have read very, very few books that totally enrapture you during the time you're reading them. Read this book at your own peril. You might end up not sleeping for about a week.

I loved this book. I laughed and cried. I will say there is some very disturbing sexual violence, but it is a very small section of a beautifully written book. I feel like I actually visited 18th century Scotland.
I've never read a Harliquin romance, but I imagine it would be like this, only way shorter.  The historical bits were good.  Otherwise, three stars is the most I can go.
A little heavy on the sex, graphic and innuendo...seems unnecessary to a reasonably good story.  Apparently, all the Scots and British do is fight and roll in the hay.

Just finished this one, and have moved on to the next in the series.  It had me in it's clutches until the last 200 pages.  and I won't give any more away, for fear of spoiling it for those who haven't read it.  All I will say is that apparently I'm more sensitive than others, and there's only so much rape and pillage I can stand.  on the other hand, to say "i'm hooked" puts it mildly.  I was up until 3:00am finishing this one, it's hard to put it down.  The author has quite an imagination, and the amount of historical research that went into this is mind boggling.  I found myself falling in love with Jamie.  There were times I laughed out loud, and times I cried.  and the person who suggested the book to me, didn't bother to tell me about the huge amount of hot sex in the story.  I quite often felt the need for a smoke and a drink after finishing a chapter.  The violence of war aside, this is one of the best books I've ever read.  But I"m only giving it 3 stars because of my aversion to so much ugliness in times of war.  All that being said, I highy recommend it.
I wasn't sure what to expect from the book, but it was amazing. I could not put the book down and have moved on to the second one. Would recommend this to everyone.

An escape adventure and love story beyond anything I have ever read.  Absolutely love this series, it's author Diana Gabaldon and can not wait for august 9th when starz starts this series!  Love, love, love
Basically, a story of sexual encounters with some other storylines thrown in.  If you are into "mommy porn," like 50 Shades of Grey, you will like this.

I wanted to like this book. And for a while I really did. At first I ignored some of the more graphic scenes and just skipped over them. But it got to the point where they were just so nasty and so many, I just couldn't read it anymore. The story itself is great. The writing is great. But there is a lot of swearing by the main character. Still I might have ignored that as she was an army nurse and also very fiery. What I couldn't ignore is the x-rated love/rape scenes. I wish the author had been more subtle. Some people apparently like this kind of book, but I would strongly caution women against this sort of thing. I quit reading when the male character, whom I had mostly admired for his gallantry, told the main character that he was going to take her if he wanted to, that he was going to be rough, and that he wanted her to call him master. At first she protests, but is apparently overcome by passion even though it hurts her. Ummm, this is just not something I wanted to put in my head. I closed the book and was done. Sad really.

I have read all six of the Outlander series several times.  Diana Gabaldon is an extraordinary writer, imaginative, talented, and extremely creative, and the overwhelming response to her stories is indicative of her talents in this genre.  She has interwoven romance, history, and adventure into a mesmerizing tale which captures the attention of the readers, holding them spellbound and breathless as each page is turned.  Her writing has inspired many, including myself, to learn more about Scotland and the people who lived/live there, their way of life, their haunting music, traditions, and history.  I note that one of the reviews (2 stars) was critical of the male/female views of that era in Scottish history.  Too bad that reader didn't read the entire series as she missed out on a great adventure.  One should not take it personal that the values of that era included "ownership" of the wife; that ownership also included protection and security, of which many current wives do not now have.  I rate the Outlander series with 5 stars.

I literally stumbled onto this book while surfing the Amazon website.  I read the sneak preview and I was hooked!!  I immediately ordered all the books in the series, including the companion and Lord John's Private Matter.  So far, I have read the series twice.  The first time reading so fast trying to find out what happened next, then the second time to savor each word.  I must say Diana Gabaldon has become one of the primary authors in my library.  I will certainly continue to be a great fan of hers.  I am impatiently waiting--probably with many others!--for her next installment either to the Outlander series, or Lord John's series.  The books are very thoroughly researched for the historical period featured in her books, but presented in such a way they are all page-turners.  Jamie and Claire, along with Brianna and Roger, show how true love should be enjoyed.  Even with the period hardships they show through.  All the adventure, romance, history and laughter you would ever desire are in the Outlander series.  Enjoy!!

I bought this book at our local pharmacy, thinking it would be a book to leave in the car to read while waiting for the kids at their various activities....Boy, was I wrong!  Although it started off a little slow, once Claire passes through the stones and meets Jamie, I could not put the book down. I enjoyed it more than many of the books I have read in a long time....and believe me, I read alot!!.  I gave it to a friend to read, who told another friend, who told another, and another, and another......As a result, Ms. Galbaldon is now a favorite of ours.  We have read all four books in the series, but this is the one that is continuously read and re-read over and over again.  I enjoy her discriptive style, and the information about Scotland thrown in for good measure. Perhaps some will say the whole concept is a little far-fetched--time travel, the numerous dangerous situations Claire and Jamie find themselves in, etc.  But do not let this sway you from reading this book...you will not regret your decision.

I was introduced to these books by a friend and am now forever grateful.  I am 18 years old and, upon getting into "Outlander" I immediately fell in love, not only with Jamie and Claire, but with the entire overall feel (that's not the right word...) of the story. Ever since then I have done extensive research of my own into Scotish history and done several school projects on the Risings.  (Both the '15 and the'45)  I find myself being taken back through time and living every moment in the story as it was happening to me.  Any author who is able to do this to my emotions is truly amazing.  Right now I am on "Drums of Autumn".  I waited so long for this to come out in paperback!  I love it.  However, despite Claire's feelings toward Jamie's possible return to Scotland, I really hope the story leads back to the rocky highlands.  I will say no more though, I won't ruin it for any of the readers out there.  Recommend this to your friends, read it youself...you will truly be amazed!
Terrible, terrible, terrible.  It seems like I am the only one with this opinion.  But I only made it about 1/4 of the way in before I abandoned this book.

In celebration of the newest novel in the Outlander series (Written in My Own Heart's Blood) finally being released I am re-reading the entire series from start to finish in order to come to the new novel with everything fresh in my mind. Reading Outlander for the second time was just as good as the first, maybe even a tiny bit better. I even felt like I was able to take in everything even more efficiently because I had context. So, while I remembered all the major events of the book, I was able to spend more time on the smaller details this time around. Not being so eager to know what will happen next makes re-reading the novel that much more enjoyable. For newbies, this is a great read sweeping, panoramic, epic, and exciting. I am NOT a romance reader in general, usually romances bore me to tears or make me hate myself. I think of this series of books as a great time traveling adventure, with an unforgettable romance as the center. A must read for anyone interested in the 18th century.

Not that I can say anything that 2000 other people haven't already said, but these are the BEST BOOKS EVER!!!  I have read them all, and eagerly await the new ones.  As a student teacher, my cooperating teacher was discussing this "handsome man" that she couldn't get enough of....I told her I'm single...I'd like to meet him!  She said "No problem".  The next day she brought me this book.  Needless to say I was surprised, but man, I have never looked back.  I love their story.  Diana is a brilliant writer.  She mingles, steamy romance, time travel, and history together in a way no other writer has!  I have laughed and cried with Jamie and Claire on their adventures.  I have never been able to get over the foreshadowing she's done in the beginning of this book.  A regular reader misses it...I know I did.  I had to go back after I was finished and read it again!  If you are looking for a good book...read this.  But know, you'll be digging out some cash for the rest of them!  They are great!

Second reading--20 years apart. Spurred by the TV series, don't miss this book. It seems as the apparent first time-travel-to-old Scotland that many other romance authors soon pursued, it stands above them. It is not just a love story, 'tho it is. It's not just a SCIFI story, 'tho it is. It's just not a historical fiction, 'tho it is. It is much more, more complete, more complex, more deeply explicated than the usual short novel.  Look at the size of the thing!  It's not fluff, either. It is the first of 8 deeply anticipated books telling the life story of Claire and Jamie. But don't "fash ye self", it's not puritanical. Sex is a part of life and romance and history, and the author does include intimate (and not so intimate!) encounters. The story is too vital to be Bowlderised. I greatly recommend you go to the bathroom first, stock up on liquid refreshment and snacks, find the most comfortable chair you own, and climb right into Ms. Gabaldon's world-in-a-book!
These novels are addictive.  I have read this whole series several times, and eagerly await the release of the next every time I finish the last!
Bodice ripping, chest heaving, etc etc. it just need Fabio on the cover. If you like this type of stuff, you might like it. I was hoping for more.

Outlander is one of my all time favourite books (and I have read many!).  The unique blend of  characters(with tremendous depth) provides a wonderful and witty dialouge as well as make the book come to life.  The  story of a modern woman (that is 1940's moden-but she thinks more along the  lines of 90's)having to live in 18th century Scotland where everyone is  alien to her and where her  intelligence as well as her loyalty to her  husband are put to a test (married woman has a thing for Scottish man,  Jamie.  But hey! she's in the 18th century and hubby hasn't even been born!  Is it right or wrong?). This novel is well worth reading, there are  wonderful glimpses of life in that wonderful time, the traditions, the  beliefs,and the society are viewed through the eyes of an outsider or  outlander and you along with her come to love it.  It is filled with  romance, intrige, humour, feuds, and tragidy.  It is a long read but never  a boring one.
One of the best books I ever read!  I felt as though I were there in every step of Claire's journey.  Ca  hardly wait to read all of the sequels.

I'm so excited to find this series!  I didn't think I would really enjoy this genre but I heard a good review on NPR ( they were talking about it in the context of the new show on Starz which recently came out) and some friends told me they loved it so I bought the first book...wow.  The author is very skilled at writing historical fiction that transports you there, romance that doesn't come off as cheesy or torrid, and making you fall in love with and empathize with her characters and her world.  I'll be honest parts of the book are disturbing, and the most beloved characters are really put through the wringer...but it just makes you feel like you know them deeper and care and root for them even more.  I'm so excited to read the whole series now, though books that keep me up all night are very dangerous as I have to work and have three young children!  But I'll take it...it's been a few years since a book series so thoroughly drew me in!

I am a guy that likes reading fantasy, sci-phi and historical adventure novels. This book was recommended by my wife, and though it is referenced as a romance novel, it is way more than that. It is written of a woman who travels back in time and meets a rugged Highlander in the 1700's around the time of Bonnie Prince Charlie (fore and aft). It is historical, brutal, graphic, and keeps you on the edge of your seat. It can be enjoyed by both men and women, though my wife found a couple torture scenes a bit to graphic for her taste. It is incredibly well written and leaves you wanting more, but if you find graphic scenes of a sexual nature not to your taste, you will have to skip over sections of this book. This is a relatively thick book, but you find yourself tearing through it rather quickly, and time will seems to pass rather quickly. I am currently reading Dragonfly in Amber, and it is just as well written as this book thus far.

I'm sure that my little review won't mean much against the other 1000+ reviews, but I just had to have a say.  I am an avid reader and practically devour most historical fiction novels.  But once I've read them, that's it, I'm done.  Not the Outlander series.  I first read Outlander and Dragonfly in Amber when they were first published.  I recently re-read them and have continued on to the other novels in the series.  I can't get enough.  I never want them to end.  I never want to stop reading them.  I will re-read them over and over forever.  They are the richest, most engaging novels I have ever read and every time I read them I am blown away by Dianna's ability to describe what she sees and makes her readers understand the complexities of the situation and human emotion.  If you read only one novel in your lifetime...make it Outlander (and the remaining books in the series).  You won't be disappointed.

Granted I am not into the romance or erotica books.  I got interested after seeing a few of the episodes on starz.  I wanted to read the book, because I wanted a better understanding of who's who.  I read halfway through the book before putting it down, wanting to never read it again.  Halfway through the book, it does become repetive and I think unneccessary.  I've read the Twilight series.  If only they were this sexually active! I also wanted to read this because of the similarity I felt between this book and A Game of Thrones, what with the medeival brutality and hardships, but as I said, I couldn't make it.  But the show does follow the book faithfully, from the amount I've seen and read.  Granted there is sexual content in A Game of Thrones, but it is not the focal point, but then again, it's not a romance novel either.  Maybe I should just skip a few chapters and see what happens. lol.

Little did I know how great this book was going to be! It was recommended to me by a friend whose opinion I respected, so I finally picked up a copy. The copy that arrived had the original published cover and I have to say it said "Cheap and Tawdry Bodice Ripper" to me... I was skeptical... The new cover is far more intelligent looking and cryptic as to the contents. So, I proceeded and I was glad I did! Not cheap at all - historic and intelligent. And just enough 'tawdry" to keep it  fabulous and fun. Now I see that there are online clubs based around this series and I see why. Diana Gabaldon is a fun, interesting and adept writer that has created a tale I am in love with. I am now reading the second book "Dragonfly in Amber" and loving it.  - and I am a die hard non fiction fan! But thank goodness there are some fiction books out there that are worthy escapist fare
This is pulp fiction, scary, ubiquitous, corny fantasy. Thought I liked it at first, but only made it half through. Waste of time.

I am Scots-obsessed to begin with, so when I saw tartan on the cover and  "Scottish Highlands" in the synopsis I bought it without a second  thought.  It turned out to be the only book that's made me laugh out loud,  cry real tears then hunt through my history books and maps for MORE.  Needless to say, I have lent it to others who have become more obsessed  with the series than I and the last person didn't return it!  A special  thank you to Ms. Gabaldon who usually rolls into our town on her tours  right around my birthday.  As a result, my copies of "Voyager"  and "Drums of Autumn" made wonderfully autographed gifts from my  husband (my own Jamie).  My only disappointment came when I stepped inside  a stone circle near Inverness and managed to remain in present day!!  Looking SO forward to more!

I have spent most of my life avoiding "romance" books, since I consider them to be a complete waste of time. They actually suck intelligence out of your brain as you read them. That being said, I wholeheartedly enjoyed "Outlander" and "Dragonfly in Amber" by Diana Gabaldon, the first two books in what appears to be a five book series. Actually, I don't believe that the books should be classified as "romance," because the characters are too realistic and the historical details are too enjoyable. The science-fiction flourish also distinguishes this series from mere "romances." Jamie and Claire are the kind of people you would like to have as friends, they aren't mere puppets of the author going through formulaic motions. Buy Diana Gabaldon's books. Read them. You will enjoy them

I first started reading this book because of a recommendation from a friend.  I started it, and after the first two chapters or so, I couldn't put it down.  The characters came alive to me, and I couldn't wait to see how the plot was going to turn out.  I'm not a fan of romance novels, however, so I'm loathe to call this book a romance, but I guess if you boil it down, it is.  But I must say that it has many non-romance characteristics.  There is plenty of action, and the characters aren't thouroughly predictable, as I have heard they are in many "normal" romances.  Also, Claire, the main character, isn't the swooning female in distress.  She is very much a woman who knows what she wants, and will do whatever she has to in order to survive.  It is a wonderful book, and a wonderful beginning to the Outlander Series.
This is a book everyone should read! A classic, highly addictive story, can't say enough, rush out and get your copy today!!!
This was basically about riding thru the woods and having sex --- both of which are legitimate reading but if there is nothing more it becomes boring.

I enjoyed this story immensely as long as it was a story. Every time it turned into a sexually oriented creative writing assignment, I felt like I had to soldier through to get back to the story. I enjoy well written erotica but the sex scenes here were tedious to read. There were so many words to muddle through. The more the author flexed her quill with sexual images, the muddier her writing became. Perhaps it's because this book was written in 1991 and what is written here is typical of the genre from the early 1990s? I can't say because I don't read 25 year old romance novels as a general rule. I read this book in anticipation of watching the TV series and I think the TV series will be much more enjoyable because the sexual imagery won't include the authors portfolio of overly dramatic orgasmic descriptions.

This book is one of the finest i have read in a very long time. I am 17 years old. It was my mythology teacher who turned my friends and I onto this book, and now it seems our entire school is obsessed with it. It is impossible to put down. After borrowing my cousin's copy to read, i had to buy my own so i could read it over and over again. The only bad thing about this book is that it is virtually impossible not to become obsessed with the story. All of my friends and I are in love with Jamie and want to travel to Scotland to see if such men truly exist. It is not merely a romance, though romance is involved. It is more of an adventure story. I would've given this novel more than 5 stars, had i been able to. Gabaldon is brilliant, and i highly reccomend this book, as well as the others in the series.
This book was terrible. I couldn't even give it 1 star. Poorly written, boring, unimaginative & I would not recommend it.
I Never write reviews, however I just had to say how I found this double crossing self centered heroin simply UNBEARABLE!
I have read this book so much I had to buy a second copy.  It's a wonderful book, as are all the others in this series.

I usually don't read this kind of literature, but I have to say it was pretty good. However, to be honest without the TV show I would probably never decide to read this at all. The first thing ill say is that this book truly cant be categorized under one heading.It crosses over so many genres and really to label it would take away from the magnificence of the book.I do not know how many male readers would feel the same way I do after reading this but I must say I was blown away by the raw emotion and heart of the story.Anyone who truly enjoys reading should do themselves a favor and read this book.The author Diana Gabaldon has ascended into the pantheon of my favorite authors with just me having read this one book by her.I think I hear the next book in the series calling my name....

I read this book for the first time 11 years ago. It had been recommended to me many times, because I love big long reads and I love history. I don't like time-travel:) or I did not until this story. I love the way the words are put together: the relationships of the words and the descriptions of the time and place changed the way I looked at popular fiction and I am a much more discerning reader as a result. In the beginning I loved the book because it was the story of a marriage, not just a romance, but an actual long-term relationship and I stand by that now. There are many layers to the tale and each re-reading reveals another. Claire Elizabeth Beauchamp and James Alexander Malcolm Mackenzie Fraser and all of their connections take root in your imagination and never let go!
After all the hype of this book, when I actually sat down and read it, it was not at all what I expecting. A let down.

I bought Outlander a couple years ago at a Heathrow airport newsstand,  to take my mind off the flight I was about to get on.  That day  there had been terrorist threats somewhere and I was convinced that I was going to die.  But by the time the plane left the runway I was totally engrossed in the novel, and hardly realized I was on a plane the entire flight home.  Diana Gabaldon writes books which can instantly transport you to another time and place, as quickly as magically walking through ancient standing stones.  I probably would not have bought Outlander if I had realized it was a romance novel, as I had never read one before out of embarrassment.  But now I am very grateful for my mistake, and I have enjoyed the following books in the Outlander series very much
Well written, warmly romantic and full of fabulous history!  It draws you in and keeps you there - tough to put down!

When I first received this book from one of my friends, I'll admit, I was a bit intimidated.  I flipped to the back and noticed it was 600+ pages...  Not being one to turn down a challenge, I immediately starting reading it.  What a joyous day.  Gabaldon tells the story of Claire and Jamie with such detail.  I literally dreamed about these characters!  I have never read another book that so completely captured my attention as those in the Outlander series.  I am nearing the end of the third book, Voyager, and it's just as wonderful as the first.  (No boring sequels here)  And I can't begin to express how tickled I was to find that there is a fifth novel!  I rue the day when I finish the Outlander series and have to revert back to my old dime store romance novels.
Too much violence against women, too much ignorant, boorish behavior, too much violence against children. I would not recommend this story.

I love romance, adventure and/or time travel books.  But I was very disapointed in this book.  The violence was just too much for me to take.  There should have been a warning about the graphic descriptions of rape and  torture.  I found it not only unnecessary, but very distracting to what  could have been a really good story.
I kept wanting to reach through the book and slap the heroine!  She was so needy and whiny.  Heck - she even stayed with the guy after he publicly beat her.  I did not enjoy the story at all.
Hokey drivel.....

I had a friend who kept urging me to read this book. She finally gave me a copy.. I felt obliged to at least try it then. Time travel, 17th century, Scotland,800 plus pages..oh dear that sounded boring. The 3rd chapter in I was so annoyed by the scotish accents having to read things over and over... Convinced I was going to be giving this book back and reporting that it just waaant for me, I continued to read... Oh it is such a good well written amazing book. I became so engrossed in it... Seriously lost in a book. I've recently read 50 shades hunger games series... So it was hard to read such a deep book at first. I have not been so lost in a book since island of the dolphins when I was 10 years old! Amazing. Read it. Read it. I urge u!

I read Outlander and got so involved with the amazing, well writen story that I got the next five books in CDs so I could do chores and driving. I am finishing book # 5 and looking forward to # 6 An Echo in the Bone. How can anybody write almost 6000 pages and keep track of everybody. I think Diana Gabaldon is a phenomenal writer a phenomenon in her own kind. Listening to Devina Porter reading it, you feel transported to the 18th century. You learn some of the Gaelic words, Scottish customs, you feel the joys and pains of each one of the characters. You get involved with Claire's surgeries. You feel the need to meet Jamie Fraser, Roger, Briana, Claire, Fergus, Ian and everybody else. It is really an amazing book and an amazing series.

Sorry - this was a GREAT book until I got to about 70% (per my Kindle). Then it went totally downhill. So much so that I could not sleep that night after reading it. I loved the storyline and it had wonderful potential. But that twist at about 70% through the book makes me rate the book at one star. It was THAT bad. It was a sickening, torturous book towards the end. That is really too bad because the author tells a good story with her words painting a perfect picture in the mind's eye of the reader. I just wish it would have stayed a time travel, mystery, or romance novel rather than turning into a twisted and violent crazed character's fantasies and sick desires (i.e., rape, torture). I was like WTH??? No more in this series for me.

I stayed through Outlander only because a family member urged me to. There were points when I just had to howl, the language was so silly...the heroine fantasizes about thehandsome Jamie--"He could ride me  anywhere."  But Gabaldon does have a turn of phrase and facility with  the language, and there's one point toward the end that frankly is  brilliant. It's a shame she doesn't put it to better use. It's all pretty  harmless except for her disturbing preoccupation with sodomy. Even if that  sort of thing happened a lot back then, the lines about kilt-clad men  having to watch their posteriors for fear of "buggery" got a wee  bit tiresome. When a "good guy" in the book is raped by another  man--who feels a sick sort of love for him--the author dwells on it for  page after page. I skimmed most of it, but it made my skin crawl. I don't  know if Gabaldon thinks this is cool or kinky or a turn-on, or she's really  tapped into her audience and knows this is what they'll plunk their money  down for. Either way, it's kinda sick. At the end of the day, Outlander is  pretty low-rent. If you want British Isles history, why not stick with  Braveheart and Ivanhoe and the incomparable novels of Mary Stewart?

I first read these books a number of years ago, and was immediately swept away. I am beginning today on my fifteenth journey thru them, and I am just as excited as I was the first time. I have found that in different moments of my life, different messages in the book have meant more, and if Claire and Jaime are fictional people, would that we could find a magick wand and make them real. Cudos Ms. Gabaldon. Many many cudos. And for those of you that haven't read this series... shame on you. Get busy. I have recommended them to lots of girlfriends only to find that the men in their lives love them just as much. I love them. I own 5 different sets in different versions. Maybe obsessed? Definately obsessed. Read them, you will be too.

I was introduced to the Outlander series by my mother, an avid reader. I have always had a thing for historical fiction, so the synopsis sounded interesting. When I started this book, I was shocked! I stayed up until the early hours of the morning for 2 straight days to finish the book. Gabaldon is a true artist. The characters are as real as the can be. I found myself completely engrossed. Thank god there are 6 books so far! The story of Jamie and Claire weaves through Scotland, France and the new American colonies seamlessly. This is the kind of book you read and then force all of your friends to read so you can all talk about it. I have never felt compelled to write a review before, but this book is that good. Read and enjoy!

I haven't read much fiction during the past few years, but in September I picked up Outlander at the library, and have been thoroughly hooked for the past two months.  I'm so glad I started this series after the sequels were  written, because I immediately ordered all of them (from Amazon.com, of  course.) I just finished the last book and am feeling withdrawl. What makes  this a great read are the lush prose, gut-wrenching emotional situations  and the wonderful characters.  You can't help but fall in love with Jamie  (whether you're a man or woman, it seems!). I like the detail about  Claire's herbs and healing. The words "dinna fash and verra" keep  creeping into my vocabulary. This is great recreational reading.

All the characters were well developed and seemed like real people with character flaws, weaknesses and strengths. I liked the humor, tension and tenderness between the protagonists and the way they chose to establish their relationship on truth. I enjoyed learning about Scottish clans,customs, and history and their cultural attitudes contrasted with the English and French. A beautiful love story woven into many different and unexpected adventures and the time travel, which I thought would be a silly detriment, was handled very well. The role the church played in the history of that time was also interesting. Had to start Dragonfly in Amber immediately cause I did not want the story to end. A very rich and satisfying book.

This is book one of a series.  It is a story of a women who falls though a “rabbit hole” and winds up 200 in the past fighting and loving her present day husband’s ancestors in Scotland. Like any family saga, new characters are introduced and are not who they seem to be.  For some reason it reminded me of the John Jake series.  What I liked about the book is the historical account of the period.  She goes into great depth about the medicine of the time and the weaponry.  What I didn’t care for is the main character herself.  I found her to be a bit too self righteous and too accepting of the predicament that she is in.  The book was reviewed perviously as a stand alone.  I would say that isn’t so.  I just didn’t end.
Love the book - I have read it multiple times but having Jamie and Claire on the cover is great to look at!!!

After reading all the reviews for the other books in this series (and other series, I am surprised that no one mentions the fact that these series sell far more books than the stand alone. The series that I have read in the past just get weaker and weaker in substance and story line. I enjoyed this book even though it went on and on and on in detail with things that had very little to do with the story.  I had to just skim over much of it. Not going to purchase any more of this series. I don't like authors who just jerk you back and forth with impossible scenarios....they're dead, no they're not dead, oh, now they are dead again. Curious to know what happens in the future, but not enough to buy another book.

I absolutely loved this book.  I have never fallen in love with a character of a book before.  I would really love to find a Jamie Fraser in my life...sigh.  Anyway,at frist I thought it was a little hoakey but once she went back in time it was NON-STOP adventure.  I found myself holding my breath through some parts and really through the brutal parts, you can tell Diana Gabaldon did a lot of research on quite a few things in Scotland back in the 1700s.  Having Scottish ancestry myself, it just really gave me a glimpse into that life in that century when My ancestors were in Scotland.  I would recommend this book to anyone, even those who don't like Romance novels (like me), it was so much more than that.

When I first picked up "Outlander", I was just humoring my mother, who insisted that this was THE most engrossing novel she had ever read.  When I finished "Outlander", one day and eight hours later, I was addicted to Scottish lore, time travel, and possibly the greatest love couple to come along since Romeo and Juliet.  Diana Gabaldon masterfully weaves a tale of the political and domestic intrigues of 1743 Scotland, of love lost and discovered elsewhere, and the triumph of two souls who find each other despite the centuries that separate them.  A unique plot and characters so real that you can almost touch them, and wish that you could!  Long live Diana Gabaldon and Jamie and Claire

Thankfully, I am a latecomer to Diana Gabaldon.  I don't think I could stand to wait for each sequel.  A girlfriend and her mother HIGHLY recommended the series so I purchased book 1.  There are not enough adjectives to describe these novels.  I am hooked, and have made several frantic searches and subsequent desperate dashes to the nearest bookstore upon completing a book.  I couldn't wait to pass them on.  My mom has refused to accept any past the first book as her house was in  shambles.......book good, housework BAD!!!  These are truly the absolute best books I have read in my 33 yrs as a reader.  Currently on #4 and I am already looking forward to reading them all again...... A DEFINITE MUST-READ

This book series is my absolute favorite of all times. It has everything you want in a story. It is cleverly written, extremely creative, and suspenseful. It includes romance, adventure, time travel, history based on facts, and realistic, lovable characters that feel like your own friends and family. It is also sexy, quite humorous, heart-wrenching and addictive. This first book in the series lays the foundation for a thrilling ride. Don't be intimidated by the length of the books. They read easily. Savor them. I'm a LOST fan and this series parallels the use of well-developed characters and mysterious, exciting time travel immediately immersing you in and wanting oh so much more!!! Enjoy the ride!!!

It's hard to label a Diana Gabaldon novel.  While she writes with romantic tendencies, her stories are truly well developed and well written--not at all like the run-of-the-mill romance "trash".  I love to get absorbed in a really god romantic novel but I get so tired of the same old plot formulas.  The Outlander series is truly original.  You'll become so immersed in the story and the characters that you won't be able to put it down!  In fact, I've read the entire series many times over and just can't wait for the next installment.  A warning though--each book is long!  But, they will keep your interest.  Ms. Gabaldon has an excellent web site where you can find out all about her series!

The first romance novel I have ever read. To be fair, the romance genre is not my cup of tea. The book itself is a historical romance where the main character, Claire Randal, touches a stone in a circle like Stonehedge and is catapulted back to the early mid 1700s. There she is forced to marry a Scotsman as she has to adapt to the new circumstances.  It tends to lack any plot development after Claire decides that she will stay in Scotland with her new husband (and after she has told him her unique situation). It is most interesting when it tries to portray the different expectations in the relationships between men and women (18th century views vs 20th century). All in all, I was not too thrilled.

This book had an interesting story, but parts of it were very strange. I did like it but I think that some people, especially those sensitive to violence or sexual assault, might find it disturbing. I realize that some of it was to move the plot along, but some of it also seemed unnecessary. Overall the story was good but weird in parts. Perhaps that's part of the draw. Also, I feel like there were some things in the book that were left open ended or left for the reader to conclude when the answer isn't necessarily evident. Maybe those are things left to the subsequent Outlander novels. It does have a good love story and for those who enjoy historical fiction I think it's worth giving it a try.

OK, I've just finished book 8, sob... I hope more is forthcoming, and thank god for the TV series. Love, love these books. If you're an historical novel fan, get # 1 and off you go! I wish it came with a gaelic pronunciation guide, although, with some effort, you can find help on u-tube. A bit sexy, but nowadays it's pretty tame. I thought "Gone With the Wind" was sexy, after all. Oh well. Diana G. writes with fluency and great descriptive power. Her characters are individual and memorable, even the minor ones. I especially like that she can maintain a character's identity, but show growth over time. Not easy. Read her biography on Amazon. She's got an interesting story as well.

I was reluctant to read Outlander, because I heard it involved time travel, and I am not a fan of science fiction.  However, Outlander is an engrossing and well-researched historical novel, and time travel is a vehicle the author used to bring 18th Century Scotland to life.  The story includes the romance between a Scottish clansman and a 20th Century British army nurse, action and adventure, witchcraft, religion, folklore, and many other elements of life in historical Scotland.  Outlander was a long and fascinating story, which  kept me engrossed from beginning to end.  I would recommend it to lovers of history, romance, and adventure.  I think most mature adults would enjoy this book.
This novel is just OK for me.  Do not like the Scottish/Gaelic verbiage.  It is a very slow read for me.

Not only does Gabaldon create a tremendous historic novel, but she also creates one of the best love stories I've ever read.  Gabaldon's story brings us to Scotland and a mysterious ring of stones with even more mysterious powers.  We find out a great deal about these amazing places throughout the book everything from faeries to clans brings the lore and people of historic Scotland to light.  However, this is not even the best part of this amazing novel.  Jamie Fraser is one of the best heros I've come to know in years.  His strength, love for Claire, and soulfulness make him impossible to resist.  Of course, I know he's only a figment of someone's imagination, but I LOVE Jamie Fraser.

This book took me on a journey I will not soon forget.  I was reluctant to commit the time to reading such a long boook but I heard such great things that I gave it a chance and was not disappointed.  I started this book Friday night and was done by Monday morning.  This book has it all, it is brillently writen with a rich plot and enough twists and turns that your heart and mind feels like you spent hours on a roller coaster.  I laughed and cried and got angry and felt my heart swell with love for Jamie and Claire.  I just purchased the next book and I am made I didn't pick up the whole series because I am dying to know what the future...or should I say the past holds for this pair.

I was lucky enough to have searched for free books a couple of months ago, and this one was free.  Since it had such a good rating, I thought "What the heck - pass a little time".  WOW - I started the first and bought all the rest, reading them one right after the other.  My husband has his own kindle and loves westerns, books about indians, fighting..., typical guy stuff...lol.  I told him he HAD to read the first book.  Finally, he ran out of things to read and began.  Meanwhile, I was already on book 4 and he is hooked.  I have finished all of them and the John Grey series (not as good by no means).  He can't wait to get home and start reading.  You HAVE to read this book!

I have read more books than I can count...There are only a few novels that I consider "the Best"...then came Outlander!  Totally blew all competition out of the water!!  I have told all my friends about this book (even bought audio version for Hubby) and everyone has thanked me profusely.  My best friend and I get into the most intense discussions in the books...Even to the point of picking out famous actors and actresses who could play the parts should it ever be made into a movie!(we have all the secondary characters chosen, but we cannot decide who would play Jamie and Claire!  Nobody can come close to filling theirs shoes!)  Bless the day I came upon this book!

I will read this book over and over again.  What an amazing, adventurous love story.  I recommend this book to anyone!!!  All of the characters were incredible and I found it difficult to believe that most of them have never existed.  Diana Gabaldon did an amazing job making this story and the characters jump from the page to your heart.  I fell in love with this series from page one!  I really liked Diana's usage of the facts.  She presented just enough history to make it feel like the story was real without making you feel like you were reading a history textbook.  If you are a lover of historical romance, stop reading these reviews and order this book, it's wonderful!!!

Several friends had been recommending this series, and I finally tried it out.  Brilliant.  Simply brilliant.  Excellent writing, narrative, flow, and plotting.  Huge kudos to Gabaldon for the completeness of her scenes, for fabulous detail that never gets in the way of narrative flow, and for avoiding anachronistic thoughts in her characters.  18th c characters don't have 20/21st c thoughts and expectations, which is harder to pull off than you think, and the clash of those often conflicting cross-century thoughts and expectations is a major theme.  Grand fun, late-night page-turning escapist reading crafted by an Eng-lit level author.  Brilliant and totally addictive!

Wow! What a book! I've had it on my shelf forever and really kept putting it off because it's 850 pages. All I knew going in was that it had been highly recommended to me by a lot of my friends on Shelfari and FrugalReader and that it involved time travel. Because of the time travel aspect, I expected it to be really sci-fi and it wasn't. This book is probably the best love story I've ever read. The characters were absolutely amazing. The adventure and suspense were awesome. The detail in the writing was stunning. I just can't say enough good things about this book! I'm not a big fan of historical fiction or romance and I still loved this book! Highly recommended.

In specifics, I was ensnared by this book and was placed into the contents.  I was compelled to read whenever possible.  The characters were well established and you felt as though your heart would break for them.  Without giving anything away, this historical fiction was well thought out and without any doubt on my must read list.  Claire is trapped within two different times.  Loving two men, but one in her time and one in the past.  Her decision is based upon many turn of events to choose her destiny.  Given many paths she chooses her heart, which may not be the easy.  However, war, corruption, and love makes this book thrilling, intoxicating, and enchanting.

This book was not what I expected. I read it because I was going to interview the author; all I knew (at first, and mistakenly) was that DG wrote romance novels. Outlander is no romance novel (sorry, romance fans!). Rather, it is the ultimate adventure story with a strong and admirable heroine and a hero who is her match, as well as sharply drawn secondary characters. The writing is great; Gabaldon's power to evoke a sense of person or place is simply unmatched by most other writers working today. She reminds the rest of us who write that you need character and plot to tell a great story; one or the other alone, ye ken, will not do. Gabaldon is a master

I love this book.  Diana is the greatest.  She can't write the new books in this series fast enough and I certainly cannot read them fast enough.  This is a romance/drama/historical novel/science fiction/fantasy novel all rolled into one.  The characters of Jamie and Claire maybe the most romantic couple of all time next to Romeo and Juliet.  There are at present (Jan. 2002) five books in this series and more are promised.  I recommend that you read them all as soon as possible.  Everyone that I have recommended these books to has loved them as much as I do and that never happens.  Buy and enjoy!  Diana please keep up the good work.  We must have more!

If you love well-researched historical fiction, medical history, romance, time travel, and characters that you fall in love with or really hate, than this is a book for you! It is a book, you can't put down. When you finish it, you go on to read her other books and travel through time and history, from Bonnie Prince Charlie to The American Revolution and to Scotland in the 1980's. I am addicted to Gabaldon's books. I have been listening to all them  on audio so that when the next one comes out, I will be ready to escape into another world of fiction! I preordered her next book almost 2 years ago and await with my breath held for June 2014 to arrive!

The Outlander series contains the first books I've ever purchased. (I love the library.) I stumbled onto the reviews a couple years ago and took a chance and ordered all 4 in paperback. Diana Gabaldon is such a great storyteller, and as you read, you really come to KNOW these characters. I have since purchased (again) the entire series (including Outlandish Companion) in hardcover. (And am anxiously awaiting the publication of Fiery Cross.) These books are wonderful treasures, and I've convinced as many friends as possible to participate in Jamie and Claire's adventures. Don't be afraid of the length of these books...they are beyond worth it.

This was a perfect case where I came in with different expectations. I thought I'd see a little more history woven into the narrative than what I got. This is a romance novel with a sevententh century backdrop. Personally I was looking for more of a "Pillars of the Earth" flavor with more of an eye on the geopolitical events going on in that time. Gabaldon does this with a very narrow lens that reads more like a personal diary intertwined with conflicting loyalties and emotions...just not my cup of tea. The writing is compelling enough and will hold the reader for a time. But this was a book that was all too easy for me to put down.

I'll start right off and say I didn't finish the book. I have to like a book to finish it and how can you like a book when the main character annoys you, therefor the entire book annoys you because it's all first person. I have to agree with other reviewers in that Clair excepts her surroundings far to quickly. She has almost no regard for her husband, she doesn't seem to miss him at all. No real discussion on HOW daily life was ie baths/oral care or lack there of ect.. I don't get all of the great reviews I made it to 189....and the story hasn't really gone anywhere. It might have been a good book had there been 400 or so pages taken out.

This is one of those rare books that captures your imagination, drawing you into its world in such an effective way that you are genuinely sad when it is over. Though difficult to categorize--name another book in the time-travel-historical-romance-paranormal genre; I dare you--I promise you won't care after Clare goes through the circle of standing stones. In fact, when you read this book you will find yourself caring less and less about a lot of other things, such as eating and bathing-- though personally I draw the line at brushing my teeth; a girl has to have standards. Get lost in this book for a weekend. I promise you won't regret it.

Diana Galbadon has obviously done her research on Scotland, Scottish  history, and the highlands and highlanders in particular.  She brings both  the land and the inhabitants to vibrant, pulsating life; dialogue is  appropriate, and the Scottish dialect is appropriately portrayed.  I bought  this book at lunch one day, started reading at 7:00pm after dinner, and  finished the book as the sun rose the following morning; not ready to lay  it down without finding out how it ended.  Went back to the bookstore the  following day and bought the 2nd book, in HARDCOVER for $25.00+ to continue  the read!  The 2nd, 3rd and 4th in the series have maintained the quality  of the first book, a rare thing indeed.  I am most anxious to obtain  anything else this fine author pens, either of a "pre-quel"  nature or as a continuation of Claire and Jamie's saga in the New World.  A  hearty recommendation to any reader who truly enjoys a fast-paced,  well-written, historically accurate story!  Five stars aren't enough!!!
I am on CD 15 and am totally glued. Can't wait to get in my car everyday to continue the  story.

This book is so good you won't want to put it down.  The idea of time travel and romance was not exactly what I go for, but this one, oh it is incredible.  After several years this still is my No. 1 book of all time.  Don't miss this one and its successors.  The story of Claire and Jamie is captivating.  Diana Gabaldon leads you to unbelievably romantic situations and lets your mind get lost in what she has not written.  It's masterful and provides a key element in leaving you wanting more.  I'll admit that Outlander is the best of the series, but the others will fill the craving Outlander leaves you with.  Don't miss this great read.

For three months the book cover put me off--I'm not the romance-fiction sort, but what a surprise when I finally settled down to it!  Although there is plenty of both sex and romance, I think it is a disservice to call this book--and the others in the series "romances".  There is solid history here; a story well-constructed, with plausible characters and dialogue.  Ms. Gabaldon succeeds so well in setting the scene and dialogue I was astonished to discover she is not English and had not been to Scotland until the book had been written!  (She's not a nurse, either--I am, and the medicine's good too!) Most highly recommended.

Right now I'm cursing my mom for giving me these books.  As soon as I finished the first, I had to read the second (Dragonfly in Amber) and now that I'm done with the second, I have to read the third (Voyager).  I'm a grad student, so it's not like I don't have plenty of other reading I should be doing.  (I even promised myself that after I finished Dragonfly in Amber I'd read a school book before I started the next one.  Well, now I don't think I can wait to find out what happens.)  These books are absolutely fantastic -- romantic, exciting and touching, but please don't start them until you have time to finish all of them!

Ok, so I had been told to read Gabaldon's books and I hadn't because I thought there could be nobody better than Kurland when it came to  historical romance/time travel.  Also, have you seen the size of Gabaldon's  books!  Anyway, I broke down and got Outlander and...well, I'm just  speechless.  The detail and heart wrenching moments, unexpected and  sometimes hidden humor...it just has everything you could want in a true  "best book of my life" type of read.  This book just makes you  want to find a way to travel back in time yourself just so you can meet and  know Jamie and Claire, and be a part of their family.

This will be one of the best and most addictive books you'll ever read.  I have read thousands of books over the years, and this one single book meant more to me than anything else I've ever read!  You will live the life of Claire and Jamie.  The characters of this book become very real people as you read the vibrant and tragic history of the Scots.  The secondary characters are realistic and lend depth and demension to this book that many other books lack.  The only problem is that it starts a bit slow, if you can read the first three chapters, you will be hooked for the next four books!!  Take a chance and you'll love it!

I have read all four books in this series, and I tell you, Diana Gabaldon has made it so that I can never go back and enjoy those other "romance" novels. Her attention to detail, the authenticity of her historical facts, and the realistic handling of Jamie and Claire's relationship blew me away.Each book built on the previous but still could stand alone. I almost never get involved in 'series' books, but I'll make one exception for this series, only. I even asked for 'The Outlandish Companion" for my birthday, and my daughter better get it for me!  I am anxiously awaiting the next book. Thank you, Diana!

This is just the first in a series of books by Diana Gabaldon with Claire and Jamie as characters.  Her style of writing with her sense of humor shine throughout all of her books.  This first book is all it takes to become addicted to the series.  Although it involves some time travel and romance you really don't get hung up on those features.  You end up living vicariously through the characters and tend to become attached to them.  It is almost painful to read through the danger scenes or where the characters get hurt, either mentally or physically, because you feel what they feel!  A must read for any avid reader.

I am thrilled to have the first award winning book of Diana Gabaldon.  She has quickly become my favorite author.  And she's apparently writing another book at this time.  The book is brand new, perfect condition, arrived quickly.  I am interested in the Battle of Cullodon as I have an ancestor who led troops in this war and was beheaded on Tower Hill for treason in August of 1746.  Lord Kilmarnock, 4th Earl of Kilmarnock.  I didn't expect to really find him in her books but was surprised and thrilled that he appeared in the later quarter of her second book, Dragonfly in Amber.  It's hard to put her books down.
The story could be told in helf the number of pages if you cut out just half the sex scenes.

I watched the eipisodes on TV and the book was recommended to me so I thought I'd give it a try.  I agree with other reviewers who feel that the author gets bogged down sometime.  At some points I'd have to just scim over some of the verbage.  However, what I really don't understand is all of the folks who are upset about the "spanking" but seem OK with the sexual abuse at the end of the book.  I don't  consider myself a prude, nor am I squemish about what I read but I just thought all of that detail just went too far.  I'll not be reading any further - the end of the first book ruined it for me.

I'm addicted. I was also excited to find out shortly after starting this that it will be a series on TV in August. The first 50 or so pages were a little difficult to get through and I almost put the book down. Gets much better once Claire goes back in time. I love the characters and plot. I sometimes wish there was a family tree in the beginning or a list of characters and relations because it can get confusing at times, especially by the second book. Lots of parts you can skim and not miss anything, so don't be overwhelmed by the small print and near 1,000 pages. You do fly through the story quickly.

What a stupid and poorly written book. I was looking for something light and entertaining, but this was overlong, nonsensical, and meandering. I realize it's ridiculous to call a book based on time travel nonsensical, but it irked me to no end that Claire just accepted that she had gone back in time and decided to adjust to life at the castle. I did think the romance was good fun but it didn't make up for the rest of the drab storyline. Barely made myself finish it in the hopes that something exciting would actually happen, but was disappointed. Will absolutely not waste my time reading the next book.

My mom recommended that I read this book and it didn't look very good so i put it off for a while. BIG MISTAKE. This is my favorite book after I read this book I bought all of Diana's other books. Her writing is magnificent, and the characters are so well developed. Once I started reading it I just couldn't put it down. I fell in love with Jamie, he is my hero! He was everything that you would want in a man. Claire was a wonderful main character and I could really sympathize with her predicament. The secondary characters complete a wonderful cast for an extraordinary book. I was pleasently surprised that the book was written with a first person narrator. You don't see that very often and it helped to understand the characters more. I would reccommend this book to anyone. It is definitely a keeper!
I would give it a hundred stars if possible. It is an amazing story, amazingly well told.

Diana Gabaldon is one of those rare authors who not only has an unparalleled imagination, but also the gift of storytelling.  I didn't read the Outlander books -- I lived them.  Every event, character, and scene is described in such meticulous detail that you feel as if you are actually a part of it.  Jamie and Claire are unforgettable characters, and you miss them long after you've read the last page.  I've read thousands of books ranging from classics to trashy romances, but very few books left the kind of impression that the Outlands Series had.  Can't wait for the next installment.

How can anyone rate a Diana Gabaldon book as anything less than 5 stars? I already owned the book in paperback,  but talked my husband into reading the series before the television show comes out,  and didn't want to  give him my old well-read worn out copy. So I ordered it in hardback for him. For us. Ok, for me!!! It also comes with a cd with some nice songs, and a ribbon bookmark. Can't wait for him to finish it so I can read it yet again! I love all of her books but this one is definitely my favorite. PS, husband says the cover and binding are good quality as well. Happy reading!

After hearing about the TV Series, I decided to read the 1st book. I can't say I didn't enjoy some parts of the book, but others were not to my particular liking. I had to skip over the very descriptive sick torture parts and had to ask myself where this came from in the author's mind. I know I will get lots of comments about this, but couldn't Claire & Jamie have just had a bath in a nearby Loch before the oral sex part? Some of the book was just too unbelivable. I would like to know what happens overall so I will attempt to read the next book, then see if I want to go any further.

I am totally immersed in the story line of Jamie Fraser and Claire.  It is realistic to the point of being painful to read. The decriptive rape scene (and later references to it) are troubling.  As much as I am addicted to the story (I am now on the third novel of the series) I almost wish I had never started.  My husband and I both have been personally affected by the devastating antagonistic events.  However, I must confess that the story has also stirred strong, romantic emotions in us, which after twelve years of marriage are a wonderful shot in the arm to our intimate life!

This ended too quickly and I wasn't prepared and I'm crying with the sentimentality.  The writing was superb. The voice of each character is unique, interspersed with 1940s English, Scottish, Gaelic and Latin. Ms. Gabaldon is a fascinating storyteller. I'm watching the television version and find it quite true to the book. I'm enjoying it almost as much as the pleasure in reading this beautifully crafted, exquisitely descriptive historical romance. Just returned from two weeks in Scotland where the book's history came alive in the rich landscapes and cities. Mesmerizing novel.

This was a fun read and hard to put down at times.  I read sometimes until the Kindle fell out of my hands and I would have to re-read a couple of pages beginning again!
