I fell in love with this story along time ago when I discovered the paperback in a used book store.  I wanted it on my kindle so I can take it everywere. On my fourth re-read.  The writing is so amazing that you develop real feelings for the characters. Truly an awesome beginning to a series.

It was a wonderful read. I can't wait to start the next book. I love a good romance with a dose of history thrown in. I would recommend this book to adults who aren't easily offended by bawdy descriptions of two people whose loving relationship is something we'd all be blessed to have.

I am 61 years old and I have loved a lot of authors and a lot of series, but never has one hit me the way that all of the Outlander books have. They are history lessons that give you an insight into how history impacted in real time. Beautifully written. Thank you from my heart Diana.

I don't have anything new to add, I just wanted to be a part of the fan club.  I've read this book at least a dozen times and get something new out of it every time.  I thought I might grow out of it at some point, but whenever I need an escape read, this is my first choice.  Love it.

Meh. Outlander was OK. I read it all the way through, but once I realized it was 800+ pages (no wonder the percentage on my Kindle wasn't moving!) it felt like drudgery. I won't be reading the rest of the series - just don't have that much time to commit to a "just OK" story.

I was surprised to find this heralded novel not much more than a bodice-ripper with a veneer of fantasy. The writing is competent, to be sure, and reading along you can't help learning about 18th century Scotland. Overall, it's fun. But it's a gussied-up romance novel, nothing more.

I loved this book! Sure there is violence and sex, but I find it completely relevant to the period of time reflected in the story itself. Don't let the naysayers drive you away from a delicious long book full of life, reality and most important, engaging and personable characters.

Some might be daunted by the sheer size of this book but I say it is well worth the time spent reading it. Dianna Gabaldon is a master of story telling and held me captive throughout this epic journey. I would suggest snuggling up in a cozy chair and getting to know Jamie Frasier.

I picked this book up from the library randomly, wanting something to read before bed when I couldn't sleep. Oh my God. I read it in 1.5 days, eyes bloodshot. I even cancelled a date to finish it. Really wonderful. I wished it wouldn't have ended and am SO glad there are more!!!

For some reason the "author" of this series thinks it's ok for men to abuse women, and for husbands to abuse and punish their wives.  I cannot abide by this and refuse to support any "author" who espouses it.  There's enough misogyny in the world as it is, so I really don't think I need for it to show up in my reading.

The book could use  some really good editing. If 150 pages were edited out it wouldn't spoil the story at all. I like that it is written in first person. This is probably one story that would fair better on film then on the pages of a book. At least the story would be edited. My advice forget the book enjoy the movie, it really is better and life is too short to waste reading endless pages of descriptions of herbs, plants and forest glades and glens.

Have read all of the Outlander books and LOVE them - but it's been a while so I will start reading them on my Kindle again.  Reading on my Kindle has become much easier than reading books and, obviously, takes up much less space - but the Outlander series will remain with me.

I enjoyed the settings and interplay between the characters. The sexual scenes were a little too explicit for my taste. The traumatic scenes were a bit too many and the flow of events could have been improved. I "liked" the book but will not bother with reading more.

I am glad that I watched Starz Outlander first. I have always been a little bit of a book snob. Reading a book first usually made me prone to being disappointed with a the screen version. Seeing the show first hooked me. And now the book adds flavor and meat to the story.

Claire the practical falls through  time in Scotland and meets crazy relatives of her husband and is rescued by a mangy Scotsman. She then realizes she needs to go back to her time and struggles to do so. She meets adventure valiantly head on and never changes who she is.

I enjoyed reading this book at first, but it got to unrealistic for me by going back in time.  I had a hard time with this and didn't finish this long book.  I guess some people enjoy reading this time of time warped novel, but I don't.  The author writes very well.

I loved Jamie almost from the beginning, although he "grows" on you......the more you find out about him - the more you love him.  He and Claire find a love that most folks just dream of......and the writer takes you, literally, on a trip back through time!

I must be one of the few men that ever read a romance novel, mushy right.not this one it has everything high adventure, time travel, battles, excitement all the way through from first page to last, humor, oh yes and romance. i would recommend this book to anyone

Not to my tastes. I would not consider this literary fiction and do not plan to continue the series. Though I finished the book, I was disappointed in the storyline's lack of direction and seemed to go on and on for no good reason. Written for TV it would seem.

Well written and  the story line is unique. Relatable, with awkward situations that don't seem forced and predictable. The characters are easy to fall in love with and keep you wanting for more insight into their depths. This series and first book is wonderful!

First read this book when it came out in '94.  I hadn't read any of the other in the series and decided to go back and refresh myself before continuing on.  It was even better the second time around.  Defying genre, this book truly has something for everyone.

I really enjoyed this book and was so glad to finally get a good book to read. I was disturbed by part of it that I really wish hadn't been included...but was an excellent read other than that of a beautiful love story set in an interesting historical period.

I loved loved loved this book. I'm so excited to finish the whole series, so that I can start reading them again. I could not put it down. Diana Gabaldon makes you feel the pain and the love and your heart will literally feel all the emotions of Outlander.

the book in paperback is too small ,for all the pages.It  should be printed on a larger format, such as 9  x 6 . it is a 4x5  tiny book with tiny print.only recommend if cannot  afford  hard cover. I feel it is a tiny short fat book. Disappointed  in it.

Wow!  This book really grabbed me and kept my interest throughout and it is a long book.  It was well written and very exciting and I looked forward to reading it at every opportunity.  I love historical fiction and history of Scotland so this book had a lot of appeal to me.  I am not a big fan of time travel stories, but I thought this story handled it pretty well, and did not make it the primary focus of the book.  While I found this book very enjoyable and will probably read more of the series, I do have some criticisms of it.  First, Claire adjusted far too easily to being thrust 200 years in to the past.  She quickly devised her cover story as to who she was and immediately adapted to 18th century life with little complaint about the drastic change in lifestyle.  Since this story was written in the first person, one might expect some commentary on the difficulties she encountered with the lack of creature comforts and hygiene, but she pretty much glossed over those issues, except for a brief mention midway through the book about how her upbringing with exposure to nature and the great outdoors made her new life easier.  Second, I like a good love story, but I do not like romance novels...there is a difference.  Initially, I thought the developing relationship and love between Claire and Jamie was handled nicely, however, as the book progressed, the constant focus on their never ending sexual encounters seemed more like a trashy romance novel.  I think much of that could have been omitted without the book losing a thing, and would have preferred that.  There was a lot in the story that was unbelievable, like rescuing our hero from a prison, but let's face it, those are the things that make stories exciting!  Also, Jamie was probably the most perfect hero who ever graced the pages of a book except for the time he beat his wife.  On the other hand,  I very much enjoyed the religious considerations of time travel issues when Claire asked for guidance from the priest at the sanctuary.  Overall, there is so much that went on in this long book that there is a lot to like but also a lot to criticize.  In the end, I enjoyed reading this book very much, even though there were aspects I did not care for.

The problem with most of the one star reviews for this book is that the readers are not considering that this is an "historical fiction". Meaning a fictional story set in an historical time. People are crying feminist crap about the domestic abuse, violence, and rape in the book.. Consider that marital rape did not become illegal in all 50 states until 1993. 20 years ago. We are even now seeing cases of spankings being debated as domestic violence versus appropriate punishment (Adrian Peterson). How then are we to gauge the beating of a wife who endangered the lives of many men because she did not obey her husband? I'll admit that the passage made me cringe, but when you read it from the historical perspective, it is accurate. Whether or not she is a modern woman, as some have argued, does not matter, she is not in a modern time. As to the complaints regarding Jamie's fond reminiscence of his father's beatings: I don't think you read the passage. He was not happily remembering the beatings, but his father and the things that he said that impacted the man Jamie became. The life lessons he learned from his father were often given when he had done wrong and had to be whipped. Just as a parent may  punish with time out and then sit down and explain why a behavior was wrong today.. I fondly remember my mother's favorite punishment: hugging my sister until we talked out whatever we had been fighting about. I'm not remembering the punishment fondly as I was often bristling with rage, but rather the result - which made me a better woman. Yes, they have sex a lot, but they also talk about deep topics and meaningful life events. Both contribute to the development of their relationship throughout the book (and come on- sex sells). If you read a historical fiction and expect tidy streets, modern law, and pretty events tied neatly into a bow.. You obviously are  not meant for true historical fiction.

Well. I don't normally write book reviews so I am no expert here.  It is only my experience that I relate.  I sort of accidentally came upon this subject due to the Starz  program.  It was a matter of I simply chose to watch the show while channel surfing.  I guess I caught it about mid-showing,  just before the wedding.  So....I liked it right away because I am a history buff (and yes, I enjoy cross checking historical references from books or movies).  For whatever weird reason, I felt a kinship with the story and setting.  I think what really hooked me tho, was the sheer attraction between Jamie (what can I say?) and Claire.  Damn, these two actors really make that passion, the tension of it, so real on screen.  Also...I don't want to forget Dougal, who, in my opinion brings a really strong and passionate character to not only the clan, but to the Claire and Jamie relationship, as well.  I know he gets a bit sleazy further on, but even in the beginning, you can see his passion for Claire.  It just adds to the suspense.  Watching just 5 recorded episodes (I guess i missed recording a few of the first...gotta catch up!) compelled me to buy the kindle edition of the books.  I've finished the first (which had me going back and watching those episodes I'd recorded) and am now on the second (Dragonfly in Amber).  I am still enthralled by the story.  Even though I get a little exasperated at the assumptions and behavior and thought that Claire and Jamie put each other through, I find myself just waiting until they figure out what is really important.  Their love scenes are well....,you just have to read it and make up your own mind as to whether that appeals to you or not.  For me...it was a home run!! Love it.  I plan on reading the whole series :)  I fell like Starz, so far, has done a darn good jon of staying true to the books.  This is a really enjoyable story, both for history buffs and romantics ;)

What a fantastic book. If you are not a historical reader the imagery details may escape you. She had to have researched this book to the ends of the Earth to have gotten all of the minor details right. I know this was written a decade ago but it provides a prime example of the difference between fly-by-night self-publishers and ones backed by publishers. Don't get me wrong I LOVE Indy writers and actually prefer them over publishing houses and their forced drivel! Diana gave me chills at every turn though my least favorite part was the prison scene after she leaves Jamie behind. There was something lacking like she danced around the edges of the topic at hand. However I will say that ten years ago talking about a subject like this was a dicey proposition! We are far more open to the ideas now. Her descriptive style is what makes writers great story tellers. My favorite by far was the explanation of what it felt like to fall through the stone. The sense that you could feel it with Claire was truly incredible! It still gives me chills. I must have reread that passage fifteen times it was so enchanting. The ending was a little lack luster a hint of what was to come probably meant as a cliff hanger. It could have provided drive for the next book. Instead she "jumped the shark" in as few as five pages of the next book. It ruined the series for me. I won't say more but I will caution you if you are a Jamie supporter you may end up bitter with the first chapter. So unhappy that I read the spoilers and then promptly returned the book. Too bad there was so much going for this series. That being said I still gave Outlander five stars. Success can be such a fickle friend as it certainly was for this author after Outlander.

Claire and Frank, a young married British couple separated by the events of World War II, decide to travel to Scotland for a second honeymoon. The impossible happens when Claire, exploring a small circle of stones in the hills, is suddenly catapulted back in time to 1743. Shortly after her arrival in 18th century Scotland, a skirmish between English and Scottish soldiers sweeps her away from the stones, and into the heart of the Highlands. Although she vows to return to her husband by any means necessary, she soon finds herself drawn to handsome Scotsman Jamie. As it becomes clear that their fates are meant to be intertwined, Claire finds herself torn between one lover in the 18th century, and her husband in the 20th century.

First, I’ll give you the positives about the novel. Although it tops 600 pages, Outlander is a well-researched and lushly detailed page-turner, and the love affair between Claire and Jamie is hot and dirty enough to make any middle-aged romantic squeal with delight. Yet, being the cynical spinster that I am, I found that the warm glow of the romance couldn’t outshine certain glaring problems in the story.

First off, the heroine. Although Claire is supposed to be a Blitz-era Englishwoman, she seems more like a liberated female from 1960s America. Worse than that, though, is the inconsistency of her character, which seems to oscillate from strong, steely combat nurse to immature brat at the drop of a hat. As for the “love story,” there is much to be desired. The only reason the couple gets together is due to a convenient forced marriage that will ensure Claire’s safety from the pursuit of a sadistic English captain. And although she protests her new marriage to Jamie the hot Scot, she is soon struck speechless by just how darn attractive her groom looks in a wedding kilt, and becomes, sort of, well—distracted from thoughts of her modern-day husband. While she does feel bad about betraying Frank, her sense of guilt isn’t visited nearly often enough, which leads me to think that maybe she and Frank shouldn’t have been married in the first place. After all, shouldn’t such a legitimate love affair, especially one that deserves such celebration, be founded on a little more than how high the hero ranks on the Scoville scale?

Needless to say, there will be those that disagree with me. Some readers will love this story, others will hate it. For the majority of readers who found The Time Traveler’s Wife to be a flawless epic of true love, you will probably adore Outlander, and its many 800 page sequels. For those in the minority, however, you may just want to look somewhere else.

After all the hype surrounding the new tv series circulated online this year, and after a book signing with DG, I was excited to reread this book and envision the new cast members as Jamie and Claire. Finally a face to sweet Jamie. Ahhh... Hmmm....Sorry I lost my train of thought for a moment. After a bit of a lag getting into it, I was captured by just how intense, crazy and realistic this world is described. Every page I am not just reading words on a page, I am there and I just don't get why I haven't used some of Gelie's magic to transport me there in real life. But that being said, I have a really hard time recommending it and wanting to see the new show. By chance a friend mentioned this the other day, and she too struggled with the brutality and explicit nature of Jamie's rape. It almost borders on some bondage/sexual fantasy that is for an audience of explicit romance novels.  To my point of view, there are more details about the realities of his encounter with Jack Black than with Claire. I really wonder just what Starz will do to this scene. If they go all Hollywood and make it appear that part of Jamie enjoyed it, then it will be very insulting to the real life victims of rape who, I can surely guess, did not enjoy it either.  However, if they do explore the graphic nature of this- I will have to pull my eyes out of my head as I really can't stand watching this kind of stuff. (Yes, I am talking specifically to the crazies who made the Girl and the hornets nest European version- holy crap disturbing). Yet at the end of the day I love these characters. Claire's response and life-saving measures for Jamie is a direct change from the timid girl we meet in the beginning trying to run away. Her actions are truly heroic and she will do anything for this man and that is something I can read more of any day.

I've read all of the Outlander books and am waiting for the new one that will be delivered to my kindle in March 2014.  These books are not for the faint hearted.  It's true I couldn't put these books down but at times I wished I'd never started the series - I guess that's really what makes a book great?  No other book(s) made me feel so emotional.  I'd even think about these character's as if they were real and had to remind myself that it was just a book and I was being silly.  Sounds crazy I know.  The books are very long which for some readers might be hard.  I can be impatient sometimes wanting to know how something ends without having to spend more than a few days reading but these stories don't end anyway!  So if you like to pick up a book and have a happy ending when it's over these aren't the books for you.  Now if you love your books to really tell a story with lots of detail (sometimes too much) and you don't expect happy endings then you should definitely try these books.  You can read them out of sequence but you shouldn't - they do build upon each other.  This first book I really liked but almost put it down to never picked it up again before finishing (something I never do) because I felt like the writer just brutalized Jamie (the best character I've ever come across in the hundreds and hundreds of books I've read). I felt like it was just too much but she did back off a bit on the rest of the books and poor Jamie did get some mercy.  You'll fall in love with Jamie.  You'll want to keep reading these books because you'll want to see that Jamie has a happy ending.  Terrible things happen to the character's in the books so if you're used to books where the character's narrowly escape disaster and nothing really bad happens to them - again these aren't the books for you.  My favorite of the books was the Voyager and I really liked An Echo in the Bone.  The Echo in the Bone book probably got the worst of the reviews although there are usually good reviews for these books but I don't know why - I really did like that one.  Maybe because of the ending.  Gabaldon waited until the end to really amp up the excitement and pull in more interesting plots.  I am worried though that this story still won't end with the next book.  Please end them soon Diana Gabaldon!  I want Jamie to have a happy ending - he certainly deserves it!  I've never been a crazy fan that gets overly involved but you will find yourself doing that with these books!

Maybe it is my counselor background, but, I found myself anaylyzing too many things in both the process and the content of the book.  It seems Gabaldon used a lot of unnecessary descritptions (i.e., the flaura and fona that goes on for pages in the beginning of Outlander) to take up space as opposed to really good character descriptions/development.  I did find it to be a page turner due to all the action, but, again, too much of this and not enough character description.  I found many of the secondary characters drawn better than Claire.  I do not know if writing it in the third person would have made a difference, but, at times, I wanted to smack Claire and ask Jamie what he was doing with a cold, selfish woman such as her.  I had no understanding of what motivated Claire. For example, she stays with Jamie when he gives her the chance to return to the 20th Century, but, the build up of why she did this was not enough.  I did not see the progression of her falling in love with him and not just seeing him as a friend.  When she joins him in the cottage (a great scene), and he asks her "why", Claire still can not open up totally with him.  She always seems to hold back, even just a little.  Gabladon is an intelligent writer and has an excellent way with words; she can say in a sentence what some writers can not say in a paragraph and she conveys her message really well. But, I found myself too frustrated at times with things that happened with the two main characters.  The biggest problem in this area was Jamie's rape.  He allows this to happen to save the life of Claire.  I could deal with this.  But, when Randall crys and Jamie comforts him and when Jamie gets aroused, this opened up a whole can of worms that ruined some of the story for me.  Jamie would not be physically capable of becoming aroused unless he were "turned on".  His is beaten, bloodied, and raped and he gets aroused!  This is going to far for the hero, in my opinion.  Especialy when this theme reoccurs in later books with Capt. Gray.  Yet, like so many readers, I found Jamie to be a romantic figure - one of the best in a long while due to the realistic way he is written.  He is not a cooke-cutter hero.  I like Gellis and Jenny better than Claire.  In their few scenes, they were drawn much better than her.  I have no problem with whatever genre this book is in - it was a good read in many ways.  The problem with the series as a whole is that she could have gotten the story out  in less pages if there was less filler descriptions and more character development.  I did not like the fact these people with this supposed great love were kept apart for 20 years.  I know Gabaldon used this as a plot device to bring us to the American Revolution, but, it did not work for me.  If I were Claire, I would have been hitting the history books as soon as I returned to my century to find out what exactly happened to the man I am supposed to love beyond reason.  True, she thought he died at Culloden, but, she was even too selfish to find out how.  When she is with Frank she thinks of Jamie and vice versa.  I would have been back through those stones with baby in tow as soon as our child was born and I knew was healthy.  Gabladon's research is excellent, but, where the books were good, they were great, where they were bad they were lousy.  She started out to do historicals and added romance as an afterthought, so she has six of one and half a dozen of another.  I agree with another reviewer who said she should have stopped after the first 3.  I will say that I do admire her for the risks she took; she did not tie things up in nice, pretty bows with fast resolutions.  She has an excellent imagination and I admire her for using it.  I think the Loch Ness monster scene in Outlander will be one of my favorite scenes of all times

Kept me turning the page and was interesting to read about the History. Some of it was repetitive and predictable but then surprisingly the action would pick up and I would find my self drawn back in. I would recommend it for a fun interesting read.

Finally getting on the Outlander bandwagon.  Better late than never, right?  Love the story so far.  Just started Book Two and have plans to purchase all the others as I get to them.  A series like this is a commitment...but this one seems worth it.

This book was a lot if fun. You really get sucked back into 18th century Scotland. The plot really moves along at a good pace. My one main criticism is that it is too long.  I feel like the whole last 25 percent of the book could have been cut out.

I was told how wonderful this book was and that I HAD to read at least the first ones. I'm not a romance reader, which I affectionately call smut books. This book is a romance novel... story was good, but a little too sexually graphic for my taste.

An amazing read. The history, the love story...I couldn't put it down. Lost a lot of sleep. Claire is a feisty heroine and Jamie (oh Jamie) is a heartthrob for the ages. Just started book 2 and I can't put that down either. Brava Diana Gabaldon!!!!

I fell in love with this book and it's characters, heart and soul. I don't remeber the last time a book evoked so many emmotions, I laughed, cried, and felt genuinly connected to Clare and Jamie. I have literally read this book 5 times. LOVE IT!!!!

Ugh.  Don't know how in this day and age women can enjoy this kind of "damsel in distress" book.  Definitely not for me -- cannot understand the cult following.  Stopped reading the book once the testosterone level got completely out of hand.

Really enjoyed reading, page after page. Full of adventure, romance and mystery. Very descriptive but interesting not drawn out. Hard to put down at night. Looking forward to next book. Recommend to anyone who enjoys reading a well written novel.

So I actually began watching the Show first.  I had heard about this book for years & I was really intrigued with the show. Well let me tell you the show is so much better! Something I never say.  The way I heard women swoon over this book I expected so much more!  I like a good escape in a romance as much as the next gal but this was just plain terrible.  The book is just a plain & awful let down.  Claire acts ridiculous in the book! And Jamie, seriously Ladies that man was written by a woman!  I am all for literary fun but it just gets to the point where you continually say to yourself "really?" It is more than that though, I think the best way to describe it is pot holes, a page or 2 seem promising & the writing dumps you through an alley of potholes, literal potholes.  Such a let down!  Big build ups with the scenes you would THINK held importance and you get a crappy one liner…and it continues like that A-L-L the time.  I can't tell you how many times I was like 'that's it!'. She tells Jamie she's from the future, ya that gets like a couple of paragraphs.  And the sex scenes are fairly blah, except for the violent ones, like really?  I am so thankful a friend told me about the vile & horrific rape scene as I quit reading at that point.  They said it disturbed them for days.  I understand that rape would without a doubt always be horrific reading about but from what I understand the depth of detail goes beyond a lot of violence in books. So be forewarned if like me that would haunt your life for weeks.  One reviewer noted that the author must absolutely hate a man named Jamie as she spent pages torturing him in the most grotesque ways!  As one reviewer put it, wish I could time travel back and not read this book!  It kind of ruined the enjoyment of the Starz show, its talented actors and Scotland!  Maybe the TV writers can save what could be a promising story, I wish them luck!  If you are on  the fence about this book, move on, wish I had!

I do love good historical fiction, and Outlander begins with a strong and compelling story filled with mystery, excitement, adventure and intrigue.  Unfortunately, it gradually devolved into a typical romance novel with all the expected turns.

I read this before, but I couldn't find my original book. I wante to re-read it so that I could keep up with the STARZ production of th Outlander. I love the whole series that Diana Gabaldon wrote. Can't wait for the next part of ther Outlander.

This book opened the door to the entire series. Exciting, positively romantic. The author brings her main character back in time to become a participant observer to history in the making. After reading this book, I 've ordered the whole series.

I walked into Borders and asked for a great series.  These were recomended to me and I am in love with them.  There is so much information and so much love between these two people that it makes you feel like that love like that is timeless.

For the first time in my life, i couldn't find the words to write a sound  book review. Right now no words are rushing through my head, my fingers are  not speedily clicking along the keyboard and in this instant, i feel like a  mute. Trying desperately, the tears come to my eyes with the effort of  communicating but nothing comes out of my mouth. I am a mass of emotions,  all jumbled up inside me. I am left with a feeling of constant unease and i  cannot quite say in one word, what i truly feel. I know, with utmost  certainty, that whatever i write here, it will not do justice to this  novel. I've read not a few romance novels, but i've never, until now, read  a story which portray love in all its dimensions, the joy, miracle, pain,  hurt evident in all their decisions and gestures towards each other. The  reason I find this romance novel so different is that it never degenrates  into soda-pop, bubblegum, cotton-candy romance. Not that i'm against  romance. But too many people equate love with romance rather than by  association. There are enough incidents to darken the plot, such as sadism,  rape, and graphic violence. On the other end, the act of intercourse, is  pushed to its highest level by portraying it not only as the simple and  pleasurable joining of two bodies, but two lovers struggling to become one  and indistinguishable by sharing and uniting their souls. The elaborate  plot brings to the forefront, what love means, as it is constantly tested  through different trials. For days now after finishing the book, I still  feel trapped by the intensity of the plot. No woman who read this will fail  to fall in love with Jamie. And I lament, for he exists only between the  pages of a book ...

The first episode of the movie was good.  I watched it last night.  However, the book is great.  I read it for the first time in 1999, I think.  Everyone by now knows the premise of the novel about the time traveling heroine who meets her soulmate. I have read Book 1 of the series many times, and every time it read it, I fall in love all over again. The first book is where we meet most of the major characters for the first time, including of course Claire, Frank, Jamie, and even young Roger..  I remember the first time I read the book; I started out rooting for Frank as Claire's husband, BUT then the author introduced Jamie.  He has been my favorite male protagonist of all time, and I have fallen in love with several heroes from Harry Potter to Gideon Cross.  (I mean as characters, of course).  And Gabaldon is just such a wonderful writer.  We get to know the characters intimately.  We see and feel the surroundings, the majesty and grandeur of the Scottish Highlands, the miserable degradation of the prisons...we can experience it all through Gabaldon's words.  It always amazes me to think that the author had not visited Scotland when she wrote "Outlander" because I have been to Scotland, and her descriptions are spot on.  Obviously, she did her research.  But the story itself is intricately woven, and as I continue to read, I see how wonderfully the events and characters are linked.  Yes, there are things that happen to the characters, as well as characters' actions, that are horrific, but such is true in life as welI.  I love the way the author makes even the most fantastical events seem believable.  I can't get enough of Jamie and Claire.  Their story transcends time.

I was not enthused with the book within the first few chapters.  I heard much hype about the series at the library book club and decided I should read it.  I cannot understand the wonderful reviews, etc.  I guess it just is not my cup of tea.

The only bad thing about this book is that it had to end. Gabaldon did a wonderful job keeping me up all night not wanting to put the book down. Fantasy, History, Romance and Jamie <3...  Ahhh... Jamie, if only men were like you in real life.

She is a fantastic storyteller, but I could have done without the soft porn sex that went on and on, so I did not finish it. I felt like the over-sexed narrative stopped all the action and distracted from the story.  Deleted from my kindle.

In 1945, Claire Randall a former combat nurse is back from the war and reunited on a second honeymoon with her husband, Frank, in the rural countryside of Scotland.  But a magical stone circle thrusts Claire back in time to 1743 - when Scotland was on the verge of a disastrous uprising against the British.  Cast into a bewildering, primal time when Scotland is torn by war, Claire is compelled to join forces with a young Scotsman named Jamie Fraser when she unintentionally attracts the attention of an infamous British soldier known as Black Jack Randall ---- her husband Frank's ancestor.  Jamie rescues Claire from Randall's attentions by marrying her.  Suddenly, Claire is enmeshed in the intricate politics of Scottish clan life, saddled with a stranger as a husband.  But Jamie is a gallant young warrior whose compassion, tenderness and courage compel Claire to consider whether she will try to return to her own time or stay with the young man who has captured her heart.  Gabaldon has written a magnificent first novel that is chock full of valiant battles, breath-taking escapes and heart-pounding sex.  "Outlander" is a terrific achievement, providing non-stop action and likable, believable protagonists.  Although the book is an unabashed romance, Claire is no vapid, young heroine; she is an older, experienced woman who has endured death and violence as a nurse in World War II.  Her medical and herbal knowledge provide entrée into the suspicious Scottish society which welcomes a woman who can diagnose smallpox or efficiently return a dislocated shoulder to its proper place.  "Outander" is a book to be savored again and again by the discerning historical romance fan.

It's a great book better than the series but the series is good also. I am rereading it after having read five more of the series I've gone back to the first book outlander and it's as good the second time through if it was the first time

I would give this 3.5 stars if Amazon allowed half stars.  Don't expect sizzling romance, but it is an excellent story.  It is a story about tremendous love and heroics in a dangerous world.  Although there are frequent references to sex, many are described mildly as if in passing for example: he took her to bed.  A few are more detailed and describe the power, or amazingness of the relationship or events around the couple.  On the negative side, I can usually handle limited amounts of torture in stories, but this book had a terrible event which combined torture and sex which I wished I had never read.  I would like to forget those details and so far they're still haunting me.  Another part of the story I did not like was the open ending.  I had no idea if she would become pregnant, or if they would be able to change events in the coming war.  I then read some Amazon reviews of other Gabaldon books and realized there are at least 5 other books in this series which continue the story.  I saw that my questions would be addressed in those books.  I haven't decided whether to read any of them yet.  At the end of this book I felt a little worn out, as if I had been living through the tragedies.  I prefer a happier feeling for myself at the end of a book, but this book left me with more of a feeling of relief that they had survived somehow.  The best parts of this book were the two amazing characters, their love for each other and the various things they did for each other.  I am glad that I read it, but I'm not ready for more.  Sexual language: moderate.  Number of sex scenes: about sixteen.  Setting:  1945 and 1743 Scotland.  Genre: historical romance.

Started off so promising, then got long winded and turned out to be basic love story, with explicit male rape domination......I kept waiting for her to go back to her first husband, but guess not in this novel. The ending disappointing.

I read the novel after I watched the Starz series, so I had a vision of the actors playing the roles. I admit that shaped my view of the book as I was enchanted by every morsel of the TV series. The book follows the story line closely of a woman thrust back in time in the Scottish highlands and her relationship with Jamie, a young man on the run. Season one of the TV series ends at about the midway point of the book, so reading the rest kept me on the edge of my seat. From what I've read about the times, Gabaldon captures the 18th century authentically. The highlanders were warriors, but she depicts them as normal human beings, with the same issues and concerns of modern times. She makes it credible that someone could adjust to living without modern conveniences - although I wanted to find out how she dealt with toilet issues and her period. While she's wholly in love with Jamie, I like that the story shows Claire's continual struggle over her husband in the 20th century. The story isn't perfect - there were times when I thought the "steamy" scenes were getting to be a bit much (okay, we get the point - they're newlyweds!) and some scenes around Jamie's capture and the scheme to bust him out of prison later in the book were far-fetched. Really, she fights off a pack of wolves?! Perhaps the best part is that the story got me to look into my own Scottish heritage and I discovered they were clan chiefs from the highlands and Jacobites, too. Shortly before Culloden, one relative, a clan chief, was hung beause he wouldn't reveal that he had a son. It makes reading this story even richer for me. I am now savoring book two.

I love this book. I have read it 4 times and still love it. The characters are easy to picture, and seems so real. Claire and Jamies love sticks with you long after you have finished the books. There are times when you laugh, and cry.

Best series ever!  I already have all 8 books on my Kindle, but I bought this paperback because it has pictures of Jamie & Claire on the cover (from the Starz network series)!  Love everything about these two!  Thanks Diana Gabaldon!

I hate when I get into a good book and it ends way too soon!  This book was one of the longest books I ever read, including Gone With the Wind!  It was bizarre, unrealistic, a page-turner - basically every requirement of a good book!

What a great read, couldn't put them down, Jamie and Claire's love was wonderful.  They were my friends for weeks, I couldn't wait till the next one came out.  I hope she writes another triglogy on time travel these three were great!

I absolutely loved this book. It has romance, adventure, history! The characters seem like real people. I feel like I have new friends after reading this series. The settings are easy to visualize. Gabaldon is a  master storyteller!

I sometimes think novelists attempt to shape their story to a group of people who don't respond to logical thought, but only their basic instincts.  A little disappointing that they must continuously stoop to soap opera techniques.

WHAT A BOOK and WHAT A WRITER!!!  The BEST book I've EVER, EVER, read!!!  This book was recommended to me 10 years ago by a coworker.  I purchased the book from AMAZON but couldn't get into the book because at the time, I was into reading true crime or books based on true stories.  So I gave the book to the individual who recommended it.  About 5 years later, a friend gave me a bag of books and OUTLANDER was one of those books.  I thought OH NO!  There's that book again!  I donated the bag of books to a charity.  Last July I wanted to get back into reading historical romances and read a couple of books that were so-so.  I wanted to read something EXCELLENT and long, perhaps a series.  Then I got to thinking about OUTLANDER.  I know the book had excellent reviews on AMAZON so I downloaded the sample onto my KINDLE FIRE.  The sample only has two chapters.  Not enough to know if you'll be able to get into the book.  I was afraid if I purchased the book at $8.99 I wasn't going to be able to get into it like before.  I called AMAZON to see if I could download it for free since I purchased it in 2003 and it's there in my history orders.  AMAZON said NO.  I would have to purchase the book again.  So I did.  Forcing myself that I would get into the book no matter what.  Jesus H. Roosevelt Christ, I would have to get into it after pay $8.99 again.  OMG did I ever get into this book!  I LOVE IT!  I'm up to DRUMS OF AUTUMN (forth book) and to me, so far, the first two were EXCELLENT!!!  I shall see what the rest of the series brings.  I hope this review helps in your decision in reading the series!  Thanks!

To say it's soft porn is understating it.  Ugh. I have to scan and move on to the real, historical plot -  with all due respect to the scholars spending their lives on this era - I'm fascinated by this Scots History for Dummies...

To tell you how much I liked this book, I am getting the entire series!  I got this book after watching a TV miniseries based on it.  The book is even better than the series.  I am very anxious to move on through the next 6 books.

Discovered the show just recently on Starz, had to watch it marathon-style, then immediately purchased this book after viewing the first 8 episodes back-to-back.  Fantastic, can't wait to get through the next books in the series!

I bought this book because numerous friends have told me how good it is. They said they couldn't put the book down. I am half way through and i keep waiting for it to get better. But so far i am finding it really slow and boring.

This book has an overarching theme of rape; in addition to beatings, and other torture and sadistic behavior. It's basically a romance novel that is soft core, with graphic brutality. One of very few books I truly regret finishing.

Amazing book! Really grabs you in, but I'm starting to not like Claire towards the end, and also getting into the second book. That is really disappointing, but I'm going to keep reading the series and hopes she redeems herself.

I've just finished re-reading the Outlander series for the second time.  I think I may have loved it more the second time and I never read books twice!  Also, listening to in on the audiobook read by Davina Porter is excellent!

Very disappointed in the thinly written story. Having read all books by Dorothy Dunnett, I had hopes for an exciting series - but no, sex to the point of tedium and very little else. Gave up about two thirds of the way through.

This book was okay if you like that sort of thing. I enjoyed the first part but when the character starts getting beat to smithereens and she fights off a pack of wolves, it was too much for me.  I didn't want to read anymore.

Outlander is a series of 5 books, quite large in volume. When I first read Outlander, I loved this story, and I loved the characters. But by the time I finished this book I wasn't sure I wanted to read the next one and find out what happened to Jamie and Claire. But as I said, I was now engrossed with the people and the story and so I continued. I am now half way through the third novel and already own the last two. And I STILL wonder WHY I am continueing to read these! And here is why, Diana Gabaldon writes in DETAIL right down to the dirt on someones shoes. And she says so and so got chills and not because the room was cold; so many times you want to wretch. She writes pages and pages and pages of things that have nothing to do with the story. You really begin to wonder where she is headed and you start to feel that she is either wasting your time or she just likes the sound of her own voice. OR she enjoys BEING this character right down to the last thought and shiver. I find myself speed reading through some passages looking for when we are going to get back on track. Don't get me wrong, she is BRILLIANT!! If you love historical fiction, you WILL love her writing and you will LEARN alot about living in the time she writes about as well as the Scots. She does her homework, her research is impeccable and she has a cult following with this series. It is a great story and I will read all of them, I just think she could have written the SAME story in half the time. So forewarned is forearmed with Diana Gabaldon. If you have tons of time to kill, this is your book!

This is not a serious novel. It features time travel and a woman's adjustment to the Scottish highlands 200 years ago. Lots of sex. Lots of physical torture and a fair share of deviants. I enjoyed it at first but it grew old.

One of the best historical fiction series I have ever read, and one I constantly recommend to friends. I have not met a friend or family member yet who has read the book and not fallen in love with it and the entire series.

I could not put this book down. To enjoy it more, I read it slowly. My daughter is the person who suggested I read it. I can not wait to continue reading the series!! It is definitely a book I will tell my friends to enjoy.

Usually people try to read the book before watching the film or tv film. The books are great, but it seems that the STARZ series is doing all 16 episodes out of one book! And it is covering the material very well. LOVE IT!!

After seeing the Starz series, intrigued by the time travel and history aspects,I was looking forward to reading the book. It's a sizable undertaking at 850 pages of small print (paperback edition).  I enjoyed much of the effort, but wondered why a more effective editing job wasn't performed...seems as if Gabaldon never found a fact or detail she didn't want to include.  I realize Outlander was billed as a romance novel, but at times, she way overdid the sex with ridiculous details such as claiming the thickness of a man's thumb indicates the thickness of his cock.  Also, once the protagonist, Claire, reveals her background to her 18th century husband, Jamie, he very rarely asks her anything about the future...he's supposed to be a highly educated and bright man, but seems to completely lack curiosity about future events...no explanation of this is offered and I continually wondered why.  Claire also seems to have settled for being along for the ride, making little effort to be more than Jamie's companion, caretaker, and sex object although she's also supposed to be a bright, liberated woman who just experienced the horrors of World War II as a combat nurse.  I kept wondering why she didn't make greater use of her medical gifts and knowledge to make life better for those she encountered...her discussion with a friar in France would seem to put to rest any concerns she had about changing the future.  I just ordered the second book in the series and I hope both lead characters will be further developed...I'm willing to give it a chance.

I've read fanfiction better. Oh, it did lure me in for a bit, and it was enjoyable for the first half or so. but then it devolved big time. The ending was pure rape fantasy nonsense and could have been cut by 100 pages.

I have to say I'm a little disappointed after all the hype.  The story-line and history are ok, but both are kind of lost in the "romance." I would say it's "Fifty Shades of Gray" with a Scottish accent.

Ms.Gabaldon is truly an amazing writer. If you've thought about picking up this book, my recommendation is a definate yes! You won't be disappointed and pretty quick you will emerged into a rich and awe inspiring story!

The "Outlander" series is by far the best set of books that I have ever read!  So good in fact, that I try to get everyone I know to read them.  Only two people that I have given the first book to have never gone  on to finish the series.  One of my close friends and I talk about the  books so often, we convinced another close friend (who does not read much  beyond mysteries and true crime) to read Outlander.  She finished it and  demanded the rest of the series!  She is now avidly awaiting "The  Fiery Cross" with the rest of us. Diana Gabaldon has a storytelling  ability like no other that I have ever seen and in the words of my mother  "what an imagination"!  Her theories on the standing stones found  throughout the British Isles is thought provoking.  The wonderful story  that began with a post-war nurse getting reaquainted with her husband in  Scotland and being thrown back in time to Jacobean Scotland continues with  the story of her daughter in "Drums of Autumn".  I can't wait for  the next installlment of the series.  I also can't wait for Diana's new  mystery that she is currently working on.  Just one thing to add, I think  that the publisher and the bookstores have done a great disservice by  classifying these books as Romance.  They are far from being your typical  romance and I think that this classification deters many people who think  that romance books are all fluff and not worth reading.  I think reading is  important, no matter what you're reading.

What an adventure!  A real page turner.  When I wasn't actually reading it, I was thinking about it.  Wonderful characters and action that keeps you guessing what will happen next!  I can't wait to read the next one.

I was glad when this book was over.  I will never read another one by this author. Kind of reminded me of the clan of the cave bear series. By the end you are thinking what's next will she invent the polio vaccine ?

The story tends to drag a little bit. The romance scenes are a little too muted for my taste- having reading 50 Shades...I wouldn't say this is the best romance novel of all time, but it is enjoyable....sort of.

Although this was listed as used, this book came shipped in perfect condition.  I have ordered various used books from Amazon and have always been pleased.  This vendor was no exception.  Thank you.  Rhoda Stein

I LOVED this book, and all the sequels! Diana Gabaldon is an amazing writer, and therefore the books are very well written. The romance is wonderful, and the main character is an amazing woman. I LOVED IT!!!!

Great read! I'm going on the pretense that just about everyone has read this book so be warned, I may spoil some of the plot. I also have to admit that I've been living under a rock for the past 20 years, because despite being an avid reader and having worked in a library I just discovered this wonderful series by Diana Gabaldon. This novel is a great combination of intense drama, angsty romance and comedy. Yes comedy. There are some great (funny) conversations between Claire and Jamie as they both get to know and understand each other, especially later on in their relationship. Claire being a modern woman of the 1940's trying to adjust to Jamie's world of the 1700's is fascinating and the author has done a wonderful job of capturing her mixed emotions. This is especially so, when Claire has to decided whether to return to her time or stay in the past and once having made that decision know what the future has in store for them. The question Claire faces: should she try to change the future or just get out of its way.  The author did a great job of handling the torture Jamie endured at the hands of one particular English captain with such emotion. It was gut wrenching and it tore my heart out as he recounted the experience to Claire. The amount research done is evident in how she describes with detail the life of those living in the Scottish highlands in the 1700's. Definitely worth reading and I can't wait to start the next one.

Having fallen in love with the TV show, I felt I owed it to myself to catch up by reading the books as I'd done on several books(GoT,TVD,Mortal Instruments to name a few). Yet again I wasn't disappointed. Jamie is a dream come true. Big,ruggedly handsome,sweet, protective with the sexiest accent I can only imagine. Claire is his match in very way, beautiful,smart,resourceful, stubborn, and dangerously opinionated for the 1740's. I found the book Claire and Jamie more playful,lighter even than the show. They flirt a lot,talk dirty to each other. I just found them more personable,less serious. Things do get dire, but they always have each other, and they always find the humor in everything. Even when the most dreadful things happen to Jamie, and I think he's done for Claire yells at him,pulls him back from the brink with just a touch. I like show Geilis and show Dougal -they bring so much physically to these characters that I don't think it translates in the books very well. There are some slow parts in the books - the ghosts stories( though I know they may have meaning later), the childhood beatings Jamie got- I know they were character builders and so people can see the difference between love and abuse but I just thought it was too much.  It was a great ride though, I did manage to finish before episode 2 on Saturday(FYI) which was my goal. These books are a commitment, but if I can read GoT, this series is no problem. 4/4.5*

I have to admit that I watched an episode of the show on Starz by accident... It was the day that they were showing all of season 1 volume 1. I only caught a little of it as I had the TV going for back ground noise well working around the kitchen... Found what I was looking for and downloaded all of the first season volume 1...And watched it non-stop start to finish (& ordered it from Amazon that moment)... Then having to wait till the following Saturday for the next volume to start....But we'll in town a day or two later. I was talking to a friend, and she asked if I'd read the book's? I had no idea that the show was from a book... She enlightened me... So I bought the 1st book and just finished it... Needless to say I will be getting the rest of the book's as soon as I finish this review, as I'm now hooked on following my new found friend's.... I say to anyone that is looking to start this series of book's.... Do it now, don't delay... It is an amazing read!!! But be prepared, it won't stop with the 1 book.... Once you start you'll want to continue... I know I do.... A big Thank You to Diana Gabaldon, for bringing this in to the world....

I really enjoyed Outlander. Though it was fiction, there was a lot of history and detail which I found interesting. I wanted the story to go on and on. I've already ordered the second book in this series.

This series of books are my all time favorites! They provide entertainment and yet not a fluff read. Make sure  you have the entire series close at hand so you don't waste time looking around for these.

Every so often, I stumble upon a story that is so incredibly gripping, that I can do nothing but read until I've soaked the last word in.  I just finished this book less than a minute ago, and I've only slept a few short hours in the last two days! My interests in novels lays in two distinct categories: science-fiction - stories by authors like Orson Scott Card, Frank Herbert & Robert Heinlein, stories that make me deeply contemplate our universe, how it works, what our place is in it, and what our future might look like, and historical fiction - those stories that transport me to a time long past, stories that entertain with their fictional romances and characters, blended seamlessly with factual information about the time the story takes place in.  I am and will always be a lifelong reader, and I can honestly say that Outlander is the first book I've ever read that so perfectly blends my two favorite genres together.  I've always believed that the best stories, whether in books or movies, do more than entertain... They make you really contemplate and reflect.  Not only has this book set me down a path of finding out more about my own Scottish ancestry, it's made me deeply contemplate the universe and theories we now believe to be impossible, but may very well be the opposite.  I am a very, very happy girl right now, and I think I'll be recommending this story for a long time to come.  Now - on to book 2!

I love this book today as much as I did when I first read it 20 years ago as a teenager. This series will always be my favorite! Whenever I am asked for reading suggestions, this book is the first one.

Very romantic ...makes a girl wish for her own Scotsman...but a little too heavy on the love making scenes and too many unrealistic escapes...is this about Jamie and Clair's or superman and Louis lane?

I have read many reviews of this book and I am not surprised that it has become well loved by thousands of readers. It transcends fiction genres. I looked for the sequels in "science fiction." It never occured to me that Outlander was a romance when I read it. As an avid reader of science fiction, fantasy, and historical fiction (and having my degree in history), I saw it as historical fiction with a twist of fantasy, albeit with terrific romantic scenes included for all to enjoy! I think this book could have been marketed much more intelligently. It does not need to be classified by genre. How about just calling it "fiction"? Such an incredible, touching, story deserves to be exposed to as many people as possible.  I would also like to congratulate the author on her historical accuracy. Claire's perspective on the lives of 18th century Scots was even more poignant because she had the dubious gift  of foresight into these people's lives. She could also then be a critic of their world as well as her own "modernized" one.  And on a personal note:  any expectant mother will find Jenny's observations on the impending birth of a child in the Outlander sequel, Dragonfly in Amber, particularly beautiful. I cried when I read her words and when my son was born I had to write them down in his baby book. Not every author can craft characters that speak to our hearts.
The story line is interesting but the writer goes on forever about what the conditions of the weather are or what color something is.  I haven't finished the book yet because I'm tired of reading it.
The first of the book was interesting and intriguing. Very descriptive and well written.  After reading for awhile, the plot turned more into a chick flick type of book and  I became dis-interested.
Very unimpressed.  An interesting idea, with lots of potential.  However, it read like an historical romance novel, with silly, contrived relationships and situations, and not much history or plot.
It could never really get into this novel.  I had heard that it was good so I bought it which is why I finished reading it.  I did not like the book, but that does not mean that you won't like it.
I just finished the 6th book in the series. I have read many romances but this one is the best by far and this story will stick with me forever. I love my husband but I still wish I had a Jamie...
The most amazing book and series I have ever read. Absolutely captivating. Beautifully researched and written. The only thing that could top these books is if Jamie knocked on my door one night...

Outlander Novels in a word.....OUTSTANDING...... Engrossing and hard to put down.. very period specific.  This author did some research before attempting this love story/period piece. I have read books one and will finish book 2 'dragonfly in amber' today. My only concern now is that I had wanted to watch the Starz series coming up based on these novels and neither of the actors shown in the commercial's who will portray Clare and Jamie even REMOTELY fit the images in my mind of Clare and Jamie which is very disappointing. . It's rare when a casting company and a producer come anywhere close to the images in the readers minds of characters.  All through the books Jamie is described as having fiery red hair with streaks of copper and gold, powerfully built and tall... where do you see that on this actor who's to play Jamie?. His stature and hair color is nowhere near the description of Jamie. and Clare.. no way... sorry Starz.. you guys missed the boat completely on this one..  MY Jamie and Clare are way better...Why on earth did they cast Sam Heughan as Jamie instead of someone who actually fits the description like actor Brian Robinson, he's red headed, TALL and BUILT and with an Irish accent which I'm sure could become Scottish verra quickly.  (verra was a deliberate spelling, not a mistake) Personally, I'll just finish the books and forget the series on tv..
Easy reading, or listening. Great rhythm, and characters. Loved it. I give it 5 stars and am buying the set.  The audio has the best voice I've heard to date, and really brought the book to life.
When the book was recommended I was leerry because it was not my type of read and it was rather a long read. Now that I am well into the book, I love it and I can't wait to order the other books.

I purchased the paperback Outlander (named Cross Stitch in the UK) as a last resort of a bad choice of books as WH Smith at Heathrow Airport to while away the flight to Chicago where I was going to visit my sister in May 1995 -  the book store in the airport didn't seem to have anything that appealed to me but as a former student of archaeology the historical background suggested that this book might at least pass away  a boring 8 hours.From the first line I was completely hooked and  the  hours literally flew past. I ignored my  9 year old daughter who was accompanying me and could barely tear myself away for drinks and meals (well okay meals, maybe - I did indulge in several drinks!)  I have avidly awaited the publication of each book since. I have the paperback of Cross Stitch, Dragonfly in Amber and Voyager and the hardback of Drums of Autumn  (couldn't wait for the paperback of this one to be published in the UK) and have read all 4 at least 3 times.  I am madly in love with Jamie Fraser who transports me from my mundane life as a bored Welsh housewife and cannot wait for The Fiery Cross, and Farewell, King to be published so that I can escape once more into the world of the 18th century and a time when men really loved their women and didn't just expect them to hoover the house and look after their kids and have their dinner on the table each evening.
I am among the many who love this series and want to be sure everyone knows it is about to become a series on The Starz network in the fall. Try the audio series read by Davina Porter. The best!
This entire series is perfect for someone who has romance in their heart. It's a wonderful read and Gabaldon's characters are so witty that I am often laughing out loud. I love this series!!!!
I know this series is very popular.  I made it through this first of the series, but I thought it was a little bit too long.  It passed the time, but it's by far not one of my favorite books.
I thought Outlander was just okay.  Long and pretty boring. Was hard for me to finish.  I got tired of the sex between Claire and Jamie, which consumed most of the book.  Would not recommend.

The first novel in my favorite series of all time, Outlander follows Claire Randall, an English WWII nurse visiting Scotland with her husband Frank, to have a second honeymoon of sorts now that the war is no longer keeping them stationed in separate places.  An amateur herbalist, Claire goes exploring around a local standing stone circle, and is sucked back in time ~200 years to a Scotland on the brink of rebellion. There she meets Jaime Fraser, the highlander who will become her husband, rescuer, rescuee, sparring partner, and great love. Her knowledge of modern medicine, herbs, and history give her valuable tools of survival, but her modern sensibilities also make it difficult for her to make he way in a culture still steeped in superstition and the more misogynistic side of "chivalry." Jaime becomes the man who is equal to the challenge of a strong-willed, highly intelligent, educated, and medically skilled English woman whose mere presence in per-rebellion Scotland elicits suspicions of spying and witchcraft. This novel, and the rest in the series, are steeped in thoroughly researched historical detail, a slew of engaging characters, and conflict on scales ranging from interpersonal to international. This book is about 4 1/2 stars, rounded up (there are some scenes that are historically accurate, but may jar a modern reader).

I was recently weeding out old books, trying to make space in my overflowing bookcases for new purchases. I came across my old copy of OUTLANDER and considered getting rid of it. After all, I didn't care for the later Gabaldon novels and had quit reading the series after a few books. So maybe my fond memories of staying up too late night-after-night reading OUTLANDER years ago were distorted? Or maybe I would no longer like a book I had liked years ago? With these notions in mind, I opened it to read a few pages before discarding it... and found I COULDN'T discard it. Now that I had started it, without having had any intention of reading the whole novel, I couldn't put it down! Exactly as I remembered from years ago, I was once again up too late at night, several nights in a row, unable to stop reading even after I got sleepy and knew I'd regret it in the morning. It's a wonderful, engaging, energetic, compelling, romantic high-adventure tale of love, history, action, intrigue, loyalty, betrayal, and fantasy! The first time I read it, I thought it was a stand-alone novel and had no idea the author intended to write a series. And it still works well as a stand-alone novel. If, like me, you didn't enjoy Gabaldon's later books, it's well worth returning to this early book--you're not remembering wrong, it really IS a terrific read.

Outlander is a title that I've had several people tell me I need to read, but I just put it in the back of my mind as a dated historical romance until this tag. I wish that I had read this book when it first came out (granted, I would have been nine years old), because then the novelty of time travel would have been fresh, and I wouldn't have felt the weight of every other romance I've read over the years with that theme that have cribbed from Outlander. Claire is a wonderful, absolutely non-stereotypical, character. Her dilemma of loving and marrying two men in two different times makes her fascinating as well. There was only one time I wanted to smack her: In Wentworth Prison, instead of watching Jamie and the brute fighting each other, she should have had the forthwith to smack Randall and take care of him before he woke up!! That made me want to tear my hair out a bit. The middle did drag a bit, and for awhile it felt like the book would never end. I enjoyed it, but it was loooong! I have already added Dragonfly in Amber, the sequel,  to my wish list. It's got romantic sex without being pornographic. Lots of amazing historical detail. Jamie is awesome! How cool is it that for once the MAN is the virgin! Gabaldon turns so many romance stereotypes on their head. Even in a book that 26 years old, she makes the genre new again.
Well written, it keeps you turning the pages to find out more. You think about the story even when you are not reading. Excited to see what the next book holds in store for Claire and Jamie.
I couldn't wait to read the next chapter and when I finish it, I had to get the next book to see what happen. Once I started I could put it down . I wanted up find out where Clair went next.

I've been a long time fan of this series.  Just for fun I looked through some other reviews, especially the negative reviews because I was curious to see what it was about the book that caused people to give it just one star.  Now, I completely disagree with what the naysayers have posted about the book, but I also respect that every one has opinions and these people are entitled to have their own.  If you are reading the reviews on here, my word of advice is to take them with a grain of salt.  Again, these are people's opinions and things that bother them, may not bother you.  As much as the infamous "wife beating scene" bothered me when I read it, I also took into consideration that this was set in the 1700's and things were done a heck of a lot differently back then and frankly much worse things also took place (maybe drawn and quartered rings a bell?).  So, I seriously recommend when you're deciding whether or not to read this book, realize that it takes place during a very dangerous time and is written in very intense details.  Draw your own conclusions about the characters and understand that just because one person thinks it's not a good story doesn't mean you won't enjoy it.  If you do complete this book and do indeed enjoy it as I hope you will, the next books in the series get better and better!  Happy reading!!
I only read this to find out what happened in the second season of the television show.  It is slow because of too much details.  I like developed main people but the rest was too detailed.
A wonderful opening to the Outlander series, a must read. Book was as described. Some lightly dog-earred pages which I had no problems with, as I could feel comfortable marking other pages.
This was a most fascinating look at Scotland's history and culture filled with romance, superstition, religion and politics. I'm ready to get the next book because it can only get better.
I love the setting (Scotland) & the time frame.  But the story line is enthralling & so captivating.  I look forward to my getaway into this world each night.  Can't wait to begin book 2.

I picked this book up in an airport a couple years ago looking for a time killer.  I read it the entire vacation, the way home, at home -and read it four more times that year.  I think this book is one of the best escape books I've read in ages.  I fell head over heels with Claires wit, Jamies earthiness.  Problems?  Well, I got obsessed -watched Braveheart and fell in further -was suddenly looking for a man in a kilt and the misted crags of Scotland.  I was in Ohio at the time. . . Those of you who are critiqueing Gabadalon's style -yes, you have some valid points.  However it sounds as though you are people who don't lose yourself in this kind of book.  Relax and don't take it too seriously (it *is* FICTION btw), find yourself a writer who suits you and don't spoil it for those of us who fell in love with this series.  For some of us, it is a godsend in the area of escape literature and fantasy.  I recommend this book (the rest of the series is steadily altered, so takes a bit of priming of expectations) to anyone needing a good long walk through a the gamut of emotions -this book will take you there.  I think the overall message she is portraying is that life carries the unexpected - laugh at what you can, and understand the rest is a part of your travels.  Read well!
This book was good, although not my favorite. It took a bit of time to get "into it", but after that it was enjoyable to read. I'm not so sure I'll read the next books, though...
This is what mommy porn was before there was fifty. It's neither good fiction nor good mommy porn. Either get a good book or get fifty shades. It makes me sad that people like this book.
I was skeptical to read this book but onceI began I could not stop!  If you are interested in history along with witchery this is a must read.  I'm looking forward to read the next book!
